]>
COMMONWEALTH OF AUSTRALIA
PARLIAMENTARY DEBATES
HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES
Hansard
1997
FIRST SESSION OF THE THIRTY‐EIGHTH PARLIAMENT
(THIRD PERIOD)
The House of Representatives, on 13 December 1996, pursuant to resolution, adjourned to Tuesday, 4 February 1997 at 2 p.m. Pursuant to that resolution the House of Representatives met on Tuesday, 4 February at 2 p.m.
Tuesday, 4 February 1997
Mr SPEAKER (Hon. R. G. Halverson OBE)
took the chair at 2.00 p.m., and read prayers.
CONDOLENCES
Panizza, Senator John Horace
Mr HOWARD
(Bennelong—
Prime Minister)
(2.01 p.m.)
—I move:
That the House expresses its deep regret at the death, on 31 January 1997, of Senator John Horace Panizza, a Senator for the state of Western Australia since 1987, Opposition Whip in the Senate from 1995 to 1996; and Government Whip in the Senate since 1996, places on record its appreciation of his long and meritorious public service, and tenders its profound sympathy to his family in their bereavement.
There is, I suppose, a special poignancy when one of our serving colleagues dies and when he goes from our midst on public service, as was the case with John Panizza, who died whilst participating at a meeting of the Senate Standing Committee of Privileges in Cairns on 31 January.
John Panizza was born on 24 March 1931 at Southern Cross in Western Australia. He was a farmer and property developer in Western Australia before entering federal politics. He came to the Senate with a very
solid background in local government. He had been a councillor of the Yilgarn Shire Council from 1975 to 1987, during which he was Shire President for five years from 1982 to 1987.
He was a very successful wheat grower. It was often the object of very friendly remark by many colleagues who regularly travelled the distance to Western Australia that, if you fell asleep at the beginning of John's property, you could still have a decent respite, wake up and still be travelling across it. He was very much a man of the soil. He was a person who fought tenaciously for the interests of his state and for the interests of the wheat growers.
John was of very direct and blunt manner. His interventions in the party room were always to the point. They were always prefaced by his saying, `Prime Minister, you ought to understand that they are saying this.' And you were left in no doubt about what they were saying. He always managed to cut through in his contributions in the party room and to push aside a lot of the humbug.
In his maiden speech to the Senate, he referred to his election as a realisation of an ambition that he had had since he was 20 years old. He spoke on the many issues primary industries faced in Western Australia, and he displayed a wide knowledge of these industries, ranging from wheat growing and
meat production to mining, including the gold and diamond industries, to fishing. Above all, he declared his commitment to the needs and concerns of rural Western Australia, to its people and to its industries. He touched on important rural issues such as access to all levels of education by country children and adequate water supply.
Significantly, John concluded his maiden speech by referring to his Italian parentage and paid special tribute to the hardships, the achievements and the contributions that migrants have made to the building of modern Australia. He was, as I understand, the first person of Italian parentage to be elected to the Australian Senate. His vision of a tolerant united Australian community was not tied up with the obsessions of professional lobbies but, rather, with the down-to‐earth determination to ensure that all Australians, irrespective of their background, were treated equally.
Throughout his parliamentary career, he never ceased to champion the interests that he entered the Senate to represent. He was a staunch member and active participant in the affairs of the Liberal Party over a long period of time. Along with all the other members of the Liberal Party in Western Australia, he played a major role in the resurgence of the Western Australian division at the time of the state election before last and played a major role in the success of the division in the last federal election.
He served as Deputy Opposition Whip in the Senate in 1993, and when the coalition assumed government in March of last year he was elected to the position of Government Whip in the Senate.
His efforts on Senate committees were acknowledged on all sides of politics. In his 9½ years in the Senate he served on numerous committees. At the time of his death, he was a serving member of the Senate Economics References Committee, the House Committee, the Privileges Committee and the Standing Committee for the Selection of Bills as well as the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade. As I mentioned at the commencement of my remarks, he was in Cairns working on the Privileges Committee at the time of his death.
In his passing, Western Australia, the parliament and my party—the Liberal Party—have lost a strong, down‐to‐earth voice. We miss him greatly. I spoke to his wife, Coral, a few hours after his death. He died in his sleep with his wife beside him. On behalf of the government, I extend to his wife, Coral, to his mother, Mrs Caterina Panizza, to his children, Frank, Janine, Stephen and Linda and to their families our very sincere sympathy in their sudden bereavement.
His funeral will take place in St Mary's Catholic Cathedral in Perth on Friday morning. I and many other members of the government will attend the funeral to pay our respects to a well‐loved and a very well‐respected colleague.
I want to take this opportunity to record my personal gratitude to a number of my colleagues—Senator Helen Coonan, Senator Chris Ellison, Senator Bill O'Chee and others—who were with John and Coral Panizza in Cairns when John died suddenly. My colleagues rendered immediate compassion, sympathy and support to Coral quite naturally and as a spontaneous expression of their concern for the bereavement suffered by the wife of a colleague.
We will miss John. He was a cheerful, lovable bloke who epitomised the down‐to‐earth qualities of the Australian bush. He brought a lot to parliament. He threw his heart into what he did in his life. He was a devoted family man. He was a devoted farmer. He was a devoted servant of the Liberal Party. He was proud of his Italian heritage, but he was a 100 per cent lover of the Australian nation, which he served so very well.
Mr BEAZLEY
(Brand—
Leader of the Opposition)
(2.08 p.m)
—I join with the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) on this very sad occasion. I guess most members of this House, particularly Western Australians, can scarcely believe that this has happened, because Senator Panizza, if you knew the man, seemed so indestructible. He seemed so much part of the soil which he tilled; he was as solid and as timeless as the Australian earth itself. That he should die in office is an occasion of very great sadness for us all and
not an outcome that any of us would have expected.
The Prime Minister has outlined Senator Panizza's meritorious service in the Senate and elsewhere and I will not go over the ground that the Prime Minister covered canvassing those, except to say this: it is attested on our side of the House that Senator Panizza's decency, generosity, truthfulness, honesty and plain dealing is the experience of all of us in relation to him. His departure is mourned I suspect almost as much on our side of the House as it is on the other side of the House.
He was an effective senator representing the interests of many Western Australians. He was an authentic Australian success story of the postwar era. If you look at his background and the sorts of things he did, you begin to understand that there was one unfortunate feature of his life: because he had to struggle so hard, because he had to do so much, he probably arrived at each stage of his public service a little later than would otherwise have been the case; hence we find him in office, at the age of 65, having had a fairly short period of service in the parliament.
He preceded that with a most extraordinary record of establishing himself in an area of Western Australia which is not easy to establish yourself in. Life out there is always a struggle. The rewards are great if you get it right, but it is always a struggle. He had interests that were broad, not just in the agricultural sector. He developed empathy with his area in the mining industry as well. So his success in business and in farming life was matched by his contribution to public life—long service in local government and then service in this place.
So we have lost a very good colleague. Western Australia has lost a very good senator. We have lost from this parliament a person with an unusual record: the first in the Senate of Italian descent. We provided the first member of the House of Representatives born in Italy—Con Sciacca. I know they had some interesting chats together as the years proceeded. But that was a major achievement on Senator Panizza's part—to win preselec
tion and come into this place with the background that he had.
The WA Liberal Party has lost an effective campaigner and member, but above all his wife, Coral, and their four children have lost a beloved husband and father. I will not, unfortunately, be able to attend his funeral, but I will make sure that I am appropriately represented, and I apologise to his family in advance at the same time as I extend the opposition's deepest sympathy.
Mr TIM FISCHER
(Farrer—
Leader of the National Party of Australia)
(2.12 p.m.)
—It was a great shock to learn at Broken Hill last Friday of the passing of John Panizza and I join with the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) and the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) in expressing my sadness and sympathy to members of the Panizza family. John, it has been said, was a staunch advocate of things Western Australian, things relating to the primary industries of Western Australia and indeed of Australia and matters relating to rural and regional Australia. He was arguably the largest single wheat producer ever to sit in the federal parliament and he took not just an interest in that industry but also an interest in a wide range of primary industries in a dedicated and determined way.
As the Prime Minister has mentioned, John Panizza, before entering the Senate, gave great service to the local government area around Southern Cross, from which he came, serving as shire president and performing a range of other community activities. His contributions in the Senate were consistent since he entered that place in 1987. He always put forward a very strongly held view and put effort into his comments whether it was in the Senate, in committee meetings or in the joint party room of the Liberal and National parties.
I have to say to the House that I think Western Australian members of this parliament—be they members of the House of Representatives or be they members of the Senate—carry a particular burden created by the time zone difference and the extra hours spent on aircraft as they travel to and from Canberra and many other places. For instance, Senator Panizza was in Far North Queensland
with the Privileges Committee when the tragic event occurred. It is a burden; it is one which must tell on their health by degrees. John Panizza always gave the manifestation of being a particularly tough, determined operator, yet the burden caught up with him. I am very conscious of that extra burden carried by Western Australian members of this parliament and I really do express my sympathy and that of my wife, Judy, to the Panizza family.
I make one other point. John Panizza's maiden speech highlighted the fact that he travelled enormous distance in the contest of the Western Australian Senate elections both in 1985, the time he lost by 115 votes, and in 1987. It does take a particular determination to bounce back from a lost campaign in which you just miss out, yet he did that and went forward to take up a seat in the Senate as the son of Italian parents, creating yet another first. In his maiden speech, which the Prime Minister briefly referred to, he said:
At a time when the term `multiculturalism' has been misconstrued—
remember that this was back in 1987—
through prejudice and mistrust, each Australian, including political parties, must dedicate themselves to overcome those elements of ignorance and prejudice in our society which are counterproductive to Australia being a successful nation, a cohesive nation, a democratic nation.
I say amen to that. I am very glad that, in addition to a cathedral service being held in Perth on Friday morning, arrangements are in hand to have on Tuesday morning of next week a mass in his honour at the cathedral in Manuka.
John Paterson, former Federal President of the National Party—he has stepped down from that position—and the Western Australian Nationals have conveyed to me their desire to be associated with this condolence motion. They obviously had many more direct dealings with him over the years. I have the happy duty of passing that on.
The Panizza family can be rightly proud of the contribution John Panizza made to the state of Western Australia and, through his service in the Senate, to the nation.
Debate (on motion by
Mr Reith
) adjourned.
Kelly, Hon. Charles Robert, CMG
Mr HOWARD
(Bennelong—
Prime Minister)
(2.17 p.m.)
—I move:
That the House expresses its deep regret at the death, on 17 January 1997, of the Honourable Charles Robert (Bert) Kelly CMG, a Member of this House for the Division of Wakefield from 1958 to 1977, Deputy Government Whip from 1964 to 1967, Minister for Works from 1967 to 1968, and Minister for the Navy from 1968 to 1969, places on record its appreciation of his long and meritorious public service, and tenders its profound sympathy to his family in their bereavement.
Bert Kelly, as he was affectionately known by his colleagues and many others, was born on 22 June 1912 at Riverton in South Australia. He was a farmer in South Australia before entering federal politics. He was a member of the South Australian Soil Conservation Committee from 1940 to 1958 and also served on the South Australian Advisory Board of Agriculture.
In 1951 Bert was awarded a Nuffield Fellowship to study farming in Britain. This was the first time farming fellowships had been awarded in Australia. Although his interest in primary production and in related issues such as soil conservation was to remain with him throughout his subsequent parliamentary career, his overwhelming concern and the single issue which he championed fearlessly and tirelessly in his political life was tariff reduction and free trade.
As I said in the news release that I issued marking his death, no person in the postwar parliamentary period or earlier than that period championed the cause of lower tariffs and free trade ahead of Bert Kelly. Whatever people's views may have been of Bert Kelly's views, he was, in a parliamentary sense, the trailblazer of lower tariffs. The significant thing about Bert Kelly's contribution was that, at the time he began to argue the cause of lower tariffs, it was not a particularly popular line to be taken. The conventional wisdom all round, indeed substantially on both sides of politics, was that it was a good idea to protect Australian industry from outside competition and that, if that imposed some burden on the export industries of Australia, then you compensated for that burden by some direct subsidies to those export industries. Bert
Kelly's father had been a member of the tariff board, and Bert himself, from his early days in parliament, began to champion the cause of lower tariffs.
I always found Bert Kelly's speeches entertaining. They were always full of humour. He developed to the full that great Australian art—and it is an art when it is developed effectively to the full—of self-deprecation. He could argue a case with winning humour. His speeches, I found in my experience after I entered parliament, always attracted a good attendance, particularly from government and some of the then opposition backbenchers.
Bert was one of the serving members of parliament who made me, as a member of the contingent of parliamentarians who came in in 1974, particularly welcome. I can remember spending many happy times with Bert and one of his South Australian colleagues Jim Forbes in the bar of Old Parliament House in the months that immediately followed my election. One of the other people who was always there listening to Bert's speeches—and I noticed a bit of rapport developing between him and Bert Kelly—was the then only recently elected member for Moore, John Hyde, who had entered parliament in the same year I had.
Bert was a trailblazer. He wrote a very lively column under the title `Modest Member'. A society was formed in his honour: the Society of Modest Members. Therefore, he did make quite a contribution towards the development of the line of argument that is variously paraded under the description of economic rationalism, dry economics, free trade or whatever description you want to give it.
This is not an occasion for trying to demonstrate who is right or who is wrong but rather an occasion to honour the fact that ahead of others Bert was prepared to courageously put points of view that a lot of people much senior to him in the government of which he was a backbench member and briefly a frontbench member would have heavily deprecated. I do not know that he would have got much encouragement but he probably would have got a great deal of deprecation
from the then Labor Party opposition, who was as heavily, if not more heavily, into the causes against which he so passionately argued.
Bert Kelly was a very earthy man in the best sense of that word. He was awake to anybody who was a humbug. He had a tremendous sense of humour. He concealed from most the deep hurt and disappointments that he felt in relation to his ministerial career. What was remarkable about Bert Kelly, in my experience of members of parliament, was that he spent only a very brief period on the front bench and most of his time on the back bench over quite a long period from 1958 until 1977, when, as a result of a redistribution, he was knocked out of the ring in a preselection contest, if my memory serves me correctly by his fellow South Australian Geoffrey O'Halloran Giles. These things sometimes happen in the best of managed circles. They had a bit of a clash and Bert came out second best. I think he had been spending more time arguing the causes in which he believed than attending to his branches.
Be that as it may, he continued to argue the cause. He continued to gather followers and devotees. There were many of my friends and acquaintances in the parliamentary Liberal Party in the 1980s who regarded Bert Kelly as some kind of antipodean Adam Smith when it came to the causes that they believed in and the causes that they were arguing.
He was one of those people who had a capacity to be remembered for the ideas that he championed rather than the particular policies that he implemented. He played a role in not only shifting thinking inside the Liberal Party, which he certainly did—and any member of the Liberal Party who pretends that Bert Kelly did not make a contribution to shifting the thinking inside the party on issues relating to industry protection and to more deregulation and freeing of the economy do not understand the history of debates inside our party—but also in arguing for deregulation and those other policies in the Australian press.
I want to say, on behalf of the parliamentary Liberal Party, that, in expressing our
sorrow at his death, we acknowledge that he lived to a good age, into his middle 80s. He had a long and very happy personal life and a very good life. His departure from federal politics in 1977 was marked by many tributes, perhaps best summed up by a
Bulletin
article which said:
Bert Kelly is almost a legend. He is one of those rare politicians who actually manages to see the importance of consistent long-term policies over immediate party advantage.
That may be collectively a little wounding to many, but it is a fair comment about the causes that Bert Kelly argued for. I certainly found him intellectually consistent. I found him good humoured. I found him passionate for things he believed in, but always in a way that was endearingly self-deprecating. In that sense, it was the more effective. He did not rant or rave; he seduced you with the good humour of the argument that he put. That was one of his very great capacities.
I want to express, on behalf of the federal parliamentary Liberal Party, to his wife Lorna, to his children Tony, Kim and Roger, and to their families, our most sincere sympathy in their bereavement. Bert made a remarkable contribution to public debate in Australia. On behalf of the Liberal Party, I thank him and send my condolences to his family.
Mr BEAZLEY
(Brand—
Leader of the Opposition)
(2.26 p.m.)
—I would like to support the remarks of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard). Unlike the Prime Minister, I did not have the privilege of knowing Bert Kelly personally, but I guess I did know him vicariously through my father, who served with him for many years in this parliament and had enormous respect for him, and more directly through his columns in the newspapers as the `Modest Member'. I suspect, via that process, we also know Lorna pretty well since, under the name of `Mavis', she appeared quite frequently as his foil in those deliberations of his across the pages of the newspapers.
Mr Tim Fischer
—Along with Eccles and others.
Mr BEAZLEY
—Eccles had a run, too, that is right. He was one of those people who made the public debate in many areas of politics interesting and brought with it that
lack of rancour and that sense of humour that the Prime Minister referred to.
The Prime Minister referred to his ministerial service—and I know, as a former Minister for Defence, that he was well regarded in the period he was Minister for the Navy. But I do not think he was ever meant to be a minister. If you look at his career, it was obvious that he was one of those people who would come into this place and make the rest of us feel proud to be a member of parliament, because he dealt with our inadequacies. He used the parliament as it was probably meant to be used by private members of parliament at the time of the creation of its mother in the British House of Commons hundreds of years ago. His character, which does not often appear in the Australian parliament, is more akin to those sorts of 19th century figures that we know never did ministerial service—people like Cobden and Bright. Ironically, it was their sorts of issues that in this century he essentially ran on.
His contribution to this place I would say lies not so much in the policy area, if we are going to remember him in this parliament, even in debate on tariffs, but in establishing the credibility of this House as a forum that addresses the needs and interests of the nation.
He obviously touched the heart of a former leader of the Labor Party, who has taken to advising me on valedictories. I do not think I would dare leave this chamber without at least having read a portion of his letter. It perhaps goes to something that the Prime Minister referred to. It comes from—and I will not read it all because it is obviously fairly lengthy—the Hon. E. G. Whitlam AC, QC. He said:
In your valedictory for Bert Kelly on Tuesday 4 February you might like to have some material from his State Funeral in Adelaide on Friday 24 January. No private member has had as much influence in changing a major policy of the major parties.
From his father W. S. (Stan) Kelly OBE, a member of the Tariff Board from 1929 to 1940, Bert imbibed a deep scepticism about the Scullin Government's policy of tariffs on request. McEwen hated him. I thought that Kelly's speeches on Tariff Board reports were much more consistently rational
than those of his colleagues or my colleagues. I naturally approved his support for my Government's 25 per cent tariff cuts in 1973.
During the Bass by-election in 1975, which is often compared with the Canberra by‐election in 1995—
this letter hurts—
the Liberals blamed the tariff cuts for the decline of the textile industry in Launceston. At Friday's exuberant wake several Liberals enjoyed recalling that Fraser had urged Kelly to campaign in Bass. Kelly responded that he was intending to do so—for me.
The State Funeral was held at Wesley Uniting Church at Kent Town. The congregation audibly approved when the officiating minister carefully enunciated the name of the first hymn "They who tread the Path of Labour"{.
Bert Kelly was christened Charles Robert after his maternal and paternal grandfathers. The congregation still more audibly approved when Bert's eldest son explained the order; W. S. Kelly was not going to have an R. C. Kelly in his family.
There is more in the same vein. Of course, what that indicates is evaluation by a very distinguished Australian himself of the contribution that was made by Bert Kelly to the public life of this nation.
This is one of those occasions when I can say that we are entirely genuine in the bipartisan condolences that we offer. He was a private member much loved on both sides of the House, probably because, apart from his contribution to the honour of our profession, it was that sense of humour, that absence of rancour that so dominated the style of his contribution to public life.
On behalf of the federal opposition, I join with the Prime Minister and other members of this House to pass our condolences to Bert Kelly's family, his wife, Lorna, and their children, grandchildren and great‐grandchildren.
Mr TIM FISCHER
(Farrer—
Leader of the National Party of Australia)
(2.32 p.m.)
—There are some similarities between John Panizza and Bert Kelly. Sure, they were in different chambers, had different times of service in the parliament and came from different states, but there was a degree of doggedness and determination about Bert Kelly which was replicated in John Panizza
and which perhaps flowed from their love of the land. In the case of Bert Kelly, it was those beautiful hills due north of Adelaide; and in the case of John Panizza, it was the country around Southern Cross.
In his first speech to parliament in 1959 Bert Kelly laid down from the very outset what his philosophy was about and took a particular interest in the trade policy area. He recognised the importance of building access to markets for our exporters. In what may be an unusual but accurate picture when viewed from an historical perspective, Bert Kelly, in his first speech, actually praised John McEwen, trade minister, for the work he had completed in developing trade treaties at the time with Japan and Malaya. They were steps in the right direction, and Bert Kelly said:
I should like at this stage to pay a very warm tribute to the Minister for Trade, Mr McEwen, for the clear sighted way in which he has worked to do this very thing, that is, to help us sell what we produce.
This was perhaps the lull before the storm, given what developed over the onward debate about tariffs and protection generally and the role that Bert Kelly took up, especially as the Modest Member.
Throughout his parliamentary career Bert Kelly clearly laid down the problems that he encountered and the many difficulties on the trading front for farmers and exporters. He made clear in his writings, in a very crisp way, a degree of irreverence in respect of government, bureaucracy and the political correctness of the time.
Australia would be a much poorer nation if it had not been for the gradual rising influence of the ideas espoused by Bert Kelly and his ability to put them forward in a way which cut through. His ability to analyse and present simply the effects of the tariff, good and bad, on our economic institutions and fortunes convinced increasing numbers of people to look more closely at policy directions.
We must not forget his contribution in other areas, however. They extended beyond the area of tariff and trade policy, in which it is not quite correct to say that he was absolutely one way on the issue. Indeed, a letter to the
editor in today's
Financial Review
offered some further comment on that aspect. He reached out from that to also take up a range of other issues, including rail standardisation across Australia. He joined such people as the former members for Farrer, David Fairbairn and Wal Fife, William Charles Wentworth and, indeed, the Right Hon. Ian Sinclair, the member for New England, in his previous portfolio roles, in helping to facilitate the decisions in tough budgetary circumstance to provide a standard gauge rail connection, particularly between Sydney and Melbourne, subsequently between Sydney and Perth and Sydney and Adelaide, via Broken Hill and Crystal Brook. That was a very good basis which led to the final completion of the standardisation direct between Melbourne and Adelaide.
In fact, in the conversations I enjoyed with Bert Kelly as a fellow member of the Modest Members Society, it was often this subject we talked about—as was his wont and my wont—and it was very true that that key committee played a key role in jogging the then Menzies/McEwen government along the path of facilitating that key rail standardisation at the time.
I join the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) and the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) in expressing the sympathy of National Party members to the family of Bert Kelly. There is no doubt that the parliament and the nation gained a great deal from the contribution that Bert Kelly made and the example he set to all of us who have been backbenchers at various times as to how there can be real influence and real power by a dedicated and determined backbencher.
Mr REITH
(Flinders—
Leader of the House)
(2.35 p.m.)
—I move:
That the debate be adjourned to a later hour this day.
For the information of members, it is agreed that we will now proceed to question time, the tabling of papers, the MPI and then the debates will resume on both matters in sequence.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
MINISTERIAL ARRANGEMENTS
Mr HOWARD
(Bennelong—
Prime Minister)
(2.36 p.m.)
—The Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Downer) will be absent from question time this week. He is visiting the United Kingdom and Europe on government business. The Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Tim Fischer) will answer questions on his behalf. The Minister for Finance (Mr Fahey) is also absent from question time this week. He is representing the government at a world economic forum in Switzerland. The Treasurer (Mr Costello) will answer questions on his behalf.
QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
Savings
Mr BEAZLEY
—My question is to the Treasurer. Now that the Treasurer is aware of the flexibility of Treasury forward estimates which have produced in his case a $3 billion Costello crater, and given that the bulk of it is a result of a forecast of a shortfall in company tax receipts, will he give a guarantee that he will not seek to fill his crater by repudiating the coalition government's promise to maintain the full three per cent government contribution to all Australian superannuation accounts and like savings vehicles—in other words, swapping public savings directly for a hit on private savings? Can the Treasurer give that guarantee?
Mr COSTELLO
—Last year, when the Labor government released its mid-year review, it released a three-page press release and said, in the lead-up to a federal election campaign, that the budget was balanced when it was $10 billion in deficit. Don't you come in here and try to assert there is some kind of moral equivalence between you and us! This is the government that is putting in place legislation to ensure the level of deceit practised by you personally will never again occur in Australia. This was practised by you personally, the chief person in the lead-up to the election. You went out onto the radio waves and tried to claim that the budget was balanced and waited until after the election before you asked that fatal question about where the accounts really were. So this government swept that away.
We have a charter of budget honesty coming into this place to legislate to ensure that never happens again. We want to see the colour of your money, whether you will vote for it—whether you will vote to make sure nobody ever again tries to do what you did. That is the great challenge for you, my friend: to at least have the decency to legislate to make sure nobody ever again tries to do what you did—a great challenge.
So we went out into the mid-year review and, in accordance with the charter of budget honesty, released 100 pages. We reviewed all of the estimations and all of the forecasts and said what the projected outcome would be, not only for this year but also for next year and the year after—figures that the Labor Party had never even tried to disclose. So don't come in here on the doctrine of moral equivalence. Nobody will ever morally equal your deceit before the last election.
In relation to matters that will be announced in the budget on 13 May, as the Prime Minister and I have made entirely clear, after the enormous progress that was made in last year's budget by the coalition government in reducing deficits in the forward estimates, this government will be continuing the process of fiscal consolidation. Those areas which have already been substantially visited will not be revisited because so much work was done and the restructuring was put in place in the last budget.
In relation to the social safety net, this government will ensure that the social safety net continues. In relation to other matters, the government, in accordance with time honoured practice, will not be giving a day-to-day commentary on the matters which will be announced. They will be announced on budget night, 13 May.
Economy
Mr BARTLETT
—My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. What are the priorities for the government for this year? What action is the government taking to ensure that pressures on families are eased, that small businesses are in a position to generate jobs for young Australians and that
the economy is managed properly instead of having periods of boom and bust?
Mr HOWARD
—I say in response to the member for Macquarie that it is appropriate at the beginning of a parliamentary year to briefly state the government's priorities. Those priorities include continuing to regard the welfare of families at the centre of economic and social policy making. We intend to build on family tax and private health initiatives already announced, and on parenting education. Of course, we also announced towards the end of last year the launch of the pilot homeless projects, which are of particular relevance to many young Australians.
As I indicated during the election campaign and through all of last year, providing greater incentive and greater encouragement to small business lies very much at the heart of the government's economic plans. It remains the very strong view of the government that the area of greatest job generation, particularly for the young, is the small business sector. It is the small business sector which is the hope of the side so far as future employment is concerned. It is the small business sector that needs more incentive. It is the small business sector that will begin to feel the benefit of the recent reductions in interest rates. It is the small business sector that will benefit from the abolition from 1 January of the unfair dismissal law that was visited on the small business community by the former government.
From 1 July this year it will be possible for any man or woman in Australia running a small business who sells that business with proceeds of less than $5 million to invest those proceeds in another business, not necessarily a business of a like nature, without there being any capital gains tax liability. I remind the parliament of what was said by the
Business Review Weekly
. Managing editor Robert Gottliebsen said that this particular announcement was the most important corporate tax reform for 30 years because what it will do from 1 July this year is transform the landscape for the operation of small business in Australia.
I am very happy to remind the House that the mid-year review supported the projections
of growth made at the time of the budget—growth of 3½ per cent, which is amongst the highest in the OECD area. We now have inflation at levels that were not experienced in Australia after the OPEC oil shock in the early 1970s. We have presided over reductions in interest rates that have amounted to savings of $187 a month on an average home loan.
We will be announcing later this month the government's response to the small business deregulation task force, presided over by Mr Charlie Bell, and the measures to reduce red tape on small business will make a further contribution to boosting the incentives that are available to that sector. We will continue to build on the modern apprenticeship and traineeship scheme and the youth allowance schemes that have been announced in the first 11 months of the government being in office.
Another great goal of the government is a sustainable future for rural and regional Australia. I am very happy to remind the House of the benefits to rural and regional Australia of the passage of the Telstra sale legislation—legislation that was opposed by the Australian Labor Party and opposed by the Australian Democrats. They fought tooth and nail not only to stop this massive injection of money into regional Australia and the consequent creation of jobs in regional Australia, but they also fought tenaciously to stop the largest ever capital investment in the environmental future of Australia.
Further initiatives for regional and rural areas of Australia will flow from the work of the Supermarket to Asia Council, which brings together senior ministers and industry leaders. I say to the House on this first day that the House sits in 1997 that overwhelmingly and without qualification the priorities of this government will continue to be to help families, to boost job opportunities, particularly for young Australians, to boost small business as the engine room of job creation, and to build a sustainable future for rural and regional Australia.
Retail Trade Figures
Mr GARETH EVANS
—My question is to the Treasurer. Has the Treasurer seen today's
retail trade figures which show an alarming further decline in retail sales over the Christmas period? Do you agree that this result is very bad for jobs and growth? What are you going to do to get Australians confident enough to be spending again, and generating jobs by doing so?
Mr COSTELLO
—The answer to the first question is yes. In relation to retail trade figures, as I indicated in the mid-year review, the government has revised down its estimates in relation to consumption and revised up its estimates in relation to investment. The government stands by the growth forecast of 3½ per cent, so the retail trade figures are in line with those expectations.
What does the government propose to do to encourage an environment for retail sales? As the Prime Minister has just indicated, nothing a government can do can put more disposable income into the hands of the Australian public more than the reduction of home mortgage rates—nothing.
Mr Beazley
—Do you agree that—
Mr COSTELLO
—I will come to your proposal for a wage rise in a moment.
Mr Beazley
—Oh, good.
Mr COSTELLO
—Your last gasp strategy to try to knock inflation up, to try to deny the opportunity for interest rate reductions—the Australian Labor Party down in front of the Industrial Relations Commission with its last gasp strategy to try to deny interest rate reductions. As I said earlier, nothing that a government can do can put more disposable income into the hands of buyers than reductions in interest rates.
As the Prime Minister said, we are talking about interest rate reductions, not only as a result of official rate cuts but also as a result of competition, which have delivered $188 a month on the average Australian mortgage—$188 a month after tax income in the hands of Australian mortgage holders. We are now at a time when the standard variable mortgage rate is the lowest since June 1974, since the Labor Party in a previous incarnation got to wrecking the economy in the Whitlam government phase.
Some of those interest rate reductions that have come on stream were only passed on in the last week by some of the banks. I have already expressed to the House my own view that banks ought to be passing on to home buyers reductions in official interest rates with the same alacrity that they pass on the rises in official rates. The benefits of some of those reductions were only passed on in the last week, but that benefit of $188 per month over future months puts back disposable income into the hands of Australian families, together with the family policy that the Prime Minister has already indicated, providing through the years strong and solid growth as forecast in the mid-year review.
Mr GARETH EVANS
—Mr Speaker, I ask a supplementary question. Further to the Treasurer's answer, what proportion of banks pass on interest rate reductions in the form of increased disposable income and how many pass it on simply in terms of reduced mortgage terms?
Mr SPEAKER
—The question is in order.
Mr COSTELLO
—I was not aware you were going to allow it, Mr Speaker, but I am always happy to oblige the member for Holt. I do not have the specific amounts in front of me but it is an obvious point. When interest rates are raised those banks that extend the term of the mortgage generally bring the term of the mortgage back when they are lowered. So the advantage in relation to the people who had their mortgages extended when, under Labor, interest rates were rising is that they have a shorter life than they would have had, had your high monetary policy stayed in place. It has been a matter of great success for this government to be able to unwind the tightening of monetary policy presided over by the Labor Party at the end of 1994.
I must say that we always take great interest in the fact that when the member for Holt comes in every morning to the parliament and they ask him what should be done he always says, `Interest rates should be cut.' The dollar has gone up—interest rates should be cut. The dollar has gone down—interest rates should be cut. The deficit has blown out—interest rates should be cut. The only thing you were never doing was following that prescription
when you were in office, when you actually had some influence over monetary policy back at the end of 1994. All of these prescriptions apparently did not apply then.
We now have a government that is prepared to face the big issues, to take the tough decisions, to get the benefits for the Australian public—and what do they say? They have suddenly discovered the virtue of it, after all of this time. We said that by attacking the deficit, by eschewing the path of deficit and debt that Labor had put in place, we could deliver benefits to Australian families; and nothing makes the government prouder than to be able to do that.
Forestry
Mr BROADBENT
—My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. Is it a fact that it was promised by the coalition that the regional forest agreement, which the Prime Minister signed yesterday, represents a win for both sides, jobs in regional Australia and the environment? What are the ramifications of this historic agreement for the people in East Gippsland and particularly for the people in my electorate of McMillan?
Mr HOWARD
—Mr Speaker, the agreement that was signed yesterday by the Victorian Premier and me is, in fact, a very adequate reflection of the goals and the priorities of the government that I am very proud to lead. What it does, first and foremost, is create 400 new jobs in regional Australia, and the response of the Australian Labor Party has been not to support the arrangement but to attack it.
Mr O'Connor
—You have destroyed that number in Geelong alone.
Mr SPEAKER
—Order! The member for Corio!
Mr O'Connor
—Oh yes, Mr Speaker, but the fact is that he has knocked off 400 jobs in my electorate alone.
Mr SPEAKER
—I warn the member for Corio.
Mr HOWARD
—The shadow minister for the environment has put out a news release saying that there should have been even more areas set aside for reserves. In other words,
she wants fewer jobs in regional Australia. It would seem that the values of the Labor Party in relation to jobs has not altered since March of last year.
This agreement will attract a $140 million boost in investment to regional Australia. It will be particularly attractive to small business. It will, as I said, provide 400 new jobs in regional Australia. It will bring greater certainty. It does achieve a balance between a concern for the environment and providing a stable climate for the timber industry. I know that there are many members of the Australian Labor Party, particularly those who have some lingering connection with rural and regional Australia—and there are not too many of them—who know deep down that this is a very good agreement.
I notice that the new member for Blaxland is nodding his head. He thinks it is a very good agreement. I thank the member for Blaxland for the contribution that he is making towards a bipartisan policy. What we need to get jobs generated in this country is a bit of bipartisan investment policy. That is what we want. We want people working together in order to attract investment in regional Australia.
This agreement will endure for 20 years. It provides first‐class security for the industry. It ensures that the nationally agreed criteria on care for the environment are matched or exceeded in every area. In other words, it is a win‐win agreement. It is a reflection of the high store we place on environmental values but, above everything else, it is an agreement that will generate investment in small business and generate jobs in regional Australia and they are the goals, they are the priorities, they are the values of the government I am proud to lead.
Unemployment
Mr GARETH EVANS
—My question is directed to the Prime Minister. How can the Prime Minister talk of there being a `rare conjunction of positive circumstances' in the economy at the moment when unemployment is up, youth unemployment is up, growth is down compared with our last three years, and retail trade, including very much in the small
business sector, is alarmingly down? Are the 800,000 Australians out of work part of your `contented community' or can't you see them from Kirribilli?
Honourable members interjecting
—
Mr SPEAKER
—Order! Members on my right! There will be no exchanges across the chamber.
Mr HOWARD
—I say in reply to the Deputy Leader of the Opposition that the circumstances of which I spoke last Friday and of which I speak again today are as follows—and I think they do represent a very legitimate proposition: that the conditions at the moment in the Australian economy do provide a `rare conjunction of circumstances' that should make us feel optimistic rather than pessimistic. That is not to say, as I acknowledged in the speech I made last Friday, as you know, that we do not regard the level of unemployment in this country as being quite unacceptable. But I have to make the point, as I made last Friday, that, when you have had a group of people who have been in charge of the government for 13 years, they push unemployment to a level of 11 per cent, they leave us with 8½ per cent and, after we have been in office only 11 months, they have the audacity to bang the table and say, `How outrageous; why haven't you fixed it?' it is not surprising that there are a large number of people in Australia who do not take them seriously.
Let me say something of the circumstances. The first of the circumstances of which I spoke is the relative strengths of the world economy, and that has been testified to not by people on this side of the House, not by people on your side of the House, but by those who normally make pronouncements on those things and whose views in the past you, ad nauseam, had quoted in support of your propositions when you were in government. I talk of organisations like the OECD and the IMF. So that is strike No. 1 for the proposition that I made.
Strike No. 2 is that we have one of the best business investment climates in this country for 25 or 30 years. Why do I argue that? It is because we have a very low level of inflation. When you have had a mid‐year review that
says that the underlying rate of inflation is going to be one per cent—it is actually going to be lower than what was forecast at the time of the budget—when you have the same mid‐year review that has revised upward the business investment figures rather than revising them down; when you have seen an improvement, albeit not as dramatic as we would like, in the balance of payments situation; when you have the passage through the parliament of legislation that will provide much needed freedom to the labour market; when you have a government that is committed to a charter of budget honesty that will bring a new level of transparency to the public accounts of this country; when you have a Reserve Bank which is operating with its proper commitments not only to keeping inflation down but also to generating an appropriate climate for the generation of jobs in this country; when you have a government that is committed to a real future for rural and regional Australia, is it any wonder against that background, that I should credibly argue, as I did last Friday, and I do again today, recognising that the present level of unemployment is too high, knowing that it is a level of unemployment we inherited from you?
Mr Kelvin Thomson
—What is your target?
Mr HOWARD
—We inherited from you an unacceptably high level of unemployment. You exceeded that 8½ per cent when you were in government, with 11 or 12 per cent. The highest level since the Great Depression was the supreme achievement of the present Leader of the Opposition.
I say again to those opposite and to the Australian people that it really is the height of political impertinence for the group of people who ran this country for 13 years, who drove it into the ground and who gave us the highest level of unemployment since the Great Depression to have the nerve, after we have been in office for 11 months, to bang the table and say, `How outrageous! You haven't fixed the problem that we progressively made worse over 13 years.'
Constitutional Convention
Mr GEORGIOU
—My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. What action is the government taking to fulfil its election promise to enable Australians to have a say in the careful consideration of the Australian constitution? What is the next step in the process?
Mr HOWARD
—I can inform the House that it is the intention of the government, as promised during the election campaign, to hold a constitutional convention. This constitutional convention will be held in November or December of this year. As promised during the election campaign, half of the delegates to the convention will be appointed by the government, which will include an appropriate proportion of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people and young people between the ages of 18 and 24.
The elected people, which will comprise the other half, will be elected by a voluntary popular ballot. It is the disposition of the government at this stage that that ballot be conducted by post, although the details of that are part of the ongoing investigations.
It is the intention of the government that the convention be held in Canberra. It will probably be held in the old Parliament House. The agenda will include issues other than the head of state, but, as I indicated before the election as part of our policy, it will be our intention to ensure that the head of state issue is dealt with separately and first and is not allowed to be sidetracked or held back by considerations of other issues.
It will also be the intention of the government before the ballot for the delegates takes place to initiate and conduct a balanced public information campaign. The information that will be disseminated by the government will be compiled in part in consultation with different groups in the community who hold varying points of view. That material will include arguments for and against the existing constitutional arrangements for a head of state as well as arguments discussing the various republican alternatives.
I say to the House and, through the House, to the Australian people that I and the mem
bers of the government do not regard this issue as being of anywhere near the importance of the other issues that have been the subject of question and comment in the House so far during question time. Nonetheless, we acknowledge very firmly and very forthrightly the commitment that was made before the last election.
As members of the parliament will know, I am certainly not Australia's leading republican. It is something that I have never sought to disguise from the Australian people. I was elected Prime Minister of Australia by the Australian people in their full knowledge of my views on that subject and on the full basis of a commitment I made, which I am happy to say today is going to be honoured in full. Like all of the other great commitments that were made by me before the election, this one is going to be honoured in full. I know that will be a source of enormous disappointment to those who sit opposite, but it is going to be honoured in full.
There are three quite serious points I would like to make to the parliament before I resume my seat. The first of those is that it does remain very much my view and the view of many in the Australian community that the existing constitution that Australia has has worked very effectively and has played a very significant role in delivering stable government to this country. It has played a significant role in the fact that Australia is one of only eight nations to remain continuously democratic through the whole of the 20th century. I do not believe that any republican system of government can deliver more stable or more effective government than can the present constitution. In other words, I do not believe that the present system of government is flawed.
Rather, it remains the case that a significant number of Australians, which I recognise includes not only many people in the Australian Labor Party but also a significant number of people in the Liberal Party and in the National Party—in other words, it is a view which has considerable currency in the Australian community—hold the view that there are aspects of the symbols associated with the
present system which are no longer as relevant as they used to be.
The first of the other two observations I would make is that it is very important that this issue not be allowed to create unnecessary division in the Australian community. I would encourage all of those who will no doubt engage themselves in this debate not to form a monopoly of Australian nationalism on one or other side of the argument. There will be passionate Australians arguing all points of view.
I think the convention is the right vehicle to discuss this matter. It will not be an issue that is going to consume our side of politics to the exclusion of other issues. I say once again that I am very proud of the fact that the commitment we made on this issue is being honoured.
When all the other details related to the election of the delegates to the convention and many of the other things associated with the convention have been decided by the government, I will make a more formal and lengthy statement to the parliament. There will be plenty of opportunity for all members of the parliament to debate that, but I felt the parliament was owed advice from me as to the state of the government's thinking.
I confirm without qualification that the promise we made on this will be honoured in full. As I said before the election, the Australian people, whose decision alone it ultimately is as to whether or not we change our system of government will, as I promised—to the opposition's great disappointment—be involved at the beginning, at the middle and at the end of this deliberative process.
Small Business
Mr ROCHER
—Has the Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs had a full count taken of all government regulations affecting small businesses? If so, what is the number of such regulations? If not, how will the minister know when those regulations have been halved, as promised?
Mr PROSSER
—I thank the member for Curtin for his question. The government takes very seriously its initiative to reduce the red tape compliance on small business. As the
Prime Minister just said, small business is the engine room of the Australian economy.
The regulations and compliance that the member refers to cover not only the Commonwealth but many of the state and local government areas. The survey
Time for business
that we had carried out by the Yellow Pages identified the time taken to comply with regulations. They found that, on average, it took small business four hours to comply with the government red tape, and they put a cost figure on that as well.
The member may be aware that the Small Business Coalition have set up a committee to monitor the government's performance and commitment in this particular area. So we are committed to reducing it by 50 per cent, and we will deliver on that aspect. We have in place the benchmark to be able to give not only this House but the small business sector the measurement of our achievement in this area.
Interest Rates
Mrs ELSON
—My question is addressed to the Treasurer. Can the Treasurer advise the House as to the benefits for small businesses and home buyers of fiscal responsibility and the fostering of competition in the financial services industry? Can the Treasurer also inform the House of any recent movement in mortgage interest rates?
Mr Bevis
—Let's get physical.
Mr SPEAKER
—Order! We will all get physical in a minute. There are too many jocular asides in the chamber. This is day one of what is probably going to be a reasonably tough year. Let us get on with question time.
Mr COSTELLO
—I thank the honourable member for Forde for her question. Official interest rates were cut by half a percentage point on 31 July 1996, on 6 November 1996 and on 11 December 1996. In June 1996, as a result of new entrants in the home loan mortgage market, there was a three‐quarter of a per cent reduction in margins; that is, not related to official interest rates. As the Prime Minister has already said, cumulative cuts over the course of last year of 2¼ per cent on standard variable mortgage rates delivered
$188 per month to the average Australian on the average mortgage.
Work done by the Reserve Bank also shows that in relation to small businesses, both on variable rates and on three-year fixed rate loans, the 1½ per cent three official cuts in interest rates have been passed on in the indicator rates offered by the banks. In relation to variable rates, there have been reductions from 11.25 to 9.75 per cent and, in relation to fixed three-year rates, there have been reductions from 10.1 to 8.5 per cent.
Having said that, I think it is important, particularly for small businesses, that they do see their banks and that they do negotiate with their banks to ensure that they get the benefit of those cuts in official rates. The government is not working on lowering interest rates for the benefit of banks but for the benefit of borrowers. I would urge small business people to take advantage of the reductions in those rates and go back and renegotiate terms with the banks to ensure that they get the full benefit of those reductions.
We are now witnessing a new round of competition induced reductions in interest rates. We have seen in recent times a new product being offered by the Professionals—a group of real estate agents which is now offering rates below the seven per cent level. Just yesterday the ANZ announced in relation to its no‐frills money saver home loan that the loan rate has gone to 6.95 per cent. One of the newspapers remarked today that these could be the lowest home rates since the 1960s: the standard variable rate back at what it was—
Mr Wilton
—And look at retail spending—it is down.
Mr SPEAKER
—I warn the member for Isaacs.
Mr COSTELLO
—The standard variable rate is back at what it was—the lowest since June 1974—and no‐frills rates are as low as the 1960s.
I would encourage small business people to take full benefit of those opportunities; to make sure that their banks and financial institutions have passed on, and have passed
on in full, the benefit of those reductions in rates; to shop around; and to use competition to work for them in relation to the new players coming into the market and the new opportunities that they represent.
Diesel Fuel Rebate
Mr CREAN
—My question is directed to the Prime Minister. I refer the Prime Minister to the fact that he has ruled out further cuts to the diesel fuel rebate in the forthcoming budget on the grounds that policy areas significantly cut in last year's budget would be exempt from the new round of cuts. Prime Minister, if the 6.9 per cent cut from the diesel fuel rebate is regarded as significant, will you rule out further cuts to research and development, which was cut by 19 per cent in last year's budget?
Mr HOWARD
—I refer the member for Hotham to the statement made by the Treasurer earlier in question time.
Inflation
Mr REID
—I address my question to the Treasurer. Can the Treasurer explain to the House the significance of the new low inflation environment now being experienced in Australia? How will this promote sustainable growth and jobs creation?
Mr COSTELLO
—I thank the honourable member for Bendigo for his question. The release of the December quarter CPI figures shows that Australia has now decisively entered the low inflation league of the world. The results of the December quarter show that the all groups CPI rose by 0.2 per cent, for an annual rate of 1.5 per cent and, according to the Treasury underlying rate of inflation in the December quarter, in through the year terms, 2.1 per cent. That is at the lower end of the target which this government has set in the conduct of monetary policy, by agreement between the government and the Reserve Bank.
The benefit of that policy—which this government put in place to ensure a reduction in long‐term interest rates—can be seen in the fact that the differential between the US long‐term bond rate and the Australian long‐term bond rate has shaved about 150 basis points,
and now the margin has recently been under 100 basis points.
Sustained low inflation is important for investment and for investment expectations in the Australian economy. High inflation tends to redirect investment into asset inflation, where people take short‐term decisions to try and make short‐term gains. A low inflation rate means that business can invest and, as a consequence, the government has recently, in its mid‐year forecast, revised business investment up to 17 per cent.
What we now have is a low inflation, high investment economy. High long‐term investment is the kind of investment that is going to bring growth and job opportunities for Australians.
I do want to concentrate on one of the other benefits of low inflation. Low inflation protects people who live off savings. Many people who live off savings will be saying that in a low interest rate climate, they are not getting the kind of interest rate returns which they are used to and which they require in relation to living requirements. But low inflation does ultimately and directly help savers. It helps them in two ways: one, prices don't move against savers. That means they don't have to try and get those types of rates of return. Secondly, it preserves the value of their savings. On a 10 per cent inflation rate, the capital value of a person's savings would halve within six or seven years. On a one per cent inflation rate, that person can be assured that the value of their savings will hold up over their lifetime.
So this is a climate which is right for saving. The government wants to encourage people to save. The government has put in place, and intends to keep in place, a low inflation climate which is conducive towards that and its savings which will be so important to investment and growth and job‐creating opportunities in the future.
Transport Industry
Mr McMULLAN
—My question is to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Why does the minister consider that he is better placed to assess the value of changed work practices in the transport industry than employers who
support more flexible working hours, for example, with regard to work on Saturdays, in return for an 11 per cent wage increase?
Why does the minister believe a $42 per week wage increase for a truck driver on $406 per week, who has had no increase other than safety net increases since 1991, is excessive? What ever happened to better pay for better work?
Mr REITH
—The government has quite a clear view about the way in which you proceed to ensure that people have the chance of earning more and, in fact, I am glad you recited the title of our policy, because I think that really sums up the direction in which we want to see the system go, and that is, we want better pay for better work. The way in which you achieve that is you give people the opportunity to sit down at work and say, `As the employer, as an employee, how can we, at our business, run our business or change our organisation so that we run more efficiently; so that we can provide the productivity that can assure people that when they get a pay rise, it is backed up with a productivity gain so it is a sustainable, real increase in wages?'
The interesting thing behind this question is that it betrays your real view about labour market reform. Your real view about labour market reform is—for all your talk about reform—that you want to return to a centralised system where wage increases bear no relationship whatsoever to the productivity of the enterprises concerned. The consequence of that is there for us all to see over the last 13 years. And I will tell you who cops it the most: those that you claim to be most concerned about. Those who are disadvantaged, those who are low income earners and, on top of that, those who are unemployed.
Our policy is better pay for better work. The way you achieve that is to encourage people at work to sit down and do deals to suit their businesses. I will tell you what has happened in the transport industry. There are some major employers who are supporting this wage increase. Not only are they supporting this wage increase, but they are paying this wage increase already. Their intention is to go down with the union to the commission
and seek a general, across‐the‐board wage increase so as to impose the costs which they are now paying onto other businesses, many of whom are small businesses, regardless of whether or not those businesses can afford it. And rather than those businesses being then able to employ more people or to provide their services with greater productivity and more jobs, the reality is that you actually threaten the jobs of the very people you claim to be concerned about. Not only do you deny people the opportunity of wage increases based on real productivity, you also set up—through a centralised arrangement—inflationary price pressures which will have an impact right across the economy.
Mr O'Keefe interjecting
—
Mr SPEAKER
—I warn the member for Burke.
Mr REITH
—And don't tell us your concern for regional Australia, when in your support for this application you are in fact supporting and proposing an inflationary price increase which will be imposed right across regional Australia—families in regional Australia who are not in a position to withstand the inflationary burst that would arise as a result of that.
In fact, your question again demonstrates for all to see that you want to return to the bad old days. You do not want a system genuinely based on productivity increases depending on the circumstances of individual businesses. You are backing some of those bigger employers who have done deals which they have been able to pass on in price increases. But they now want to impose their cost structures on their competitors. There are two things that this government stands for—two things that are very clear as we go to the commission on this particular case. The first thing is that we want higher pay for low paid workers. But we want the increases to be sustainable increases, not increases which are taken out of their pockets through inflationary price hikes. The second thing is that we are pro‐small business. We are not prepared to sit back idly and allow a deal done by a few big employers with the unions to impose a series of cost increases on small employers which is going to make it even more difficult for them
to stay in business and to provide jobs for ordinary Australians.
Queensland Floods
Mr KATTER
—My question is addressed to the Minister for Defence. Media reports suggest that the floods in the Charleville area today will affect up to 600 homes and their occupants. Can the minister provide a positive response to requests made by the SES and the Minister for Veterans' Affairs for urgently needed assistance which probably can only be supplied by the Australian Defence Force? Can he supply such assistance to Blackwall and remote stations and settlements on the Barcoo and Warrego rivers as and when required?
Mr McLACHLAN
—I thank the member for Kennedy for his question. The fact is that the flood situation in the Charleville area has already resulted in the evacuation of some 240 people as the Warrego River continues to rise. The main highway and the railway to Charleville have been cut off by the floodwaters. The Queensland government has declared Charleville a disaster area. It has also formally requested the Commonwealth to assist.
To that end, we have already sent a Hercules C130 up there with a number of 20‐person tents and a large number of camp stretchers and blankets. I am told that that aeroplane arrived on the strip, which is still open, at just after 2 o'clock. The second C130 will be taking up a field kitchen—which will provide upwards of 3,000 meals a day for the next three days at least—and, upon request, possibly emergency clothing, generators and chemical toilets.
In answer to the second part of your question, I simply say that we react to the requests as they come through Emergency Management Australia. If it gets worse and the floodwaters go up, then we will react appropriately in the outlying areas.
Workplace Relations Legislation
Mr McMULLAN
—My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Is the minister aware of the briefings by the Treasurer's staff and close associates suggest
ing that your Workplace Relations Act does not go far enough? When will the minister decide whether his industrial relations changes have been sufficient? Against what outcomes or benchmarks will you make that judgment? Will you recommit yourself to there being no second wave of amendments to the industrial relations legislation—in fact, to there being not even a second ripple?
Mr REITH
—Most members on this side have had a good holiday. I must say that it is a pity that some on the other side did not take the opportunity to refresh their batteries and recharge them for the new session. Their tactics committee seems to have fallen into the predictable behaviour which we had from them last year. As I have said on many occasions when I have been asked this question whether or not there would be a second wave to our reforms, the answer is no, there is no second wave. I have always made that clear. I have made it clear in the context that this is an evolutionary process. What we saw last year was a very significant stride in the development of a much more efficient labour market—a labour market which will provide people with a lot of opportunities denied them when Labor was in office.
In terms of that evolution of the labour market reforms which we propose, this is certainly an important year. What we now face in the next 12 months and in the times ahead is the opportunity for a lot of employers and employees to take advantage of some of these changes so as to introduce work practices which can underpin higher and better productivity and, ultimately, higher wages. That, of course, narks and irritates the Labor Party. The truth of the matter is that in your 13 years the one thing you were not able to deliver was a labour market which provided people with both the opportunity of higher wage increases and the jobs to go with them.
To the extent that the question asks what the government's policy is, the answer is clear. Our policy has been enacted. We are in the business of implementing our policy. It also raises the question—
Mr Beazley
—But Costello's view is totally different.
Mr REITH
—Our policy is there for all to see. Our policy is an open book. What about Labor's policy? Where is the Labor Party's policy? There is a lot of confusion on their side about what the relationship with the ACTU will be between now and the next election. I do not think there is any doubt it will be a very close relationship. It will be a continuation of the relationship of the last 13 years, when basically the ACTU wrote your policy for you. So good at it were they that they have now got a few ex‐ACTU presidents in here to make sure that you continue with ACTU policy as dictated to you from Swanston Street. The reality is that our policy is an open book. You have got a secret policy. Your problem is that the ACTU have yet to tell you exactly what it is. We look forward to seeing it this year.
Trade Union Movement
Mr McARTHUR
—My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Can the minister inform the House of any new statistics on the decline in trade union representation in the work force? What are the implications of the statistics for the future of the trade union movement?
Mr REITH
—I thank the member for Corangamite. This is an excellent question and I do appreciate the opportunity to answer it. I must say that, just by chance, someone did draw to my attention certain figures released by the ABS yesterday which do confirm the struggle which many unions face to maintain their relevance to Australian employees.
The percentage of employees belonging to unions dropped by almost two percentage points in the 12 months between August 1995 and August 1996. That does continue a trend which we saw under Labor in the last 10 to 15 years. If you look over the last 10 years, the percentage of employees belonging to unions has dropped from 46 per cent to 31 per cent. In the private sector now, less than one in four employees belong to a union. On these figures, in some industry areas only almost one in 10 belong to a union.
This government has replaced the old union monopoly with a framework in which unions
must become genuinely competitive so that only unions which are genuinely representative and accountable to their members will survive. As Jennie George, the President of the ACTU, has admitted, some unions have not adequately serviced their members and unions will need to do a lot better to meet the various demands and needs of their employees. A relevant fact in this is that, as from 1 January, under the government's new Workplace Relations Act, the circumstances and the choice facing Australian employees are now much freer than they ever faced under Labor. In fact, if you are—and many Australians have been—compelled to join a union, you now have a new choice, a new opportunity, and that is that if you do not want to be in a union you do not have to be in a union.
We have provided very simple means for those who are in a union and do not wish to remain in a union: under the new Workplace Relations Act, they merely have to give two weeks written notice to their union so as to comply with the resignation requirements of the new act; and, provided that people also advise their employers of their decision, they can require an employer to desist from making payroll deductions.
Whilst it is very early days—the new act has been in place in that regard only since 1 January—I was rather intrigued by what I call the barbecue test where one person informed me that one enterprising young person working for a major retailer in Melbourne took it upon himself to stand outside the main entrance of this particular establishment and was handing out a pamphlet. The pamphlet read simply: `Would you like a $4 a week pay increase?' Then it followed with advice on how you resign from the shoppies union.
This government believes that if you want to be in a union you are entitled to be in a union, and if you want to be in a union we will protect your right to be in a union; but if you do not want to be in a union we have given you an easy way out, and we will protect that right as well.
Petrol Prices
Mr LATHAM
—My question is directed to the Treasurer. Has the Treasurer recently
received correspondence from the Managing Director of BP Australia with regard to the government's plans for the petrol industry? The letter from Mr McGimpsey states:
The Government's plan will not lead to lower prices. There is now a strong expectation in the public's mind that there will be reductions in the price of petrol. We do not share this expectation and believe it raises false hopes.
What action will the government now take to fulfil its big election promise to achieve lower petrol prices, especially given the 2.7 per cent CPI increase for the December quarter and the petrol price hikes through the recent holiday season?
Mr COSTELLO
—I am aware of that letter, because that letter was put out by the member for Werriwa during the silly season. What I was even more aware of was when BP came out and said that the member for Werriwa, with the claims that he was making, was behaving irresponsibly and urged the Labor Party to support the government's policy. I must say that we quite like the member for Werriwa. He is proving to be quite a little vote earner for us with all of the comments that he made.
Mr Beazley
—He seemed to do all right over summer!
Mr COSTELLO
—The Leader of the Opposition just interjected because he is a bit of a hot‐shot on petrol pricing too. He got on the Howard Satler program on Wednesday, 29 January and he said that the inflation result apparently was not all that good a result; it was only at 1.5 per cent. But he said:
Let me tell you what went up. What went up was health care costs and petrol costs. That's what went up—
so that was against those two items—
and guess who stuck them up? They have deregulated petrol prices and petrol prices went up.
That is what he said in relation to the December consumer price index. The December consumer prices related to the months of October, November and December. Did we deregulate petrol prices in October? No. Did we deregulate petrol prices in November? No. Did we deregulate petrol prices in December? No. We have not done it yet. You are out complaining that a policy that has not been
implemented has jacked up prices—precisely the point that BP made against the member for Werriwa.
