This is the most extraordinary proposition. We said that by June of this year we would deregulate petrol prices once the oil companies had given undertakings. We have not done it, yet they are all out there busily saying, `Look, petrol prices have gone up.' They have gone up under your policy. I could not believe it. It might have been early in the morning in Perth, but if you are going to get your information from the member for Werriwa you are bound to mislead. In his case it is knowing; in yours it is unintentional. Just make sure that you do not try it again.
We have said that we will be deregulating petrol prices after the oil industry has given the undertakings; that we are negotiating those undertakings at the moment; and that, in accordance with the ACCC recommendation, developments in the market in relation to imports have to continue. We saw during the silly season the silly spokesman out making a silly fool of himself. That is the answer, Mr Speaker.
Government members
—Come on, Mark; a supplementary!
Mr SPEAKER
—Order! Members on my right!
Wheat
Mr WAKELIN
—My question is directed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. The Australian wheat industry is very important to the prosperity of the rural sector, to regional and metropolitan communities, to the food needs of this country, to the export effort and of course to the national economy. An all‐time record harvest of 23 million tonnes has just been completed, which is good news for Australia. Could the minister explain the significance of the wheat industry to Australia's national wellbeing?
Mr ANDERSON
—I thank the honourable member for his question. As a matter of fact, this is Outlook Week 97 in Canberra—it is being sponsored by ABARE—and it really serves as a timely opportunity to remind ourselves of the importance of agriculture, fishing, forestry and mining to the Australian
economy. In fact, these industries combined—very important for a trading nation like Australia—represent over 60 per cent of our total export wealth. Agriculture, of which some 77 per cent of production is exported today, accounts for about 23 per cent of our total export income. It is a timely point at which to consider the important role of the wheat industry in that scenario.
The Australian wheat industry is a major exporter and indeed we are a major player on grain markets globally. In fact last year, in the drought recovery year, we saw production rise very substantially to 17.2 million tonnes, worth about $4½ billion to the national economy. But this year we have seen a record production of 23 million tonnes for Australia. That is a remarkable performance, particularly when you think of the damage that has been done to the industry in recent years by drought, by extraordinary volatility in world grain prices and by the economic pressures that resulted from the sort of mismanagement that you people opposite were responsible for during the 1980s and the early 1990s.
Despite those problems, the nation's grain farmers have boosted production to record levels, particularly in relation to wheat, and they have increased their average individual turnover by 1.5 per cent per annum in recent years—a testimony to their resilience, to their innovation, to the value of research and development, and to their capacity to keep going under conditions that most Australians would just walk away from. They have made a great contribution to the benefit not just of themselves but of the nation at large.
Those of you who had a look at last week's very significant turnaround in the figures for the trade balance between November and December last year will have seen that the greatest contributor by far was in fact the wheat industry, with a very heavy shipping program. That shipping program has continued through January with record figures—an outstanding result—and that promises more good figures for us in terms of our balance of trade.
It is worth noting too that the Australian Wheat Board, operating in a global environment of pretty heavy saturation of markets,
has been able to place such a very high percentage of such a huge crop, including, as it has done so, opening up new markets such as India.
Child Care
Ms MACKLIN
—My question is addressed to the Minister for Family Services. I refer the minister to her answer in this House on 12 December, when she claimed:
. . . in response to a letter from someone in Townsville recently who had been told that her child‐care fees will be raised by $56.44 per week, we took the opportunity to ring that parent. We ran through the figures with her. We found that her child-care fees would be raised by only 56c per week.
The minister also said:
I am not sure whether this is a deliberate attempt to mislead the Australian public or . . . wait for it, whether the member has put the decimal point in the wrong place.
Is it the case, Minister, that the woman in Townsville will in fact have to pay, according to her child-care centre's calculations, an additional $38.03 per week for her children's care? Will the minister now correct the record?
Mr Crean
—They protected you last time.
Mr SPEAKER
—I warn the member for Hotham.
Mrs MOYLAN
—I am pleased to have the opportunity to answer the shadow minister's question today. I have to say that at no time did I say that the member for Jagajaga wrote a letter.
Ms Macklin
—Thank you.
Mr Tim Fischer
—Just listen.
Mrs MOYLAN
—What I did say was that, in response to a letter from someone from Townsville recently who had been told that their child-care fees would be raised by $56.44c per week, we took the opportunity to ring that parent. Clearly I was referring to a letter received by my office in a matter that concerned a parent. I did not at any stage say that those particular figures were provided to the writer by the member for Jagajaga.
There was no intention to link the shadow minister with that letter, but I do accept that had my words been a little clearer perhaps
this issue would not have arisen. That my words were not so clear is in no small part due to the level of interjections by the other side during that answer. One only has to refer to the
Hansard
to make that very clear—that there was a very high level of interjection during the answering of that question.
However, the point I was making, from which I do not resile, is that Labor, under the guidance of the member for Jagajaga, has waged a deliberate and an irresponsible scare campaign aimed at frightening parents, particularly parents from low and medium income areas, into believing that they will be worse off because of this government's child-care measures.
Opposition members interjecting
—
Mr SPEAKER
—There is too much noise in the chamber.
Mrs MOYLAN
—The child-care measures announced in the budget are evidence of this government's commitment to delivering a more equitable and sustainable child-care system, and more particularly to ensuring that the government's support is directed to families most in need. Labor's only response has been an ill-informed scare campaign against the very Australian families whose interests they, the Labor Party, pretend to serve.
Education
Mr EOIN CAMERON
—Mr Speaker—
Mr SPEAKER
—I call the honourable member for Stirling.
Ms Macklin
—I have a supplementary question, Mr Speaker.
Mr SPEAKER
—I have called the honourable member for Stirling.
Mr EOIN CAMERON
—My question is addressed to the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training. As thousands of young Australians start school this week for the first time, I refer the minister to this government's initiatives in areas such as literacy and vocational education and training in schools, and I ask: what special benefits will be provided by the government's schools education reforms for those young Australians and their families?
Dr KEMP
—I thank the honourable member for Stirling for his question. The government's schools policies are a very important part of our approach to addressing the issue of unemployment of young people. One of the most tragic legacies of the previous government is the very high level of youth unemployment. It is very clear now that Labor abandoned those students most in need in schools.
We came to office to find that 30 per cent of 14‐year‐olds were unable to read adequately, that the reading standards of boys had declined over the last 20 years and that almost nothing had been done to make sure that the 65 per cent of students who are not going on to university or full-time TAFE had real options leading them to real jobs.
The government's policies are designed to make sure that young Australians obtain the fundamental skills of literacy and numeracy at the earliest moment in their schooling. It is the government's intention to build the links between businesses and schools in local communities so that students at school can acquire a practical understanding of the world outside school and get that sort of understanding that so many employers say is missing at present.
In fact, we launched the first school based traineeships in October last year, and there will be further announcements shortly. Our policies of choice are also opening the way for low fee schools, which will expand the options available to battling families, who have been denied choice throughout the period of the Labor government.
Mr Beazley interjecting
—
Dr KEMP
—In view of the Leader of the Opposition's interjection, the important point is quality of schooling for all young Australians, for the 70 per cent in government schools as well as the 30 per cent in non-government schools. Let me say quite clearly to this House that the government's schools policies are the best news that government schools have had for a very long time. It is estimated that government schools will obtain under these policies an additional $50 million this year from the states grants legislation. In addition to this, for the first time funds will
come from the budget for vocational education and training—$20 million a year directly into schools—to assist in the establishment of those school to work linkages which are so important.
Mr Crean
—We had that the first time. You are a fraud.
Dr KEMP
—Schools around the country are now setting up working parties with local businesses to rebuild the pathway from school into jobs, from youth into adulthood, for young Australians. The beginning of this school year has been marred by the opponents of choice, who have argued that the government's policies will run down government schools. This is in fact the opposite of the truth.
Mr Crean interjecting
—
Dr KEMP
—The truth is that—
Mr SPEAKER
—Order! The minister will resume his seat. I have extended enormous courtesies to the honourable member for Hotham this day. You have constantly ignored the advice. I invoke standing order 304A. Remove yourself from the chamber forthwith.
The honourable member for Hotham thereupon withdrew from the chamber.
Dr KEMP
—The policies of the government will, over the next three years, actually increase expenditure per student in government schools by 17 per cent, compared with an increase of 14 per cent for students in non-government schools. I reject totally the claim by those on the other side of the House and some of their fellow travellers that the government is taking money from government schools to expand new schools in the non-government sector. It is this kind of dishonest statement which helps to undermine confidence in government schools when in fact under the government's policies government schools have the best opportunity they have had for a very long time—
Mr Beazley
—Rubbish.
Dr KEMP
—To improve the quality of education that they are offering.
Mr Beazley
—Absolute rubbish! You just wait until the next election, sport.
Mr SPEAKER
—Order! The Leader of the Opposition!
Dr KEMP
—The Labor Party ran down government schools. Under their policy, the outflow from government to non-government schools actually sped up. Theirs is the ideology of the education cold war: government schools versus other schools. Our commitment is to quality education for all young Australians, to provide the battling families of this country with educational choice and to provide young Australians in schools, government and non-government, with the programs, the skills and the opportunities that will get them the jobs that your policies denied them.
Mr Howard
—Mr Speaker, I ask that further questions be placed on the
Notice Paper
.

MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
Petrol Prices
Mr SPEAKER
— I have received a letter from the honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Latham) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:
The government's failure to deliver on its promise of substantially lower petrol prices around Australia and narrowing the city‐country price differential.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the standing orders having risen in their places—
Mr LATHAM
(Werriwa)
(3.54 p.m.)
—The coalition had no bigger promise, no bolder promise, for the people of regional Australia than their promise to bring down petrol prices. We all know that it has not taken them 12 months to stop listening to the bush. They have stopped listening to regional Australia and, in particular, they have stopped listening to the complaints around regional Australia about the government's failure to deliver on that core promise.
For a government that has stopped listening, perhaps I could give them one little reminder—one little reminder that I noticed in a town in regional Australia. It was a letter that appeared in the
Daily Advertiser
in Leeton on 3 January. This is what one of the citizens of Leeton had to say to the coalition:
Remember before the federal election seeing our local member Noel Hicks standing beside a petrol bowser promising to reduce petrol prices by 5 cents per litre as soon as his government came to power? These statements were endorsed by his leader, Tim Fischer. Since these commitments, petrol prices have increased by at least 8 cents per litre in our area.
They promised to bring the prices down by 5c a litre and they have gone up by eight. So the coalition is out by 13c a litre. That adds up to tens of thousands of dollars for businesses in the bush, it adds up to tens of thousands of dollars for tourism operators, it adds up to tens of thousands of dollars for farmers and it adds up to thousands of dollars in the working family budget around regional Australia—all because of the betrayal of the coalition on this core election promise.
You hear some interesting stories throughout the month of January. One of the most amusing items to come out of the coalition ranks was the concept of truth in election advertising legislation. They were actually advancing the proposition of fining people who did not tell the truth at election time. I do not know if they were talking about core and non-core fines for core and non-core promises, but there is no doubt that government MPs would be paying their fines hand over fist as Australians pay more for their petrol.
What is the record of the coalition on petrol prices? What is the record on the key promise that they gave to the people of regional Australia? There was a 2.7 per cent increase in the December quarter CPI in petrol prices—a low inflation quarter except for petrol and the people in regional Australia paying the higher petrol prices. And just yesterday we were told that that CPI increase flows through into the Commonwealth excise. So here they are collecting another $20 million when they promised to bring prices down.
Mr McGauran
—How much is it?
Mr LATHAM
—So the Minister for Science and Technology, the member for Gippsland, shamed by the result in the state by-election, worried by the state by-election, can say that the prices are going up by a small amount, but he promised—just like the mem
ber for Riverina (Mr Hicks)—to bring the prices down by 5c and they have gone up by eight. So what you said was supposed to come down has in fact gone up. No wonder the people in regional Australia are exceptionally outraged and disappointed.
They are putting the $20 million revenue from the petrol excise into their coffers. We know they need revenue to fill their Costello crater, but it should not be revenue at the expense of election promises; it should not be revenue at the expense of regional Australia. The record was particularly damning throughout the holiday period. The prices went up just before Christmas. The petrol companies knew that Australians would be travelling more, so they decided to take advantage of the holiday habits of Australian families and put their prices up by between 2c and 5c per litre.
The price differential is another core promise of the coalition for regional Australia. They alone were going to lower the differential between city and country prices. We had the member for Gippsland tramping around Australia saying that he alone would narrow the differential.
Mr McGauran
—And we have.
Mr LATHAM
—He is claiming that he has. Is this narrowing Gippsland style? On 2 January, Brisbane had a price for unleaded petrol of 65.9c. In Cairns it was 8c more expensive, in Townsville it was 6c more expensive and in the mining town of Middlemount near Rockhampton it was a massive 13c more expensive. So that is narrowing Peter McGauran style—a 13c differential between the petrol prices in Brisbane and Central Queensland. Now the Minister for Science and Technology is actually starting to say that the prices did not go up that much over the Christmas period. That is not what he was saying on 7 January. Let me just read from the AAP wire:
Federal Science and Technology Minister, Peter McGauran yesterday also criticised petrol price rises during the holiday break saying that in some cases it was blatant exploitation.
It was blatant exploitation that he could not stop. He promised the price narrowing. He promised the price reductions for regional
Australia and all he could do during the holiday period was agree with ALP price watch on petrol by saying that prices have gone up and that there is blatant exploitation. He was putting up the white flag. The Jaffa was putting up the white flag of defeat. He could not do anything about the exploitation, so up went the white flag.
Of course, this large differential was repeated later in the month. Let us have a look at the figures for New South Wales. In Western Sydney on 23 January, unleaded petrol was as low as 73.9c. If you write the figures down, Minister, you will calculate that there was a 7c differential for Bathurst and Orange, and for Broken Hill it was as high as 10c per litre. If that is narrowing coalition style, no wonder the people in regional Australia are complaining about it.
Mr McGauran
—What is your source?
Mr LATHAM
—Here is someone saying the figures are made up. The minister is claiming the figures are made up. Obviously he has not read the press release from the New South Wales Farmers Association. Remember them? Farmers? People who work the land? Do you remember the farmers?
The New South Wales Farmers Association said that petrol prices around New South Wales had risen by 2c a litre just before Christmas. Here he is condemning the New South Wales Farmers Association. Let me read it to you. I know you do not have a lot of contact with the farmers now that you have got a ministerial office in Canberra, but the press release said:
Petrol prices around New South Wales rose by up to 2c a litre immediately before Christmas despite wholesale fuel prices remaining static, the New South Wales Farmers Association said.
That was on 20 January. Minister, you cannot deny these things. You said it and the Farmers Association said it. People all over the country have been complaining about the price exploitation that you owned up to, waving the white flag, and have done absolutely nothing to stop. Not only that, I see that the member for Indi (Mr Lieberman), the self‐styled head of the backbench committee on petrol prices, the hardest job in the government, was complaining about the price hikes
on 6 January. He said that if the petrol companies did not come into line the government would be passing special amendments to the Trade Practices Act—maybe the sort of thing I have got before the House by way of a private member's bill. Of course, he could not get too far with it because Mr McGauran refused to support Mr Lieberman's warning on the Trade Practices Act, saying that it was a long way from that. So poor old Jaffa, waving the white flag, saw the reinforcements coming over the hill and he waved them back because he thought the prices were narrowing. The Farmers Association, the member for Indi, government backbenchers, consumers and farmers all over Australia were saying those things.
A funny thing happened to the National Party on the way to the forum, on the way to their ministerial offices: they stopped listening to regional Australia. We all know, particularly in the Gippsland region, what it means when you stop listening. You do not need to take the word of ALP price watch on these things; the figures are very clear. The minister was saying it—until he was caught out badly and under pressure from the media—the member for Indi, the New South Wales Farmers Association, and on it went. What happened to the member for Gippsland—the minister—is that he went from being the gamekeeper to being the poacher. A few weeks later he actually joined the petrol companies; he actually became their hand puppet. Peter the Puppet McGauran is what the big petrol companies called him in Collins Street circles in Melbourne. They have got him dancing there like the Howdy Doody doll, dancing their tune. He is now saying in his press releases that he wants the big petrol companies to work with the coalition.
This is what he had to say about BP: that he `confirmed BP's support of the government's move to deregulation of the industry and its willingness to work with the coalition'. It is a funny thing that happened to the minister on the way to the forum—not listening to regional Australia and then cuddling up to the big petrol companies when it suited him. It is no good being a hand puppet for those companies, Minister, because the Na
tional Party needs to make a decision on petrol. The National Party needs to make a very important choice on petrol: do you take on the petrol companies and break up the integrated control of this industry? Do you try to get vertical separation and an active wholesale market to give farmers and people in the bush their chance to access cheaper wholesale petrol or do you cave in to the interests of the big petrol companies in Collins Street and do nothing about it? The National Party needs to work out pretty quickly on this matter whether they are simply Liberals in sheep's clothing or fair dinkum representatives of people in regional Australia.
The minister was saying that he wants to work with the petrol companies, but the truth is that they have absolutely sold him the dump. They have said to the government in correspondence last year—the correspondence I quoted in question time—that the government will not be able to keep its promise of lower petrol prices. This is what the head of BP Australia had to say, talking about the government's program:
This will not lead to lower prices. There is a strong expectation in the public's mind that there will be reductions in the price of petrol. We do not share this expectation and believe it raises false hopes.
Beyond that, the minister will undoubtedly say that he leant on BP Australia and they are now singing a different tune. Still, he cannot deny how the correspondence I have obtained from BP Australia says this: `Minister McGauran has said that the number of retail sites in Australia needs to decrease over time from around 9,000 today to about 6,000.' Have you been saying that to BP Australia, that you support wiping out 3,000—
Mr McGauran
—Where?
Mr LATHAM
—You have been saying it. You are on the record as saying that you are willing to wipe out 3,000 service station small businesses in regional Australia.
Mr McGauran
—So does Michael Delaney.
Mr LATHAM
—What Michael Delaney says is that you should be supporting a private member's bill that I have put before the House to open up an access regime on wholesale prices. You are setting up those service stations for very unfair competition.
Woolworths can get in for cheaper wholesale petrol and retail that around, undercutting the existing service station retailers in country Australia, but you are not willing to give the same access to the 9,000 service station small businesses that you claim to represent. Those 9,000 service stations should have the same opportunity as Woolworths to shop around for cheaper wholesale petrol.
So why don't you do what the member for Indi was supporting: changes to the Trade Practices Act to declare an access regime, more regulation on the petrol industry, not less, and break up the vertical integration so that you have an active wholesale market? You can actually do something constructive to bring down the prices. That is the measure that I have brought before the House in a private member's bill. The service station association has estimated that it has the potential to lower the price of petrol by 6c a litre. That estimate is supported by APADA—the Australian Petroleum Agents and Distributors Association. The industry is supporting the private member's bill that I have got before the House as the only feasible way in which petrol prices can come down.
Minister, for all your coalition supporters, dwindling as they may be, there is only one way to produce lower petrol prices: extra regulation, not the deregulation path that you are following, to actually break up the sort of control that the big petrol companies have been exercising in this industry for more than a century. You need to do a lot more than just write letters away to the petrol companies saying, `Can you do the right thing on access?' knowing full well that the petrol companies regard access as physical access only. They do not want to see any access that means competitive wholesale pricing. They are willing to adopt the status quo, all to placate a government that made a big promise and cannot do anything about it.
It is time for the National Party to deliver. It is time for the member for Riverina, who promised a price reduction of 5c a litre, to actually stand up in the House and deliver the goods—not an 8c a litre increase or the sorts of increases that you have identified over the holiday season. It is time also for the National
Party to introduce fair competition in this industry. You should be supporting changes to the Trade Practices Act to have an access regime, to make sure that there is an active wholesale market.
How unfair is it that someone can go to a Shell franchise service station today and actually be buying BP petrol—petrol that started out in a BP terminal—because the big companies are allowed to share their terminal product horizontally—that is, amongst themselves—but will not share the petrol with the retail sector, with the 9,000 service stations that want to shop around for cheaper wholesale prices? Unless there is an access regime, unless we have more regulation—not less—there is no opportunity for those 9,000 service stations to compete fairly.
The minister can talk about closing down 3,000 service station small businesses, but for the thousands of Australians who lose their jobs, for the hundreds of country towns that are much diminished in terms of investment and employment, it is an absolute tragedy. It is an absolute tragedy that the National Party has failed so comprehensively to deliver, in tandem with their coalition partners, on this core election promise.
I hope you do introduce the truth in advertising legislation because on this matter you will be paying plenty of fines, as Australians are paying more for their petrol. It is time for the National Party to decide. Are you just Liberals, dry and callous in sheep's clothing, or are you fair dinkum representatives of the bush who can actually deliver on the things you promise?
(Time expired)
Mr McGAURAN
(Gippsland—
Minister for Science and Technology)
(4.09 p.m.)
—Labor was in office between March 1983 and March 1996 and did not do a single thing—lift a single finger—to address this problem of petrol price differentials between country and urban centres. For you to now grandstand as you have in the parliament, as you did over the Christmas season when the B-team was mostly in charge of media outlets, reeks of political expediency and hypocrisy. Worse, you are deliberately cynical and misleading.
You do not get anything right. You make assertions. We will come to that in a moment
because I am going to ask you to make available the methodology by which you supposedly monitor petrol prices. Make it available to the ACCC so that we know where and how this price monitoring is occurring and by whom.
You attack the member for Riverina (Mr Hicks). I think most honourable members in the House would say that he is the most unlikely misrepresenter of political issues. He advises me—I accept it, as I am sure you will—that the photo you refer to in the claim that petrol prices would be reduced by 5c a litre was taken before the 1993 election, when we were to abolish petrol excise, all 28c a litre, and replace it with a GST. You cannot even get it right. Ian Sinclair was standing with him, not the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Tim Fischer), as you allege. But let us put that aside.
Let us look at the claims you made during your performance. When you have 8,500 petrol stations and 400 distributors, of course you are going to get examples of inexplicable price setting, even exploitation. Of course you are. The ACCC, the government and the oil companies themselves are not going to be at each and every petrol bowser.
Let us look at the overall facts, because you have been badly caught out. The ACCC, the independent umpire, has examined your claims and has assessed your price monitoring. You put out a press release on 5 January—prior to that you had announced this ALP Petrol Price Watch network—which stated:
This is the petrol price monitoring the Federal Government refuses to undertake with its plan for deregulation of the petrol industry.
No matter that we announced it at the election. No matter that the Treasurer (Mr Costello) announced it in September last year and that it was up and running from 1 January. You went on to say:
An ALP survey of service stations through eastern Australia has shown that petrol prices have increased by between 2 and 5 cents per litre since Christmas, with the highest increases in rural and regional centres.
That was a bluff. That was utterly misleading because, of course, you forgot that these
results could be assessed and judged by the ACCC. This is what the ACCC says about your press release, what it says about your dodgy price survey:
Claims of retail price increases between 2 and 5 cpl across Australia over the Christmas/New Year period are not substantiated . . .
It gets even better when it goes on:
Mr Latham's survey figures (where identified) are generally not consistent with established surveys and appear to lack rigour.
Let us go to some of the specific examples. The ACCC assessed prices for unleaded petrol in Sydney, Melbourne, Brisbane, Adelaide and Perth.
Mr Latham
—Why didn't they get out in the bush?
Mr McGAURAN
—I will come to the bush in a moment. The ACCC concluded:
.
there is no evidence of retail price increases over Christmas that were outside of continuing price cycles
.
in all cases the peaks of the Christmas cycles were no higher than those of the first cycles in December, plus the endorsed wholesale increases in mid December.
Let us turn to the rural areas and see how the ACCC assessed your misleading press release of 5 January. On 6 January the Melbourne
Herald‐Sun
quoted your price comparison between pre-Christmas and 2 January in which you allege there were increases in Bendigo of 1.7c per litre, in Ballarat of 2c per litre and in Horsham of 1c per litre. The RACV surveyed those same areas and recorded no net changes in these locations in the month to 2 January. When you have 8,500 service stations and there is no law against charging the highest price the market will pay, of course a lot of individuals through the pricing chain will take advantage of a captive market or heavy volume through their petrol bowsers.
Let us continue on because this gets better and better. In that same newspaper, the Warrnambool price was reported to have risen as `a price war in late December slashed petrol to 65 cpl only to be replaced by prices among the highest in the State'. Again, the RACV survey showed that prices here re
mained unchanged throughout December and early January.
Let us go on to that example you gave about North Queensland. The
Cairns Post
on 8 January, again feeding off your misleading press release—that is the politest way I can describe it—looked at survey dates of 2 December last year to 2 January. It was claimed in your press release that the Cairns price was 8c per litre higher than Brisbane and 2c per litre higher than pre‐Christmas prices. The RACQ survey showed no increase in the Cairns price of early December.
Let us move back to the retail prices in country Victoria. When are you going to make available for independent assessment, by either the motoring organisations or by the ACCC, the methodology? You are bluffing. You know very well there is no organised or systemic method of notifying these prices. You are purely plucking them out of the air to make political capital.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Nehl)
—Minister, the chair is not plucking anything from the air. I ask that you direct your remarks through the chair.
Mr Kerr
—The point I was seeking to make is that you are not bluffing.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Nehl)
—I am definitely not. The member for Werriwa might remember that, too.
Mr McGAURAN
—The member for Werriwa certainly is bluffing. Let us have a look at the prices in country Victoria. The daily survey data provided by the RACV show that of the 12 major centres—prices measured from 2 December to 3 January—there were no changes in Bairnsdale, Ballarat, Horsham, Mildura, Orbost, Sale, Traralgon or Warrnambool, and no net change in Bendigo. Increases occurred just prior to Christmas in Shepparton—
Mr Latham
—Oh!
Mr McGAURAN
—Oh, yes. They occurred in Shepparton, 0.7c per litre, and Wodonga, 1c per litre. Prices in Geelong were 74.9c per litre in the week ending 13 December, falling to 69.9c in the week ending 20 December, rising to 72.9c in the Christmas week before falling back to 69.9c per litre the following
week. The RACV has advised us that on the basis of all their surveying in conjunction with the ACCC there was no general increase in petrol prices either in the city or country regions over the holiday period.
Mr Fitzgibbon
—That's hogwash.
Mr McGAURAN
—Oh, that's hogwash! The RACV, the RACQ, the AAA and the ACCC are all wrong, are they? Let us see the member for Werriwa's survey—how it is done, how it is put together. Come on! You are not fooling anybody. The oil companies have found you out, because it was Ampol who challenged you on Tuesday, 7 January to allow an independent assessment of your alleged retail price increases, saying `Ampol has nothing to fear from such an examination.' They were joined in that by BP and Mobil.
Let us turn to some of your other magic pudding solutions, bearing in mind you have opposed all of our reforms for petrol. You talked about vertical integration. This is just amazing. Why do you let the member for Werriwa quite sincerely dictate policy on this and many other things? He will just get you into trouble because he is making policy on the run and it is entirely inconsistent with the credibility you wish to establish as an opposition.
Let us have a look at the member for Werriwa's great plan for the oil industry to `break the industry's vertically integrated structure'. Have you heard of section 51 of the constitution? Section 51 of the constitution requires the Commonwealth to make `just terms' in the acquisition of property.
Mr Latham
—What do you think we have our access part for?
Mr McGAURAN
—I will come to access in a moment. This man wants divestment by the oil companies in their retail network. That has been valued by the ACCC in their recently released report at $3 billion. The Australian Institute of Petroleum has assessed it at $4 billion. So where is Labor going to find the $3 billion to $4 billion to acquire these petrol stations throughout Australia? You want divestment; you have to, under the constitu
tion, pay for it. You are just so full of fluff and bluff. It is remarkable.
Now let us get to the access under part IIIA of the Trade Practices Act. With your private member's bill you wanted to declare access to oil terminals under part IIIA of the Trade Practices Act.
Mr Latham
—Hear, hear!
Mr McGAURAN
—Oh, hear, hear! He reckons that is the real solution. As most members would know, if they will allow me to remind them, part IIIA was designed to apply to so-called essential facilities, major infrastructure facilities, through which access is necessary to block monopoly bottlenecks from occurring. Of course an oil terminal can be duplicated, but let us leave our complications like that alone. There are a number of legal problems with the member for Werriwa's plan.
The government has been advised that part IIIA of the Trade Practices Act applies only to services, not to goods. Advice has been received by the government from the ACCC that part IIIA is not applicable to terminals which have distribution facilities. They are not services. Should you change the legislation?
Mr Latham
—Why not?
Mr McGAURAN
—He says, `Why not?' Why don't we change the legislation? I will tell you why: your previous government expressly ruled it out. They ruled it out for the good reason that the Hilmer report said—and I will give you the formal words but to summarise it—`Don't let the politicians be able to play with this on a case by case basis and therefore be susceptible to undue pressure.' In other words, keep your sticky fingers out of part IIIA because the moment you include goods you will have every pressure group, every lobby group, completely distorting the competition policy.
Mr Latham
—Weak.
Mr McGAURAN
—Well, I will quote the Hilmer report. It states:
The legal regime underpinning access rights be general, rather than industry‐specific.
You have completely ignored that recommendation. The Hilmer report also recommended that a legislated right of access should be created by ministerial declaration under legislation. However, the report warned, and these are the key words:
At the same time, the existence of a broad discretionary regime may create pressures on the Minister to declare an essential facility to advance private interests.
In other words, don't let governments interfere on an ad hoc, case by case basis. The only way the terminals can be declared under part IIIA of the act is by legislation. Has the shadow cabinet agreed for legislation to change part IIIA of the Trade Practices Act? Of course not. You are running this argument that is completely phoney because you know very well your own shadow cabinet will never agree to that.
Mr Latham
—They have already.
Mr McGAURAN
—Oh, they have agreed? So you repudiate what you did in government? You are completely junking and abandoning Hilmer? In other words, your shadow cabinet agreed to something they did not understand. I warned you and I warn you again: don't be guided by the member for Werriwa on policy. In other words, according to the member for Werriwa, the whole shadow cabinet has swallowed this line that a legal impossibility will be rectified by the government. That is wonderful! That tells us a lot.
So in all those issues—the scare campaign that you run, the break‐up of the vertical integration and the access under part IIIA of the Trade Practices Act—you have no credibility. It is just a superficial policy which you make up on the run, and that is typical because you will not now show us how you collect the data that you wish to use or misrepresent.
I have read your transcripts: you talk about collusion and cartels. Where is the evidence? Put up or shut up. Why don't you put that to the ACCC? Where is the evidence of the collusion and the cartels? We would like to see it, and we will act on it because we have a commitment to this issue that your party has obviously lacked over 13 years of govern
ment; and the way that you are rushing to the party so late is designed really only to undermine our reforms.
We will not be distracted from the task that we have set ourselves, which is a most ambitious set of reforms which will bring in competition which will lead to a downward pressure on prices, and the price differential in country areas is generally between 5c and 7c, including transport costs. You have failed; the best thing you can do is support us.
(Time expired)
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Nehl)
—Order! Before I call the next speaker, I would just like to say that, while I only interrupted the minister to direct his attention to standing orders, both the speakers so far in this debate were repeatedly and flagrantly in breach of standing orders in not addressing their remarks through the chair. I would like to suggest to all members on both sides of the House that they obey the standing orders in general; and in this case, in particular, let us try to abolish the word `you' from your vocabulary.
Mr ADAMS
(Lyons)
(4.24 p.m.)
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I will endeavour to take your words on board. It was very interesting to hear the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr McGauran) slipping and sliding away from the commitments in his language prior to the last election as he travelled around Australia, he and his colleagues thumping their chests as to what they were going to do to petrol prices, especially in regional Australia, where they have failed. We have heard here today the way he has sold out. There was no commitment in what he said to this House today to bring down prices, especially to regional Australia and to my state of Tasmania.
The contradictory comments that he did make were very interesting because that press release of 7 January of this year said that the federal Minister for Science and Technology, Peter McGauran, also criticised petrol price rises during the holiday break, saying that, in some cases, it was blatant exploitation. So on 7 January he says that it is exploitation; he now comes into the House to defend the government's position, and he does not really
have a defence. He is really slipping and sliding away from the commitment that they had actually made prior to the election.
Prior to the election they were running around the country. You were running around every regional centre in this country saying, `We are going to bring down petrol prices.' I bet you that he was in the Deputy Speaker's seat of Cowper saying, `We will bring down the prices.' Well, you are not going to bring down prices and what you have said today just typifies your approach. You are running away; you are saying that nothing can be done; you are using constitutional arguments and everything else. Well, the people out in regional Australia will hear and know that you are slipping and sliding away from them. Your promise before the election is absolute rubbish and is fast becoming a joke around Australia.
Tasmania has long suffered a disadvantage compared to mainland Australia in relation to the inability of its petrol stations to compete for lower prices. This Howard government keeps preaching that competition should be a natural occurrence in a healthy enterprise system. Competition should generate where profit is taken and, in the petrol industry, it is at the wholesale level, the distributor level and the retail level.
The extent of competition is dependent on the financial capacity of operators to compete at each level and on their desire or need to compete. But that does not happen in Tasmania, especially in regard to their desire to compete. There is no ability to compete because the wholesalers are not interested in competition. They are quite happy with their market share in our small market.
So how can this government say that they are going to bring down petrol prices unless they put in place some sort of regulations to allow the retail level to pick and choose their wholesaler—the big oil companies: Shell, BP, Ampol, Caltex and Mobil? Unless they do that, unless they allow retailers and distributors, in Tasmania's case, to actually choose from which terminal they buy, you will not get competition into the system.
A recent report by the Tasmanian Legislative Council—on which a member, David
Crean MLC, put in a lot of work—highlighted many problems facing petrol retailers in the state. The report says:
When comparing capital cities on the mainland with Hobart, based on the import parity formula, supplying fuel to Hobart should cost the oil companies roughly the same as any other capital city.
Furthermore, based on the Industry Commission's calculations, the cost of that should be about 3.2 cents per litre to the oil companies. (This included administration, marketing, transport, storage.)
Yet under the PSA, 7.4 cents per litre (this was changed in 1994 to 7.1 cents per litre) is allowed which includes 0.5 cents per litre profit. According to the Industry Commission this leaves the oil companies a 3.7 cents per litre margin. Three cents per litre of this was used in Melbourne in 1993 and 1994 to discount to other wholesalers or rebate to retailers to support retail price discounting.
Over the same period in Hobart, the 3.7 cents per litre was taken as profit in addition to the 0.5 cents per litre.
This amounted to oil companies taking three to four times the wholesale profit per volume of petrol sold in Hobart compared to Melbourne on average during 1993 and 1994.
The financial capacity of oil companies to compete in Hobart is not in question. The fact is they have no desire to compete—being content with existing market share, . . . AND there is largely no need to compete because competition is not forthcoming to any great extent from distributors or most retailers.
The member for Werriwa (Mr Latham) recently helped me launch `Petrol price watch' in Tasmania to point out how difficult it is for petrol retailers to provide better prices for their customers. I totally support his suggested private member's bill that will give all service operators the legal right to shop around for the cheapest wholesale petrol. All in this House should support his bill, especially members from regional and country areas of Australia. I would have thought that there are a few people down in the member for Gippsland's electorate now starting to say—
Mr McGauran
—Gippsland West.
Mr ADAMS
—Especially those from Gippsland West—saying, `We have been taken for granted by these Nats for too long. The McGaurans have taken us for granted down here. It is about time we had a look at what sort of service we are getting and at
whether we are going to get lower petrol prices.'
If the government were serious about bringing the price of petrol down across Australia, then the only real answer is to give Australia's service station operators the legal right to shop around for the best wholesale price and pass those benefits onto consumers. When the Treasurer, Mr Costello, announced his deregulation plan, he talked of unleashing new competitive forces. From my earlier points, you will see that this will not work in Tasmania or in regional areas of Australia.
Deregulation does nothing to help competition, particularly in Tasmania where the oil companies could not care less about competition. If anything, deregulation will allow the petrol companies to put prices up rather than down as there is nothing to stop them now—and you should know that.
The Treasurer did not attack the central issue—that is, legally force the big petrol companies to open their terminals to price competition. He could do this through federal legislation and by encouraging the states to bring in their own legislation. We have to ensure that there is an incentive for competition to exist among the big players. If retailers and distributors could shop around, there would be more reason for them to do something. Retailers are saying, `If we cannot shop around, we cannot compete.'
The few price watches that have come in show that the only competition able to be pursued at the moment is where those retailers sell a high enough volume to be able to discount. Those stations are on the major routes, such as the Midlands Highway in Tasmania. Other stations on minor roads around the state can be some 6c higher.
So country people are always going to have to pay higher prices. So much for the big hullabaloo of this government prior to the last election where it was saying it was going to do this and that for regional Australia. Here is another example of where it completely bypassed the needs of regional Australia and country people. The government just walked away from them. Petrol pricing is one example.
Petrol pricing will come back and haunt the government because people out there had some faith when it said it was going to something about it. Of course today we heard the minister slipping and sliding, ringing up the excuses and making the arguments ready to abandon that policy to bring down the price of petrol for regional Australia. He has failed and I am sure he will continually fail to give regional Australia what he promised prior to the last election.
Let me remind the minister of what he said on 7 January. He criticised the petrol price rises during the holiday by saying that in some cases it was `blatant exploitation'. It is blatant exploitation not to open up those terminals to competition. The oil companies can swap their petrol from one terminal to another; therefore, it does not make any difference not to allow competition at the distribution level. Unless you can do that, you will not be doing anything about the price of petrol in Australia.
Mr LIEBERMAN
(Indi)
(4.34 p.m.)
—The member for Werriwa (Mr Latham) and the member for Lyons (Mr Adams) would want the parliament and the community of Australia to believe that they have the answers for the reform of the petrol industry. They also want to spoil the efforts made by the coalition government in its first year in office to attack the problem and to do something constructive. They are spoilers—that is the best way to describe them—using inaccurate information and using information which is not authenticated. They have failed to make available to the ACCC for assessment and investigation the results of their so-called Labor price watch.
I remember during the last parliament when these people were in government going to see and corresponding with their ministers. I took a deputation to Ms McHugh, who was the minister responsible for consumer affairs. She, as she always did, listened carefully to the plea from country members about the need for some action to be taken in the fuel industry. She said, `I am sorry, but I am not responsible; the Assistant Treasurer, Mr Gear, is.'
I made sure that the submissions were passed on to the Assistant Treasurer and he
very courteously replied. I still remember his replies. In effect, they were nothing. There was no action taken on these issues by the then government and by the party that the members for Lyons and Werriwa now belong to for the 13 years that they were in government. Where was the Labor price watch when they were in government? Where was the support and the pressure on their Minister for Consumer Affairs and the Assistant Treasurer to bring in the reforms that the member for Werriwa says will magically solve all the problems? Nothing.
When the pressure got too great and when they were unable to grapple with the problem themselves, what they did do was set up another inquiry. We do know that state and federal governments over more than 40 years have had so many inquiries into the petrol industry that we almost despair. The storage space is probably inadequate now to cope with the number of reports lying around on this issue.
So let us get it into perspective. We have a new reformist government which, in the first nine months of its office, has been dealing with the deficit and the other massive problems it inherited as a result of the mismanagement of the previous government. We have also had the courage and the fortitude and the determination to tackle at the core the reforms that are needed in the fuel industry, and there are many more needed. There will be further action with the oil code, with the code of conduct, and with refining the monitoring system that we have foreshadowed.
Let me just step out the dynamics of the policy. For the first time ever, the federal government has put in place a set of laws that enables access to the terminals and refineries in Australia and does away with the labelling agreement.
Mr Latham
—What laws?
Mr LIEBERMAN
—That is the infamous agreement set up by the Labor Party between the Transport Workers Union and some oil interests to prevent access to the terminals. We all know that that sent broke honest country distributors—I can tell you, because I know many—who were denied access to the terminals because they did not belong to the
club; that is, the organisation that had been set up by the union, the closed shop. We know that, as a result, competition at wholesale level was virtually destroyed. This government has done away with it. The member for Werriwa called out, `How? Where is the legislation?' Of course, the workplace relations legislation does away with those sorts of things. Didn't he know? It is a bit of a surprise to him. I can see the surprise on his face.
The second leg of our reform—and it is revolutionary to have the support and cooperation of so many organisations in Australia—is to set up an effective, authentic and credible monitoring system with the ACCC and the motoring organisations: the AAA, RACV and, I think, NRMA. All of them are under AAA. They will be assisted by many people in the community and by farming organisations. From 1 January there will be a process of monitoring on a proper basis so that any abuses, any collusion, any malpractice and any anti-competitive practices can be reported and investigated, as they must and as they should.
I would remind members listening to this debate that the Trade Practices Act contains penalties of up to $10 million for proven offences. This government is determined to ensure that any credible and substantiated claims that are provided to the ACCC so that they can be investigated will have the full weight of the law if they can be proven.
The member for Werriwa has done a great mischief. He has tried to tell the Australian people that across Australia there have been movements in prices which have been improper.
Mr Latham
—You agreed, and so did he.
Mr LIEBERMAN
—You misquoted me. Do not keep on misquoting. I do not want to use my valuable time with you on that one. Do not misquote people. Learn a lesson. If you have fervour and you want reform, then lay it out. Do not go around misquoting, because it does you no service at all. The fact is that, if you want movements in prices to be investigated because you believe they are a breach of the Trade Practices Act and the
consumer laws, you should substantiate them and take them to the ACCC.
Mr Latham
—I have.
Mr LIEBERMAN
—You have done it. Good. You did not tell the House that you have done it. What a major omission! He kept that back. He just said that he has done it. There it is. Why didn't you tell the House during your speech on the MPI?
Mr Latham
—I had only 15 minutes. Can I go again?
Mr LIEBERMAN
—You silly little boy. Sit down! Relax.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Jenkins)
—Order! Ignore the interjections.
Mr LIEBERMAN
—The other point I want to make is that as a result of the courageous announcements by the Treasurer (Mr Costello), supported by the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr McGauran) in these reforms, there has been unprecedented support in Australia for these reforms. Where else would you find that the RACV, the motoring organisations, the farming organisations of Australia, the umbrella organisations—AAA—have come out publicly and said, `That is what we have been fighting for.' What this coalition government has done in nine months is put in place the framework of reform for which they have been fighting for many years. What a tragedy it is that the former government did not do it. They could have. They would have had our support had they brought it in when we were in opposition. It could have been through the House within five minutes. They did not do it.
So the point I would like to make is that for years country and city motorists have been complaining about their concern and their lack of confidence in the fuel industry distribution system. Nothing was done by the former government at all, to their everlasting shame. I would have thought that a new government would have been supported by them and they would be saying privately, `Thank God these fellas had the courage to tackle the unions. Thank God they got the IR law through. Thank God the framework is there for reform.' To their credit that is what they should have done. But, no, they go
around spoiling; they go around misquoting; they go around trying to undermine the very essence of reforms which are so badly needed in Australia.
Let me also call on the opposition to support the oil industry—the distributors and the retailers—in their discussions to develop an oil code, which is the second phase of our reform and which has to be developed over the next few months. That oil code, if the member for Werriwa will step back and listen, will also be an opportunity for the retailers and the distributors and the wholesalers and the majors to get together and put in place a code of practice with integrity which is fair to all sides. If that is coupled with the reforms we have already introduced, it will be a further dynamic in the fuel industry distribution system in Australia.
Let me make it clear. No-one can guarantee the extent of price movement or price reductions in what I call the hydro-headed monster of the fuel industry. There are too few players, too few refineries, in Australia. We do not have hundreds of people bringing in imported fuel every day. You have to work with the clay you have. You guys know that.
Mr Adams
—You've given up then?
Mr LIEBERMAN
—No way. What we have done is tackle the reforms at the core. We have had the courage to open up access at the refinery level, at the beginning of the wholesale chain. If you think about it, the best inventions in the world are like a wheel: simple. Our reforms—if you look at them fairly and do not try to spoil and them and do not undermine them—are the beginning of the most logical and sensible reform. They will give transparency, they will give access, they will give supervision and accountability and they will have teeth, because of very substantial penalties under the Trade Practices Act for proven offences.
(Time expired)
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Jenkins)
—Order! The discussion is concluded.
CONDOLENCES
Panizza, Senator John Horace
Debate resumed.
Mr GARETH EVANS
(Holt—
Deputy Leader of the Opposition)
(4.44 p.m.)
—I would just like to say a few short words in this debate because I saw and heard a lot of John Panizza in the Senate during the 10 years we overlapped there. I was personally very saddened indeed by the news of his sudden death. John was one of those people of whom you can say absolutely unequivocally that he was a thoroughly decent human being. Of course, we had our differences across the political divide, but even on an issue as highly charged as Mabo, where I remember very well that John was a very strong and persistent advocate of his own rural and business constituency, I always had the sense throughout that debate, throughout that advocacy and throughout that fierce persistence with which he advanced the cause that he was aware of the human and the emotional and psychological dimensions of the issue for the Aboriginal people.
The human dimension of issues was always very much present in the way in which he approached them, in the way in which he articulated his personal response inside or outside the chamber. We heard in the chamber over the years a lot of good, plain, direct, blunt speech from John Panizza of the kind that, according to the Prime Minister (Mr Howard), you also heard a lot of in the party room over those same years. But that good, plain, blunt and direct speech was just about always, as I recall it, tempered with great good humour. Certainly, I can never ever remember him saying anything that was coloured by malice or mean‐spiritedness. That is not something that we can all claim in this place or anywhere else. So, very shortly and very simply, I want to say this: John Panizza was a very decent bloke, transparent, warm, honest and very human. Obviously, his family is going to miss him like hell. My heart goes out to them, but we will all miss him.
Mr CADMAN
(Mitchell)
(4.47 p.m.)
—I want to pay tribute to a fine Australian, a man whom I came to know and had liked very much over the time since he arrived in this parliament. When John Panizza arrived in the parliament, I had responsibilities to consider policies and ideas in relation to migration and
multiculturalism. At first, John was reluctant to identify himself with his Italian background, but once he relaxed from a fairly protective attitude his sometimes rough and direct, snappy and gruff attitude was one of real pleasure to be associated with. John was a hard worker and that showed through in his character and his manner and treatment of his fellow Australians. He was very proud to be an Australian.
I think he was a wonderful man. Since I became Chief Government Whip, to deal with John on a day‐to‐day basis was something to which I looked forward. If you had a disagreement with John Panizza, he told you quickly. There were no problems about hiding things and no games being played; he told you. If he had a problem, he told you. If he felt hurt or slighted or neglected in any way, he was quickly on the phone to tell you about that as well. So, over the past 10 months, a friendship and an acquaintanceship grew which was an interesting one, because we shared a love of the land and a similar background in our growing up in rural Australia. My understanding of the wheat industry and what John had achieved at Southern Cross on his property and the fact that I had family members living in Kalgoorlie bound us together, but that was consolidated by the need for us to work together day by day, hour by hour, in the House of Representatives and the Senate.
I want to pay tribute to John. I missed him this morning in the party room. It just seemed to me quite strange that my colleague was not alongside me there in the back row where the whips sit to time the speakers to make sure that they keep to their time limit. He guarded the stopwatch with a great deal of pride. He complained at length until we purchased one—he did not offer to buy one himself but he had complained to me that I did not have one—and when I provided it to him he seized both the bell and the stopwatch with a great deal of enthusiasm. It was his role to time our speakers, and he made remarks under his breath about lengthy speakers or speakers whom he felt were inadequate.
He was always quick to his feet and always keen to press the claims of rural Australia. He
was always fearless in his statements. Some of his statements could, if misunderstood, be seen by ministers or members to be abrasive, but everybody looked behind the words to the heart of the man. On behalf of myself and my colleagues and the whips in the House of Representatives, I pay tribute to a great Australian, and a person whom I have been very privileged to know. I extend my condolences and those of our family to his wife, Coral, and his family.
Mr STEPHEN SMITH
(Perth)
(4.51 p.m.)
—I want to associate myself with the remarks of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard), the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley), the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Tim Fischer) and other honourable members in this condolence motion for Senator John Panizza. One of the fortunes of my life and that of my mother, father and two sisters was to spend a number of years in the 1960s living in Southern Cross. Some of my fondest memories from my childhood are the years I spent growing up in Southern Cross, which of course was the town in which John Panizza was born and spent his life.
Southern Cross was founded in 1888, from memory. It was founded as a result of the discovery of gold, and the first great influx to Southern Cross was that of gold prospectors. In the first half of this century, there was a second great influx to Southern Cross and that was of wheat farmers. One thing that was significant about that second influx was that these farmers were, in the main, migrants—particularly from Italy and particularly from that area we once used to know as the former republic of Yugoslavia. Names such as Dellabosca, Granich and Panizza were famous then and abound in Southern Cross now and in its history. For example, in my case, a Dellabosca was my closest primary school friend, a Granich remains one of my closest friends today, and I had the honour and the privilege to serve in the national parliament as a member from Western Australia with Senator John Panizza.
I cannot recall knowing John Panizza in my childhood, but my mother and father certainly did. My father was in the PMG. He told me on a number of occasions how he used to
repair and attend to the phones on the Panizza farm. I rang my mother and father last week to relay to them the sad news of John's sudden death. After getting over the sadness and the suddenness, my father's remark was quite simple—that John was a good bloke. My mother's remark was that this was a kind and decent man.
My first recollection of meeting John Panizza was on a plane from Perth to Canberra, shortly after I became the member for Perth in 1993. I was beginning to experience the arduousness of travel from Western Australia, which the Leader of the National Party (Mr Tim Fischer) referred to in his contribution. John came up to me and made the point that he knew my father. We then had one of those lengthy conversations on the plane that Western Australian members will be so familiar with. What struck me about John then were so many of the attributes that people have attributed to him since his death. He was a good bloke, he was a decent man, he was kind, he was compassionate and caring, and he was imbued with a generosity of spirit. What struck me about him at the time was that there were a number of things that were clearly important to him. Southern Cross and the Yilgarn were important to him. His local government service as a councillor and as president of the Shire of Yilgarn were important to him. His Italian heritage was important to him. From my observation, perhaps the two things most important to him were his farm, of which he was entitled to be proud, and his family.
In September 1996, at John's urging, I attended the centenary of the local Catholic church; the church that my family attended when we lived in Southern Cross—a church known as Our Lady of Montserrat, which is nestled at the top of the rise in Altair Street. I went to those centenary celebrations with my mother and father, my sister and my young son, who was then four. In the course of those weekend celebrations, my mother and father renewed their acquaintance with John Panizza. He and I joked that, although we had not checked the record, we were probably the only two members of the national parliament since Federation who had attended St Joseph's
Catholic Primary School in Southern Cross, just across the road in Altair Street.
There were a number of things that I observed about John Panizza in the course of that weekend. It was clear that he was loved by his family, it was clear that he was respected by members of his church and it was clear that he was very well regarded by the people of Southern Cross. In the prayers of intercession for the centenary mass, the prayers for government service and the prayers for the farming community were delivered respectively by Councillor Charmaine Panizza and Mr Frank Panizza. That shows the contribution that John's family generally has made to those areas of activity in the Yilgarn.
The centenary celebrations concluded on a Sunday. John and I had to get from Southern Cross to Perth to continue the arduous journey back to Canberra, so we did so in a light plane—John, myself and my four‐year‐old son. John spent most of the time on the plane doing two things: firstly, lecturing me in the nicest possible way about the importance of family and, secondly, ensuring in the course of the short light plane trip from Southern Cross to Perth that others were taken care of before him. Those memories that I have of that weekend will be the memories that I will have of John Panizza: a good bloke, and a kind and decent man, imbued with a generosity of spirit, who was often, if not always, thinking about others ahead of himself.
Senator John Panizza made a distinguished contribution to this parliament, in the public service of Western Australia, to the town of Southern Cross and to the Shire of Yilgarn. On behalf of my family, I extend my deepest sympathy to his wife, Coral, and family.
Mr EOIN CAMERON
(Stirling)
(4.58 p.m.)
—I would like to associate myself with the comments already made by other members who have contributed to this motion. In the brief time that I knew John Panizza since my preselection in 1991, he became a very trusted friend and colleague. Western Australia is the poorer for the passing of John Panizza. He was a passionate advocate for the state of Western Australia, particularly the rural and regional areas of the vast state. He was able
to represent his constituency with exceptional diligence. He was able to do this as a result of his success in these areas prior to entering politics, because he was a highly successful man by any definition.
John's death was a severe shock, I am sure, to all of us. He was such a tireless hard worker, and an asset to the Liberal Party and the Western Australian community. I pass on the condolences of myself and my family to Coral and all of John's family on their sad loss. John will be sadly missed by all of us. I am not sure if John was a Kenny Rogers fan or even a country music fan, but there was a line in a Kenny Rogers song that I am sure John would have heard of. It goes: `The best you can hope for is to die in your sleep'. John Panizza deserved the best.
Mr RANDALL
(Swan)
(4.59 p.m.)
—I would like to take this opportunity to honour a fellow Western Australian, colleague and friend, Senator John Panizza, who passed away in Cairns on 30 January. Much of what I am about to say has already been said, but I would like to reiterate. The Senate lost a valuable member and the Liberal Party of Western Australia also lost a very valuable and hardworking member. John will be remembered for his refreshing down-to-earth nature and his genuine concern and desire to help the people of Western Australia, in particular those from rural areas.
John was the son of an Italian family from the northern Italian region of Sondrio, from where a number of well-known Italian migrants have come to Western Australia. John typified the southern European migrant who came to this country. Their work ethic and community spirit are legendary.
Coming from the goldfield town of Southern Cross, just east of my home town of Merredin, the positive effect of his rural background and knowledge was twofold: firstly, he knew first‐hand the issues facing Western Australia, many of those unique to our vast state; and, secondly, his no fuss, hardworking attitude earned him the respect of people on all sides of the political arena.
Senator Panizza made a name for himself as a prominent wheat grower in the rather marginal area of the Yilgarn before entering
the world of politics. As many members here will know, that marginal country can either make or break you. It provides seasons of immense success, excellent crops or there are long periods of drought. The Panizza family certainly knew their craft well and were very successful farmers in the area.
He thoroughly deserves the admiration he received for rising from humble beginnings to becoming a well‐respected primary producer, a local government representative and a tireless spokesman for Western Australia. His devotion to both his role as a senator and a representative of our state over the past 10 years has made him a consummate role model for new members such as me. At the previous preselection process for which Senator Panizza stood, I remember him coming to a Swan divisional meeting where he was touting for numbers—like many of the other Senate candidates. He said to me and to the Swan division that evening that, if he happened to lose the preselection, he certainly would not be off to the papers on Monday morning complaining bitterly about some job done on him. He would accept the result.
Having a residence in my electorate of Swan in South Perth, I was honoured to receive help and support from John during the 1996 federal election. John was determined to use his house to my advantage. He insisted on having my face, believe it or not, on his front lawn in the form of posters and signs. He was always on hand for advice. I will be eternally grateful for his encouragement during that time.
John Panizza will be sorely missed by his Western Australian colleagues and members of the Liberal Party Australia-wide. My deepest condolences go to his wife, Coral, and his four children: Frank, Janine, Stephen and Linda.
Mr FILING
(Moore)
(5.02 p.m.)
—As a former party colleague of Senator John Panizza, I would just like to make a few brief remarks on the condolence motion. John was preselected and elected in 1987 as a senator for Western Australia. He was elected in the double dissolution election in that year. He was preselected at the time by a coalition of people who wanted to have a strong represen
tative for country interests as a senator for Western Australia representing the Liberal Party. John Panizza came through that preselection process representing that particular voice.
Ever since his election to the Senate, I believe that John Panizza has forthrightly represented regional Australian interests. It takes a fair amount of moral courage as well as strength of character to stand up in the party room of the coalition and represent those interests when sometimes they are unpopular or at times when perhaps they do not fit in with the prevailing philosophical view. Nonetheless, John Panizza always represented those views strongly—at times he went against the general flow within the coalition parties.
The fact that John rose to the position of Government Whip in the Senate reflects the standing in which he was held by his colleagues not only in the party but also generally in the parliament. He took on the job as the Government Whip in the Senate under circumstances of enormous difficulty. He had to ensure that in every single division every single senator was present. No doubt that required a tremendous amount of vigilance and attention to detail. Having served in the whips office in this place for the coalition, I can well understand the enormous amount of work that was required of him and his staff to ensure that the senators were present for all divisions.
I have had a long association with John Panizza through the political process. I found him to be a decent, honourable man at all times. I read with great interest the obituary written by the member for Stirling (Mr Eoin Cameron), which I thought was a first‐class representation of the work and life of John Panizza. I commend the member for Stirling for that obituary. It encapsulated what John Panizza represented not only to his own party but also to the people who viewed him as their champion. At times, when the interests of regional Australians are being forgotten or overlooked by the interests of the east coast cities, the memory of John Panizza's contribution to this parliament will shine through. He was one of those rare people who, at all
times, remembered his constituency. I would also like to pass on my deepest condolences to Coral and the family.
Mr BARRESI
(Deakin)
(5.06 p.m.)
—I would like to add my voice to those who have spoken both here and in the other chamber on the life and career of Western Australian senator John Panizza. His sudden passing away is one that has touched us all.
Although by no means a close acquaintance of the senator, I had the benefit of his friendship and advice in the course of the last 10 months. In this time, I found him a man of great principle, warm and intelligent. He was the type of person who was not easily shocked, the kind of man who, I can remember thinking, must have seen a lot in his 65 years of life. Between us, there was first and foremost a recognition of a common Italian heritage, a heritage of which Senator Panizza was extremely proud. Yet it was a type of ethnic pride which is common amongst Italian Australians from rural areas. He was a country Australian through and through, passionate about rural issues while maintaining the good-natured scepticism with which most rural MPs view their city dwelling colleagues.
He would tell us that Australia's wealth came from the country, and of course he meant it. He had come to parliament to remind us that Australia's prosperity was linked to the prosperity of rural communities. I am sure that others will talk about Senator Panizza's achievements in his nine years as a federal member of parliament. He was an excellent, hardworking spokesperson for the people of Western Australia and that is a fact which has been recognised today by all members.
My obligation and privilege today is simply to record what we had in common: our ancestry. John Panizza, as a trailblazer in Liberal politics, indirectly influenced the changing face of Australian politics and made the path that I, and I am sure the member for Petrie (Ms Gambaro), have had to take that much easier. Senator Panizza's parents came from northern Italy, a stone's throw away from the Swiss border. People from these parts can be tough. They are determined people, resilient and extremely hardworking.
Senator Panizza's father, Robert, before coming to Australia, fought with the famous Alpini in the First World War. My own grandfather too fought in those same Alps.
Robert Panizza, upon his arrival in the new land in 1921, worked as a miner in Broken Hill, Mount Isa and eventually Western Australia, where he settled in the town of Southern Cross to build a life for his new family. I once heard a radio interview with Senator Panizza in which he was asked why, as someone who had experienced racial hatred as a child, he opposed racial vilification legislation. `Because the best way of dealing with people like that is with a bunch of fives,' was his answer.
This was typical of Senator Panizza. He would never shirk an issue.
