In fact in his maiden speech he invited senators on the other side of the chamber to feel free to interject if they disagreed with his comments. Where we, the city folk, would seek therapy, Senator Panizza was busy getting on with the task at hand. He became a better Australian than those who taunted him. He was a true son of his parents, a true son of his parent's land and a true son of this country of ours—Australia.
John Panizza was influenced to become a senator in part due to his fascination of the Roman senate. He studied it. He no doubt recognised the tangible power of the Australian Senate, one of the most powerful upper houses in the democratic world. But I am sure he also enjoyed the symbolism of it all—the child of an Italian immigrant sitting in the `senatus', a chamber with such clear Roman antecedents.
Honest people of any background are hard to come by in this day and age. We all know that people of integrity tend often to be few and far between. That is why Australia should be honoured that its first senator of Italian parentage was John Horace Panizza.
He was an achiever in business, in local government, in the Senate and I am sure as a family man. He will be sadly missed by his fellow Western Australians, by those of Australian-Italian heritage and above all by his parliamentary colleagues. I offer my sincerest condolences to his wife, Coral, and
his children. I assure them that the senator will not be forgotten.
Mr HAWKER
(Wannon)
(5.10 p.m.)
—I too would like to join in this motion and support the words that many of my colleagues on both sides of this chamber have had to say today about John Panizza, someone who will be indeed greatly missed by members of both the Senate and the House of Representatives. I have to admit to a certain shock at hearing the news last Friday of the loss of John, who was not only a treasured colleague but also a very good and very loyal friend. When he said he would do something, you knew that he would stick to his word and he would get in there and do it.
As has also been said, he was a very tenacious fighter for the state of Western Australia and he was a tenacious fighter for regional Australia. I can remember on many occasions having discussions with John. We did not always agree, but at the end of the day when the decision was made we got on and we made sure it happened. While we certainly had some common interests, a friendship developed through a respect we had for each other, many times on rural matters. As I say, when we reached agreement on these things we went ahead.
One of the things I really respected John for, amongst many other things, was that he would support you at a time when you were in need. I can well remember a meeting that was held in my electorate in 1991 when over 1,500 very worried wool growers turned up in the Hamilton town hall. It was clear that they were very dissatisfied with what had happened in wool marketing and they were rather keen to find someone to blame for the collapse of the floor price of wool. John had heard about this through the media and duly flew to Hamilton. When I said to him, `This is a welcome surprise to see you here today.' He said, `I just thought you might have needed a little bit of help so I thought I'd come along.' That was typical of John Panizza, that was the sort of effort he would make for colleagues and that is one of many examples of what a very fine man he was and what a very fine Australian he was.
We have heard many people already speak of his decency, his honesty and the fact that he was very much a straight talker, that you always knew where you were with him and that he was a very effective representative for the state of Western Australia. Others have talked about his success in public life and through his support of his family and through his achievements prior to coming into parliament, many of which he continued while he was still in the Senate.
I also had the pleasure and honour of John taking over from me as the acting shadow minister while I took a holiday in 1993. I rang him when I came back from holidays and everything was running smoothly. John had made sure that nothing had got out of control and it was a pleasure to know that in those sorts of situations everything had been placed in safe hands.
I feel that last Friday we lost a very loyal friend, a very fine Australian and a very respected colleague. Like others, I too pass on my deepest sympathy to John's wife, Coral, and their family. We have lost a very fine person.
Mrs JOHNSTON
(Canning)
(5.14 p.m.)
—I wish to join my colleagues in making a few comments about Senator Panizza. Much has already been said today about the fact that his family were migrants to this country. Senator Panizza is the sort of person that we should hold up as an example of the tremendous opportunities that people can rise to when they come to this country. Senator Panizza was a very successful man, but success never got to his head. He never let it get the better of him. In all the time that I knew John Panizza, he was a man of the people and for the people. His first responsibility was to his family, to his state and to his country.
I got to know John Panizza very well during many years of campaigning. Throughout that time he never once shied away from the principles that we in the Liberal Party stand for or indeed what any representative to this parliament should be upstanding for. Principle was something that was far above anything else in his attitude to life.
Something else that stood out about John Panizza was the fact that he continued to
believe, despite being a very successful man, that hard work would result in just reward. It is well known that that is true in his case.
The good thing about John Panizza was that he never belittled anyone. No matter who you were or what you might be aspiring to, John took you for what you were and he admired you for whatever qualities you had. He was also a very well respected man not only in his home state of Western Australia but right around Australia, as many of my colleagues have already said today.
John was always prepared to give advice. You might not have liked what he told you but, upon reflecting on what he said, you would find it was probably very good advice. For those of us who were not always prepared to accept that advice, it may perhaps have been something that we should have listened to much more closely at the time.
I know that many other colleagues wish to add to the comments that have already been made, including mine. On behalf of my family and the people whom I represent—I know a large number of people in the Italian community of my electorate of Canning will be very saddened at the loss of Senator Panizza—I pass on our sympathy to John's wife, Coral, and his extended family. May I also speak for people like the member for Bendigo (Mr Reid), who may not have the opportunity to speak today on this condolence motion. I am sure he joins with us in these comments.
Mr TUCKEY
(O'Connor)
(5.17 p.m.)
—John Panizza was a member of the Senate who was probably the first example of a recognition within the Liberal Party in Western Australia that within its rural constituency, which is very substantial in terms of its membership, were people of the qualities of John Panizza who could bring both the experience of a rural background, the experience of doing it pretty hard in their youth, along with all the other skills of able business management that one might find in St Georges Terrace and a great understanding many Australians who had come to Australia post the Second World War have. But his preselection was particularly a move towards recognising the rural constituency of Western
Australia by way of nominating people to the Senate when their representation was otherwise limited by the number of seats covering rural Western Australia—and, as I stand here, there is basically only one.
John was given a task. He was followed by Winston Crane and Alan Eggleston—similar people who bring a very broad experience to the parliament but, added to that, an understanding of the problems related to the rural and remote area constituency. In preselecting John, I do not think the Liberal Party could have made a better choice from a large number of candidates who had that sort of background, because he was outstanding in terms of his personal abilities and his personal understanding.
I would like to emphasise that point because in many discussions with John I came to understand how well he understood what life was like on a farm such as Southern Cross in those early years. John would have lived there around the time of the Depression. Southern Cross, which has been very bountiful in terms of its agricultural productivity in recent years, is pretty tough country. You have to have a great deal of courage, irrespective of your wealth, to go out, as the Panizzas do, and put in 25,000 to 30,000 acres of crop in an area where sometimes it just does not rain. It is, by anybody's standards, marginal country.
That the Panizzas have made a success of it is further evidence of just how committed and dedicated they are. On my last visit to their property, which was some time ago, they were harvesting and it was the brothers, the family, who were out there on the machines notwithstanding that over time they had become extremely successful and no doubt could have afforded to pay someone else to do that job. But that is the type of people the Panizzas are: committed to their own farm. It is no secret that John's wife, Coral, still preferred living on the farm to the luxuries of Canberra or even the city where John had established his office as a senator for Western Australia. They are great people—greatly committed to their area.
I can only say how surprised—in fact, shocked—I was to be acquainted with the
news of John's death. If anyone had asked me to write a list of my colleagues who might die, I would have put myself well and truly above John Panizza. He was a little older than I, but he always appeared so fit and looked after himself, which I never have done.
It is a sorry time that someone whom I saw as having still a very long future in politics, let alone life, has left us in that way. As I have just said, Coral's preference was still for the farm and the family, but I am so pleased she was with him when he died. John was fortunate in the way he went. I am just devastated for those he has left behind.
John and I had an interesting political career. It is a pity the member for Wannon (Mr Hawker) has left the chamber, because he still talks about the time when he, Jim Short, John and I went to Merredin, which is the heart of grain growing country within my electorate and not far from Southern Cross. We went to discuss John Kerin's proposal to deregulate the domestic wheat market. John Panizza and I were on opposite sides of the fence on the issue. John was an extremely conservative wheat grower in wheat grower political terms. John did not want anything to change. I felt the issue was a bit different. The audience was giving me a particularly hard time. It was interesting for David to see the way those sorts of meetings could be conducted.
But that did not alter John's and my friendship. He felt that the wheat growers' interests would be best represented by the status quo; I felt that their interests would be improved by what the government at the time was proposing. We both put our views, with varying degrees of support. I think John had more supporters than I did, but we did it as friends. The member for Wannon has just returned. I am sure by the smile on his face that he remembers the day. Jim Short went out of their staggering. He had never seen the likes of it.
But it was great politics, and it was two members who were always prepared to represent the interests of their own constituents. On that occasion, we had a philosophically different point of view. In later years, John shifted closer to my point of view in that
regard, but he always acted on the basis of what he thought was best—in this case, for wheat growers. That is why he stood tall in this parliament.
That is what we are all here for. We are not always going to have the same view as to how our people are best represented. John was certainly prepared to argue the case in their interests as he saw it. I think he continued throughout his career that way. He will, therefore, be sorely missed within the Western Australian electorate and Australia. He always worked that way.
I extend Jenny's and my sympathies to Coral. We are deeply saddened for her because they were very close. I know she will miss John. But, on the other hand, she has four great kids. I am sure they will give her great support.
Mrs BISHOP
(Mackellar—
Minister for Defence Industry, Science and Personnel)
(5.25 p.m.)
—In listening to the condolences that have already been delivered in this place, I have heard people talk about John Panizza having known him for a longer period than I did. I knew John, as a senator, having served with him in the Senate, since we came in together in 1987. Friendships were made in that year between those of us who came in together. I came to know John as a man who would always put it very straight. He was never a person who would dissemble. If he had a point of view, if he had something to tell you, he told you straight to your face and then you got on with the discussion.
He was a man with whom I campaigned. When I think of him, he was a man of 65, which I will call a young man, who still had a lot to give and a man who had said:
I believe that a man must show that he can manage his own affairs and preferably risk his own dollar before offering himself for higher office and thereby shaping the future of other people.
He was a man who believed that very much. He was a man who practised what he preached and who came into the parliament and gave 10 years. But he had many more years he could have given. It was the wisdom of what he had learned in doing other things, the wisdom that he had from experience, that was of benefit—learning from his parents
about hardship and about hard work, dedication of purpose and bringing up a family in principles in which you believe. That is what he believed was good for the country.
With John's passing we will miss from this parliament a man, whom I considered a friend and whom others considered a friend, who led by example. In public life, where we are so often criticised as perhaps being self-serving, or whatever the general terms we are criticised in, John Panizza was a man who came because he wanted to give service, who was true to the principles that he had experienced through his life and who argued in a debate from that experience. The parliament was richer for his being here. It is also the poorer for his leaving.
To Coral, his wife, and his children, I extend, along with everybody else, my most deep and sincere condolences and deep and sincere sympathy. I trust that they will know that within the Liberal Party there is still a place for them to be remembered and valued and be part of our community.
Mr RICHARD EVANS
(Cowan)
(5.28 p.m.)
—Respect is a word that is not often used in relation to politicians or politics. But certainly, from the contributions today from my colleagues, it is clear that Senator Panizza had a lot of respect from his colleagues—and that has certainly been evidenced by the number of people putting their condolences into the newspapers in Western Australia—and that respect has been shared by a lot of other people.
I fist came across Senator Panizza by knowing the Panizza family from Bunbury and Albany. Although distant relatives, it seems certain that the Panizza family has influence in a lot of farming areas from Bunbury right around to where John and his brothers were successful at Southern Cross. I have always thought John was successful. The best definition of success I have heard is that success is the continual realisation of a worthy ideal or goal. John had clear ideals and always worked towards those ideals. John also had clear goals and always worked to maintain those goals. Based upon that definition, Senator John Panizza was very success
ful not only in this place but also in his life outside of parliament.
Today the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) alluded to the fact that he often flew with John to and from Western Australia. At certain times of the year John would look out the window as he crossed the Western Australian coast, looking for clouds. He would quite rightly say whether it was raining or not and things like that, concerned about his crops. He was well respected for his crop growing and farming in that area and certainly paid clear attention to the weather as he was flying into Western Australia.
John was very proud of his Italian heritage. I often went to the Italian club with John. Four and a half per cent of the members of my electorate have Italian heritage. John showed me the strange nuances associated with the Italian community. We were often the only two Liberals at Italian functions. There were usually about 12 Labor members of parliament there. John was always there and he would always encourage me to come along as well. He was clearly highly respected at the Italian club and within the Italian community.
John was also well regarded as a hard campaigner when it came to elections. If I remember rightly, six months before the election campaign, he was one of the few people who said that we had a chance of winning Brand. He said that the opposition leader, Mr Beazley, would be in trouble. Sure enough, it proved the case in March last year that he was in trouble, although Mr Beazley crossed the line.
It has been very hot in Cowan during the last two federal election campaigns. On hot days you sometimes need help with campaigning. Often when I asked John to help with doorknocking in Cowan, he would always turn up on the hottest days because he was always thought that there would not be the support of others on such days and that the time to help was when others were not around.
There was a very vague rumour in 1995 that John's preselection would be under threat. As so often happens in politics, people put these things out in the marketplace to see
what sorts of comments come back and then determine what action needs to follow. There was a very serious reaction within the Liberal Party regarding those rumours. John overcame those rumours totally. The country constituency of the Liberal Party certainly supported John very strongly.
It is a sad loss to lose John Panizza. I used to enjoy travelling with John back to Western Australia. We would have many a fine chat about various issues, including football. His nephew, a friend of mine, was coaching the Claremont football team. John will be sadly missed. On behalf of my own family, who knew John, and those associated with the Cowan electorate, I offer my condolences to the whole Panizza family.
Mr ANDREW
(Wakefield)
(5.32 p.m.)
—I rise along with other members to briefly pay a tribute to Senator John Panizza. May I also take the liberty of recognising the fact that you, Mr Deputy Speaker Jenkins, have chosen to remain in the chair and so allow me to pay this tribute. You have done so out of your own respect for Senator Panizza and your desire to participate in this debate, albeit not verbally, because of the work you had done with him on the Standing Committee on Publications. I share with you and all other members of this chamber a real sense of loss and a sense of having lost a friend, although I had only known Senator Panizza for the last nine years.
All that has been said by all other members of the chamber, referring to his tenacity and his courage, are sentiments I endorse. There is no doubt that Senator Panizza was very proud of his Italian heritage. There is no doubt that he was very proud of his father and of the success that his father had, first as a miner and then as a pioneer farmer in that difficult country in the Southern Cross area. There is no doubt that he was very proud of his family and each of his sons and daughters. There is no doubt that he was also a successful senator and a successful farmer who took a great deal of pride in the family properties and was anxious to ensure that the latest techniques were engaged as part of their farming practice.
For all of those achievements, for all of the capacity that he brought into this parliament and for all that he had done outside of the parliament in local government and in farming to make a name for himself, I will remember him most as an unassuming and self-effacing person who was likeable because, in spite of all his success, he was so unassuming.
I worked closely with Senator John Panizza on the primary industry committee, a role that I shared with both the member for Wannon (Mr Hawker) and the member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey). They have made much reference to Senator Panizza's role on that committee. As chairman of the coalition primary industry committee, there were a couple of issues on which Senator Panizza and I disagreed, but I never left a meeting of that committee with any sense of division, for that was not part of the Panizza nature.
I do not know Mrs Coral Panizza or the family well. While nothing that we will say in this chamber can relieve them of the dreadful sense of separation that they must feel at this time, I hope it will be of some comfort to them to know that we grieve with them.
Ms GAMBARO
(Petrie)
(5.35 p.m.)
—I rise today to echo the sentiments of a number of members who have spoken on the condolence motion for Senator John Panizza. I want to add my own words as well. I was in Western Australia last week on some committee business when I heard the devastating news. I was only two doors away from his office, so I was overcome by a great sense of sadness that he should leave us so suddenly.
John made a very valuable contribution to the Senate and also to the country since his election in 1987. As the member for Deakin (Mr Barresi) has alluded to today, Senator Panizza was very proud of his Italian heritage. To have entered the Senate was indeed a milestone for him, a feat which I can truly relate to, having been the first female of Italian origin to enter the House. It must have meant a great deal to his family and to his parents to have him achieve that great honour.
Senator Panizza, in the short time that I did know him, was always willing to share a
story with me. Stories about his early days and the struggle that he and his family had to endure were really inspiring. I recount a particular story about the war. Members of his family would go across to another farm with their lanterns shining and quite often they would be picked up by the authorities, who thought that they were signalling to the enemy who were flying overhead. I found that quite an amusing story.
He played a very significant part in government at all levels, particularly at the local level from 1975 to 1987 and from 1982 to 1987 on the Yilgarn Shire Council. During those particular years he got involved in town planning issues and transport and works. I guess the years in council prepared him well for his future life in federal politics. He learned about things at a grassroots level, about the things that really affect people and about the local things that matter. It was this strength, gained so hardily from his experience in local government, which brought him to federal parliament and to the Senate.
The senator was a very successful farmer and property developer. He was always down to earth and a very straight shooter. He had an honesty that I admired greatly. He was brought up in the school of hard knocks and his parents, as migrants to this country, worked very hard to make ends meet. They instilled a great deal of self-confidence in him and certainly initiated a lot of the drive that he had.
Senator Panizza was active in a lot of Senate activities. A number of members have spoken about his work on the standing, legislative and general purpose committees. He was a very informed voice for the people of Western Australia. As the people he represented came from all walks of life, the senator in turn ensured that in his career in the Senate he became involved in as many issues as he could that were at the very heart of his constituency. His committee work is legendary. People have already alluded to his great personal involvement: he put his heart and soul into everything he did. He brought to all his duties a great sense of purpose and dignity and there was a commitment with everything
he set out to achieve. He was regarded well by both sides of the chamber.
As a new member, my impressions of him were that he was a tireless campaign worker. I remember an occasion not so long ago where he came from Western Australia to support me in a fundraising function, for which I truly admired him. He was a straight shooter. He was always willing to give you advice and as a newer member that is welcome sometimes, I have to admit.
He was sharp witted and his sense of humour was something to behold. He always had the time to sit down and talk to you about whatever you wished to discuss. I will remember him warmly for his conversational skills, his ability to make anyone feel at home, his warmth and his generosity. The importance of his family always came through in those discussions with me.
Senator Panizza is survived by his widow Coral and their children. I am sure that they will continue the ideals which they have learned from him and which he pursued throughout his life. On behalf of myself, my family and the people of Petrie, I extend my deepest sympathy to his family and to all the friends of Senator Panizza.
Mrs MOYLAN
(Pearce—
Minister for Family Services)
(5.40 p.m.)
—I was deeply saddened to hear the news of the passing of my colleague John Panizza. Indeed, he was a man who managed a very rare combination of humility, confidence and commitment to the causes that he felt passionate about, and he did feel passionate about many causes.
I had the opportunity to read through his first speech to the parliament. That indicates his wide-ranging concerns about his constituency. He was a great advocate for mining, for the pastoral region and for the fishing industry, and he recognised the importance of a strong economic base and the role that those industries played, particularly those from his own state of Western Australia. He was a man who knew and always remembered where he came from. In his maiden speech he said:
One thing I will always remember is where I came from. I am the son of Italian migrants. One must put on record the important contribution made to this country by such people.
Not only was he passionate and committed about the role of industry, the pastoral industry in particular, to this country, but he also had great compassion. He understood the importance of the contribution that migrants made to this country. He also acknowledged not only the hard work of his father and those who came around the time of his father to this country but also the women who followed the men into the harsh conditions. I suppose I have some understanding of some of those conditions Senator Panizza's family had to deal with because my uncle had a farm in the same farming region that John Panizza's father farmed in and that he no doubt spent a great deal of time in as a child. I used to spend holidays there and I know how tough it was on my aunty and on the other women in that region. I also recognised the hard work done by the men.
His humility was always demonstrated in his compassion, his sympathy and his understanding for his fellow man. Clearly, as a migrant he had from time to time encountered discrimination. He makes a point, in fact, that there was a lot of discrimination and that migrants to this country had met with hostility. In his maiden speech he made a point of saying `if the Aboriginal people feel that they are still discriminated against—I know they are—they have my sympathy, because I know what it is like'. So he was also a man of great compassion and, as I said, a man of humility. I think the thing that touched me the most in his first speech to the Senate was that he said:
As we move to the celebration of Australia's 200th anniversary—
this, of course, was given in October 1987—
I express the hope that we can at last be one nation, whether our skin happens to be green, yellow, black or white and whether we are descended from the convicts, the aristocracy, the Aboriginals or European migrants. Hopefully we can be one people under the same flag which, amongst other things, carries the emblem of the Southern Cross. That is my home town.
I think he is an inspiration for all of us to remember—to remember where we came from, whom we serve and our responsibility and our role not only to forward the economic progress of this country but also to continue to address the human issues. I know that I
will personally miss the association I have enjoyed with the senator and I think, indeed, the world is worse for his passing. I extend my deepest sympathy to Coral and to his family on this sad occasion.
Mr PROSSER
(Forrest—
Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs)
(5.44 p.m.)
—I, too, wish to join with my colleagues to pay tribute to John Panizza. Someone described John Panizza earlier as being a straight shooter and that is how I describe John Panizza. You always knew where you stood with John. He would tell you exactly what he thought with no mucking around. I could describe John as a rare breed in politics at any level.
He was a great ambassador for Western Australia—there is no doubt about that—and for the Liberal Party. I admire John Panizza. I admire John Panizza for his hard work, for what he achieved, for being an astute businessman both as a farmer and a property investor. But he was always a very grassroots person. My colleagues have said that his success, driven by that hard work and the hard work of his family, never changed John Panizza. That is what I liked about John. He was a straight shooter and very much down to earth.
I know that his family, Coral and his children, will suffer a very great loss at a time when they, John too, should have been looking forward to a period of enjoyment after John's remarkable achievements: local success in business, farming, local government, election to the Senate and then the achievement of the office of whip. John was a fit man, a hardworking man and, as I said, a tremendous advocate for Western Australia.
I found that John was not a person driven by any lobby group or industry organisation. John had the uncanny ability to cut through to know what the community was saying and was not the mouth of someone else. He well and truly portrayed the view of people. As I mentioned, he will be sadly missed. He was a straight shooter. You always knew where John was coming from. Success, even his success as a senator, never changed John. We all in the Liberal Party admire John for that.
For all of us, in those long trips backwards and forwards, it was more enjoyable—in the days when I and John Panizza first got in together—when the Senate and the House of Representatives used to get up together. I think the previous government probably wisely changed those rules. In fact I am sure the airlines said, `If you keep it up you will destroy our passenger loads on those segments when senators and members got up together.'
I can always recall, for those of us who knew John very well, that when the previous Prime Minister made those remarks about the Senate and described them as `pansies' and John walked on the plane and some of us said, `Good heavens, is that one of those pansies walking on this plane?' of course we got a very quick response from John Panizza because one thing you could never call John was a pansy. He was a tough bloke, a straight shooter and a hard worker. He was a good bloke.
He will be sadly missed by the parliament, his constituents but, more importantly, he will be sadly missed by his wife and his family. On behalf of me and my wife, Shirley, I do pass on my condolences to Coral and to their family.
Mr WILLIAMS
(Tangney—
Attorney‐General and Minister for Justice)
(5.49 p.m.)
—I would like to add a brief contribution to this condolence debate. I had not really met John Panizza significantly before I came to parliament. I had my closest association with him, I think as many others did, on aeroplanes. He was always a pleasant companion to travel with, and that is saying something because often the trips are four and five hours long and not many people pass the four or four hour test. He did with flying colours.
He was a man of truth, a very upright person, who always behaved in exactly the same manner no matter what the environment. Mr Speaker, you will have seen him in the party room. You will have seen him on close circuit television in the Senate. I have seen him in other environments—in Liberal Party meetings in Western Australia. He was exactly the same person wherever he was. He always spoke his mind. He always argued his
case as well as he could and he always put the public interest to the forefront in everything he said.
He and I share one factor in common. I was born and grew up in East Fremantle and have been effectively a lifetime supporter of the WA Football League in East Fremantle. He was much more closely associated with the club than I over a long period. I was not aware of that until relatively recently. But his closest association in WA was obviously with the Southern Cross area.
I attended the annual general meeting of the Liberal Party branch in Southern Cross at his invitation and it was a sight to behold. Politics were extremely well organised in Southern Cross. Most of the people who were on the committee seemed to have either one of two surnames. One of them was Panizza and the other was another name of Italian extraction. They ran the Liberal Party in Southern Cross very effectively.
John had very strong support in that area—in fact, in all of Western Australia. He had very strong support in the Liberal Party in Western Australia and he returned that support with the efforts he put in. I, too, extend my sympathy to Coral and the family. It is a very sad event that someone has been taken when they had so much more to contribute.
Question resolved in the affirmative, honourable members standing in their places.
Kelly, Hon. Charles Robert, CMG
Debate resumed.
Mr McLACHLAN
(Barker—
Minister for Defence)
(5.52 p.m.)
—I would like to add a few words to those of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard), the Leader of the National Party (Mr Tim Fischer) and the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) made early this afternoon. I have known Bert Kelly for nearly 30 years and his wife and some of his children for some of that time. I do not really remember him in the parliament, but I do remember him for most of those years at rural meetings of one sort or another.
I knew, as most of us did, that the first man on his feet at the end of a speech that he did not like would be Bert Kelly, that he would
have a biting, short, succinct question but that that question would come at the end of a long, disarming, smiling, preamble which would go on for just as long as the chairman allowed—and I have known it to have gone on for 15 or more minutes. But I think one of the great attributes of Bert Kelly in putting his view—and it was always about protection, which he did not like at all, and, I might say, about protection in the agricultural industries, which he was very fond of as well, so he was not just taking on the manufacturers or his conventional enemies—was always that he did it so pleasantly, so smilingly and so disarmingly.
I happened to agree with the general thrust of his argument but, whatever you thought, you could not escape the smile and you could not escape the dedication to the subject and his mischievous way of getting the point over, sometimes to the discomfort of his friends. I think it is a well‐known story that, in 1975, Bert Kelly called a quorum while he was speaking, as the Melbourne Cup was in the process of being run. The Labor government was forced to attend while the opposition watched the completion of the race. I am told that Fred Daly, who was known for his occasional flutter on the horses, never forgave Bert for that and was heard to say so on many occasions.
But, in the following year, when the Melbourne Cup had been won by a New Zealand horse, Bert asked a question without notice in the House. He did not have time to forewarn the then Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, who is now the Prime Minister. The question was:
Because of the consistently strong competition from New Zealand, will the Minister see what can be done to put a tariff on New Zealand horses in order to prevent them running faster than our home‐produced horses?
Mr Howard said at the beginning of his answer:
The question catches me very much off balance.
So much so in fact that Speaker Snedden, at the end of the minister's reply, said:
I am afraid the Minister weighed in light.
So Bert got his point over extremely well, as I said, sometimes to the discomfort of his friends.
I think he has had more influence on the discussion over protection than anybody else since the war and, as he exercised most of that influence by either writing in the dailies or rural journals or as a backbencher, that is no mean feat. Perhaps I could just finish by saying that in the last part of one of his books he said:
When I left parliament at the end of 1977 I naturally thought that I would not receive many invitations to speak at meetings . . . Recently I was preening myself because speaking invitations were still coming in and when Lorna—
his wife—
brought me down to earth by saying that the main reasons for these invitations was that I had a Gold Pass, so people knew that they did not have to pay my travelling expenses, I am afraid she is right, as usual.
I did not disagree with Bert Kelly very often, but I disagree in part with that view because really it was the very entertaining, delightful but very strong way that he put his argument that got him invited to many of those meetings. Perhaps the gold pass helped, but I think it was probably in that order.
Having been to the funeral service last week, at which 300 or 400 people turned up—and, as we have heard earlier, some very eminent people at that—I know those people were very pleased that they were able to get there. We all know that Lorna and the Kelly family are extremely proud of Bert Kelly, and so they should be.
Dr KEMP
(Goldstein—
Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training and Minister Assisting the Minister for Finance for Privatisation)
(5.57 p.m.)
—Bert Kelly demonstrated very convincingly the `power of one'—the power of one idea pursued with single‐mindedness by one person, the heart and the mind acting together. There are very few in the parliament who can retire with the recognition that they have influenced significantly the outcome of one of the very big policy debates that this country has faced. It has been said several times in this condolence motion that Bert,
through his impact on the debate over tariffs and the liberalisation of trade, was one of the very rare people able to do this.
I was honoured last year to be asked by the Centre for Independent Studies to deliver the Bert Kelly Lecture. Bert was already too ill to be able to attend, but I had had the privilege of talking with him over many years as a parliamentary staff member and as a member of parliament. When I organised a seminar of the Modest Members in 1995 in Sydney, he was there even though it was then evident that his health was failing. If he could come, he would come. That was one of the great things about Bert, that even when he left parliament he never lost that determination to support the causes that he believed in.
It is probably a mistake to attribute too much influence to one man, even someone as persuasive as Bert Kelly. There were, after all, very powerful forces pushing Australia towards trade liberalisation internationally, and other influential players on the Australian scene. But, when all is said and done, Bert Kelly's influence in the parliament and the inspiration that he gave to other contributors to the policy debate was very large. The strength and character of purpose that enabled him to do this was exceptional. Perhaps it can be traced to his Methodist upbringing in South Australia, perhaps to the fact that his father, W.S. `Stan' Kelly OBE, had been a full‐time member of the Commonwealth Tariff Board from 1929 to 1940. The board, after all, had been established to protect the public from the pressures of special interests—that was the purpose of the Tariff Board, not to hand out tariffs indiscriminately—and I am quite sure that Bert imbibed a lot of perspectives and principles from his father at the family dinner table over the years. Doubtless it was this sort of background that made him alert to the moral problems that arise when politicians start making decisions to advantage one section of the community at the expense of all the other sections of the community.
I believe that Bert's great achievement was to demonstrate the commonsense of lower tariffs and freer trade. This was an extraordinary achievement because, as the Prime
Minister (Mr Howard) said earlier, this was directly contrary to the conventional wisdom at the time when he began to pursue these issues. He did not pursue lower tariffs and freer trade as a theoretical position. He left that to Eccles in his columns. He always took the very practical position that lower tariffs would deliver real and very obvious benefits in the form of lower costs and expanded demand for the products of his farming constituents and others.
Mavis, the long suffering politician's wife—and we all have our Mavises, I suppose, one way or another—Fred, his farmer friend, and Eccles, his academic adviser who championed cool analysis over emotion: these characters really charmed the many thousands of readers of his column `Modest member of parliament'. In that column, time after time he assailed the fantasy that high tariffs can create sustainable jobs. He showed again and again that tariffs just forced consumers and families to give more of their money to some fortunate beneficiaries at the expense of jobs in other businesses and that those who suffered most from the inflated prices produced by tariffs were the lower income sections of the community—many in the farming community, those on benefits, pensioners and retired people.
Now, after several decades of Bert's influence, we recognise that there are very few jobs in the Australian economy still dependent upon tariffs. The jobs that are coming into existence at the moment are jobs which can stand on their own in the global economy. Australia is stronger and more secure as a result. We have Bert Kelly to thank for that. I think we all owe a great debt of gratitude to him for his persistence and his strength over those years. I extend my sympathy to Lorna and to Bert's three sons—Anthony, Roger and Kim—on their loss.
Mr SINCLAIR
(New England)
(6.03 p.m.)
—Like others in this House, I knew and liked Bert Kelly. Unlike those others who have spoken, I really saw him and worked with him in the parliament and in the party room. I really wanted to give a little bit of the background that has not come out in the contributions to date.
Firstly, I think it needs to be remembered that for a long period in the Menzies government the debates in the party room were at least as significant as in the parliament. As our own Prime Minister (Mr Howard) commented this morning in our own joint party room, Sir Robert—certainly as Mr Menzies—with his eyebrows rather dominated the proceedings. There was quite a marked gulf between those who had been senior ministers over the years and people like Bert Kelly.
Another facet of that period was that the Tariff Board was constituted as a dispassionate and independent body, designed to allow the consideration of the level of tariffs and to do it on a basis which took account not only of economics but also of employment and, supposedly, the economic consequences of any tariff that might have been proposed.
Bert Kelly—certainly from his father but also through his association with Alf Rattigan, Dick Boyer and others on the Tariff Board—inevitably, in the party room as in the parliament, presented a case that was not emotional. It was not just presented on the bare facts of the theory of whether or not there should be a tariff. Probably to greater degree that I suspect many in this House these days do, he picked out the detail, analysed the figures and analysed the product of any recommendation.
I noticed John Stone mentioned in his column the other day Bert's contribution to the debate on many occasions was at least as good and often better than the Tariff Board recommendation. Bert had the advantage of having read the tariff report. Having picked up those people who made contributions to the board, he would contact them and go through the issue. By the time the debate was presented, either in the party room or in the parliament, it was always just slightly better than the report itself.
I noticed the Prime Minister in his observations talked about Bert and his wry humour in his contributions. Quite often when there was a Tariff Board debate there was very little humour because, as a result of Bert's analysis, it would be strictly a numerical presentation and one that was not always easy to follow. The conclusions and the way in which he reached those decisions certainly
demonstrated a very soft mannered but determined and persuasive person.
There is little doubt that Bert was very much the parliamentary voice of those who felt that the time had come for a fundamental revision of Australian tariffs. I think all of us who worked with him admired and respected the way he pursued, both in the party room where there were significant political heavyweights against him and in the parliament, a cause which was not always popular.
Secondly, I want to briefly mention that Bert was always very deprecating in the way in which he presented himself. Several have mentioned his humour, and his Modest Member column was there was for us all to see. I can remember quite well some occasions when we had some quite strong debates in the party room about naval acquisitions. I remember one of the members had made a fairly profound argument about the case for bigger ships for the Australian navy. Bert said, `I do not know. I suppose an admiral needs a decent cabin, but I did think there were other reasons why we bought battleships and warships.' He also commented, `I suppose even admirals need something to play with in the bath.'
The way in which he approached what could be a fundamental decision—in this case, it was looking at future acquisitions for the Royal Australian Navy—was by deprecating himself by his understanding of the subject and then suddenly showing not only did he know all about it but also he was on top of the numbers and on top of the argument. As a result, his case was always very persuasive.
While I note the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) in his observations suggested that Bert should never have been a minister, I think one of the advantages that Bert had as a minister was that he was actually able to put in place that very significant analytical capability that characterised so much of his performance. In his contribution the Deputy Prime Minister, Tim Fischer, mentioned Bert's interest in the standard gauge railway. One of the things Bert did was not only look at the employment and at the tariffs but also look at the infrastructure.
Bert was one of those who very forcefully advocated a total analysis of the costs of production and delivery. As a farmer, of course, he was only too well aware of the cost of delivering grain and other produce in South Australia, but he certainly was a very forceful advocate to have on side as I had at the time of the completion of the Indian Pacific and the Trans‐Australia standard gauge railway. Bert was one of those who also helped in the development of the standard gauge railway to Alice Springs where, again, we badly needed to look at the cost of providing a service which at that stage was grossly inefficient and, in parts, was subject to flooding which delayed the service to an inordinate degree.
I regarded Bert Kelly as a great Australian. He certainly made a contribution in parliament. He made a contribution in the party room. As a journalist, as several have said, I think his memory will live long because he wrote precisely, concisely and to the point. I would also like to extend my own personal sympathy to Lorna and his family. As I did not speak to the John Panizza motion, I would also like my personal sympathy to go to Coral and her family.
Mr ANDREW
(Wakefield)
(6.09 p.m.)
—I was honoured to represent the Speaker at the funeral service for Charles Robert Kelly, which was held in Wesley Uniting Church, Kent Town, on 24 January. Bert Kelly was a former member for Wakefield, as everyone knows. I suspect he was one of those South Australian federal members of whom the whole state is proud.
Bert Kelly was unique, and he was unique for one reason: he entered this parliament, the national parliament, with a national perspective. I suspect most of us tend to come here having to acquire a national perspective, but Bert came knowing what the nation needed. He was determined to pursue what he felt was in the nation's best interests ahead of what may have been an immediate parochial interest. His objective was national. He entered the parliament with a national view of Australia, and that in many ways made him quite unique.
He always claimed to have been a reluctant politician. Any who have read his books will know that he said he was drafted into Wakefield and that, in fact, he did not even know whether he was a member of the Liberal Party or not when he was first invited to stand. I suspect there may be just a little editorial licence in all of that. I also suspect that, while he may claim to have been a reluctant politician, the truth is he loved this place and he loved his role as the member for Wakefield. What happened, remarkably, was that he never ceased to be a farmer. Whether he was a minister of the Crown or a well-known columnist and journalist, he was first and foremost a farmer representing the farmers of Wakefield and identifying with the family property Merrindie, which is near Tarlee in South Australia's mid‐north.
I would call Bert Kelly my mentor. He came into this parliament, however, with a mentor of his own—Charles Hawker, who had been a former member for Wakefield between 1929 and 1938 when he was tragically killed in an aircraft disaster over Melbourne. Charles Hawker was a courageous and unselfish politician who had been severely wounded during World War I and who represented Wakefield vigorously in spite of his severe war wounds. He had a reputation in the parliament for his courage and for his preparedness to speak up on any issue, whether popular or unpopular. He was recognised as a man certainly headed to the ministry and possibly to the prime ministership prior to his untimely death.
He had, as everyone who has read Bert Kelly's books will know, a profound influence on the then young Bert Kelly and on what he saw as Bert Kelly's role if he were to be a responsible South Australian. I was very pleased that the member for Wannon, David Hawker, who I think is a great nephew of Sir Charles Hawker, was able to be present at Bert Kelly's funeral.
Bert entered the parliament, as the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) said, in 1958 as the member for Wakefield to succeed the retiring Sir Philip McBride. He came in with a particular view of tariffs and of the Tariff Board—largely as a result of a lifetime of
exposure to the views of his father, the late Stan Kelly, and, as other members have mentioned, Stan Kelly's involvement on the Commonwealth Tariff Board.
Bert had pursued this particular philosophy prior to entering parliament through the columns that he had written initially in farming journals under the title
Dave's Diary
and then as a backbencher under the pseudonym the Modest Member, which was to be followed by the pseudonym Modest Farmer when he was no longer in parliament.
As others have said, particularly the member for New England (Mr Sinclair), my predecessor had this great capacity to illustrate fundamental truths in a way that people wanted to read and discover more about. He used the characters of his column to bring all of what Bert believed alive and to bring it alive in a way that really meant something to those who were reading it. So all sorts of fundamental truths about tariffs and the impact of tariffs were widely read not only across South Australia and through the farming journals but also through the
Financial Review
and other publications that ran Bert's causes.
What had been an unpopular cause, the cause of lowering tariffs around Australia, became increasingly the cause picked up by farmers as they recognised what the real cost of tariff barriers had been. Let no-one underestimate the fortitude and determination needed by Bert Kelly to pursue this course when it was not a popular course and was largely resisted by most in the parliament.
Bert served the parliament as the deputy whip, as the chairman of the public works committee, as the Minister for Works and as the Minister for the Navy. It is true that he was defeated by my immediate predecessor, Mr Geoffrey O'Halloran Giles, at a preselection battle in 1977. However, if I might be so bold to suggest, the Prime Minister was just a little wrong when he created the impression that Bert may have lost preselection because of the responsibilities that he had as a minister and the time that he had spent focusing on the tariff battle which, in the Prime Minister's words, meant that he may have neglected his branches.
As someone who was living close to the seat of Wakefield at that time, I don't think anyone could ever accuse Bert of having neglected his branches, because he simply loved to be out among the farming community. What happened in 1977 was that there was a redistribution and the seat of Angas, which included the Riverland area, ceased to exist and became amalgamated into the seat of Wakefield. Mr Geoffrey O'Halloran Giles, who had been the member for Angus, chose, not surprisingly, to preselect for the seat of Wakefield. Mr Giles brought with him a number of people who had a particularly protected view of society. I know it well—and so, by the way, does the member for Barker (Mr McLachlan). Having brought those votes with him, he raised the threshold to a point which it was more difficult for the then member for Wakefield, Mr Kelly, to clear.
I was at that preselection—I remember it well. And I remember, after the result had been announced, Mr Kelly saying that he felt like a slave set free. I think he was very sorry to lose the battle, because there were a number of issues that he felt had still been unresolved. But what he had underestimated was the degree to which the work he had already done had laid the ground rules for the tariff battle to be won.
It was in retirement from parliament—as he pursued his column as the then Modest Farmer—that he saw the fruition of all that he had sought to achieve during the 19 years that he had spent in the federal parliament and in the years leading up to it. He kept alive his columns; he kept alive his advocacy for free trade and for the lowering of protection. He gained a great deal of self‐satisfaction, I am pleased to say, out of the result that he saw as the popular economic view turned to advocate that which he had long stood for.
I want to say just a couple of things because I believe one of the areas that has been neglected in the tributes so sincerely paid to this former member for Wakefield is that too little has been made of the role of Lorna, his wife, in what was Bert Kelly's success.
Bert married Lorna in 1936. It is said that she was sent to the little Giles Corner School
near Tarlee effectively to help her brother, who had just been appointed as the school principal and probably the only member of the school staff. The Kelly farm, so Bert tells us, ran down to Giles Corner and a triangular paddock adjoined the school. Bert would have us all believe that that triangular paddock was worked more thoroughly than any other paddock on the entire farm as he went about courting Lorna during school hours and, of course, after school hours. Whatever the real reason, the facts are that he married Lorna and they raised three sons of whom they are intensely proud—Tony, Kim and Roger—and their children and grandchildren are very much a part of the Kelly family. We would do Bert's memory a disservice if we didn't acknowledge the importance to Bert of the family and the importance to Bert of Lorna, who both kept his feet on the ground and kept the objective of tariff reductions clearly in his sights.
With great respect, may I say that the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) did Lorna something of an unintentional disservice when he mentioned that Mavis may have in some way resembled Lorna. There is no similarity at all between the character Mavis in Bert's column and Lorna, the lady I know as a courageous partner to Bert who, as I said, kept his feet on the ground and kept advancing the cause in which they both so passionately believed. Much of what they did is so well portrayed in the final book that Bert wrote, entitled
Merrindie: A Family's Farm
.
It is significant, when I talk about Bert as the family man, that all three sons paid a tribute to their father at the funeral service; that they all referred to their father not so much as the man who had been so successful in the advocacy of lower tariffs, but as the man who had been their father and had kept the tradition of family life alive and well. I think it was Kim who read a poem that Lorna had written for Bert on the occasion of his 80th birthday, which touched us all and reminded us of how much she had been involved with his columns, as well as with his object of lowering protection.
It would be fair to say—and I thank the minister, Dr Kemp, for picking this point
up—that Bert wasn't an orator but he was a very effective communicator. He was in demand as a guest speaker across my electorate, certainly up until the last five years when failing health made it more difficult for him to travel. He was in demand not because he was a fluent speaker but because he was a speaker who concisely and effectively got his message across and got it across in a humorous way that everyone remembered.
He expected all of us to be aware of what he believed in and, whether we agreed with it or not, to be consistent in our arguments either in support of his line or opposed to his line. It was consistency that was the hallmark of much of Bert's success. I note that John Hyde, in his tribute to Bert in the
Australian
, said that one of his first memories of Bert had been of him chastening John Hyde because he had used a particular speech on interest rates to take a rather lackadaisical view of what the government ought to be doing. Bert said to John, `Did you really believe that?' and John said, `No, I didn't.' Bert said, `Then why did you say it?' Because from Bert's point of view, if there was something to be advocated, then one ought to be entirely consistent about it and not be concerned about what the short‐term gains or failures would be of that particular course.
I am sorry to be extended about this, but I do want to make a couple of other points. I must pay a tribute to Bert Kelly, not only as the man who stood for free trade and not only as the family man, but as Bert Kelly the farmer. Bert Kelly became a member of the South Australian Soil Conservation Board when it came into being, because he was concerned about the movement of soil and soil erosion on his mid‐north farm. His father had found in Melbourne, as a member of the Tariff Board, a publication that alluded to ways in which soil conservation could be enhanced by contour banking. He mentioned the booklet to his son, who then went searching for it, found it, and introduced contour banks. He used the agricultural bureau movement in South Australia to spread this form of soil conservation, which has now become the norm. His were the first contour banks and on that farm, Merrindie, many field days were
held to see what could be done to minimise soil erosion through contour banking.
He was, as a result of his association with the advisory board and his direct interest in agriculture, a member of the South Australian Advisory Board of Agriculture. He was also selected in 1951 as the first Nuffield scholar to spend six months overseas looking at agricultural practice in the UK. If I may introduce a personal note here, it is something of an amusement to me to report to the parliament that, while Bert was the first Nuffield scholar, my predecessor, Mr Geoffrey O'Halloran Giles, was also a Nuffield scholar, and so was I. So you can imagine I look askance at any of the other Nuffield scholars currently resident in Wakefield.
He successfully served this parliament as the minister for both works and navy. He will, as others have said, be well remembered for his self‐effacing and self‐deprecating manner. Wherever Bert went in the electorate he was welcome. Today he is remembered as one of the most colourful and effective members for Wakefield. The great message for us all is that, although his time in parliament was largely spent on the backbench, he so effectively changed a nation's view of what had been a particular philosophy for economics.
Let me conclude by picking up the point made by the Leader of the Opposition when he read from the letter that former Prime Minister the Hon. Gough Whitlam had sent to him. It referred to Bert's humour, in that Bert had selected as one of the hymns for his funeral service the hymn entitled
They who tread the path of labour
. I think I will do the
Hansard
record justice only if I read the first verse of that hymn. It says, by the way:
They who tread the path of labour follow where my feet have trod,
They who work without complaining do the holy will of God.
The funeral service was marked by the sort of humour that only the Kelly boys could introduce when they made available to any who were there copies of the book
Merrindie: a family's farm
. They said that while that ran counter to father's economic rationalisation, it would be the best tribute any of us could have to his memory. Many people who had
not already accessed this book did so. Many of you, like me, were in receipt of Burt's books. He would send you one in the post and say, `Read it and, if you like it, send me $6. If you don't, keep it anyway.' It seemed to be a very effective method of spreading these books and his information and philosophy not only around the electorate but around the nation.
I am indebted to a man who has made being identified with the seat and the term member for Wakefield something of which I can be justly proud.
Mr HAWKER
(Wannon)
(6.26 p.m.)
—I would like to join with others in this condolence motion. I think some very fine words have been said here today by many of the speakers, starting with the Prime Minister (Mr Howard), and including other ministers and the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley). I would especially like to commend the current member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew) for the very thoughtful, very well researched and very meaningful presentation that he made here in memory of Bert Kelly. I think it was something quite special. I think all of us are greatly inspired and impressed by what he had to say.
Much has been said about Bert Kelly's contribution to the parliament. I would like to briefly go through a few things about the way he did, indeed, take what at the time was a non‐conventional view for many—an unpopular view, in many eyes—and worked on changing the attitude of the decision makers of this nation. I think it was an amazing achievement not only because of the fact that he did so but also because of the perseverance that it took. The changes had to occur over many decades, and yet Bert persevered all the way and never lost sight of what he was trying to achieve. I think in latter years it was probably with quite a lot of satisfaction that he saw what had been achieved. I know from some conversations I had with him that he really felt that many of the things that he had said had finally been vindicated.
He was always highly respected, as others have said. He was always highly regarded. Another great achievement, as has been alluded to, is the fact that he contributed a
total of 898 columns to various newspapers and other journals during his time. He ran Modest Member, Modest Farmer, Dave's Diary and other articles. It shows that he did have a huge commitment. Those who have read those articles always noted two things, amongst others. First, they were always easy to read and easy to understand. Secondly, they always had a strong message in them. As he said himself, he had to be sure of his facts because he knew there were plenty of others around ready to tear him apart. I think that the fact that the columns continued to be popular for so long and were read by such a wide audience shows that Bert really did have quite a gift in the way he could express himself, particularly in those columns.
As has been mentioned by the current member for Wakefield, I do have a personal association with, firstly, the seat of Wakefield and, secondly, with Bert Kelly, because of the late Charles Hawker. Bert often cited Charles Hawker as being someone who inspired him to undertake not only his role in public life but also to adopt many of the views that he held. I would have to say that I am very proud of that association. One of the things that always encouraged me was the fact that Bert often spoke so highly of the late Charles Hawker and of his achievements during the time when he was in parliament.
I would also like to say how encouraging I found Bert. I first got to know Bert when I came into parliament. I can remember not long afterwards joining the Liberal Party's federal rural committee, an organisational committee. One of the things that I think was quite unique about that committee—amongst many others—is that if you look through the minutes of that period you will see that under `attendance' there are three lines. Members of the committee are listed on the first line and parliamentary observers on the second line. Then there is a third line which just says `Bert Kelly'. It was always like that. That was the regard that Bert was held in. He was a life member, if you like, of the federal rural committee from that time until he was no longer able to attend. It was assumed that Bert would always be there. He would come as often as he could. He would not try to impose
his views but, nonetheless, he was always there to offer some advice. Occasionally he would make sure that the committee kept on the straight and narrow, as he saw it. I think his views were always greatly appreciated.
The member for Barker (Mr McLachlan) alluded to the time in 1975 when Bert was speaking on his lonesome in the parliament during the running of the Melbourne Cup, so I will not repeat that story. The member for Barker went on to talk about Bert's role at public meetings and at Outlook conferences. I can well recall going to Outlook conferences—the local one is on today—where Bert would be sitting not at the front but right up the back. Those who have been to Outlook conferences will know that the lights are reasonably good at the front, but up the back it is not that easy to see anyone. And yet the chairman would be sitting, looking up there, waiting for the end of the speech, to see Bert. Generally Bert got the first call. Of course, that was an experienced chairman. He would let Bert have his three or four minutes, and then he would say, `Okay, now, Mr Kelly. You had a question, didn't you?' It was always put in such a polite way and it was always taken in such a polite way. I think it shows the sort of standing Bert had that, at those conferences, he was always recognised and always given the chance to put his point of view. It was welcomed there because of the incisive and yet very polite way he could put that point of view.
Australia has lost a very fine man—someone who made a tremendous contribution to public life over a very long period of time, someone who also set very high standards and very high ideals for himself in the way he cared for his family. As the current member for Wakefield has pointed out, when his family spoke of him at his funeral they showed that the thing that they admired the most was the way he thought of his family first and foremost. I, like others, would like to extend to Lorna, his sons, Tony, Kim and Roger, and their children my deepest sympathy. We have lost a great person, but we have very great memories.
Sitting suspended from 6.31 p.m. to 8 p.m.
Mr TUCKEY
(O'Connor)
(8.00 p.m.)
—Due to other commitments, I will be brief tonight, but I did want to put on record my association with Bert Kelly and my great admiration for the man and his achievements. It would not be known to many, but Bert is probably a substantial contributing factor to my being in this place. Prior to my election to the federal parliament, I lived in a remote town called Carnarvon where the
Financial Review
was an almost unheard of publication. I eventually decided that, as a hotel keeper in that town, my education needed to be expanded a little bit beyond that place which many of us did not leave from year to year because it was so difficult to get anywhere else, having no sealed roads for quite a period of the time that I lived there. So I went to the local newsagent and ordered the
Financial Review
. I think they had to consult their records to find out where you bought that particular paper. It always arrived two or three days late.
To me, in those days, reading a newspaper was absolute luxury. In fact, I still have twinges of remorse when I sit down of a morning to read the newspaper as part of my duties, because in those days it was a great luxury. I get a feeling of guilt, so I wait till probably Sunday to catch up with half a dozen issues of the
Financial Review
. It was there that I discovered the Modest Member who, in later years, became the Modest Farmer. It became a fact of life that, early in the piece, I turned to the Kelly articles first when they appeared because I was so convinced of his logic.
I am sure that those words had a great effect on my thinking when I came to this place. Bert Kelly not only addressed the tariff issue but also seemed to be able to put down that commentary on the politics of the day in a way, as others have mentioned, that was very easy to read and understand for a backwoods boy like me. The realities were that the views of Eccles, Mavis and Fred were all put succinctly. There was balance within the argument because each had a different point of view. I tended to find myself siding with Eccles and of course what Bert was saying in the background.
It was a great time for me when I arrived in the parliament in October 1980. As others have reported, Bert had by then retired due to his lost preselection. I came up very promptly and found myself amongst his disciples. Some people have mentioned that he had some influence over John Hyde. I think it was more a fixation. Hyde, Peter Shack, Jim Carlton and a few of the others were quite clearly Bert Kelly disciples and carried on his message in a very vigorous way after his departure.
I think, in contrast to John Panizza, we can say of Bert that, having died in his eighties, he had a fortunate life. To last that long and, until the very later years, to enjoy an active and intellectual life, as he always did to the end, I think made Bert himself a fortunate man, particularly because, having had a long life, he actually lived long enough to see the fruits of his endeavours.
It is quite remarkable that, notwithstanding the fact that he left the parliament and could no longer contribute directly in that fashion, he carried on. His disciples formed the Modest Members Society, of which I am a proud member. Bert was a regular visitor to some of our functions and kept our interests fired up. Not many of us in the federal scene have had a task of such magnitude to shift public opinion that far and to see the success of our efforts prior to our demise. Bert was very fortunate in all of that.
In saying those things, I recognise, as I do with John Panizza's family, that the loss of a loved one, such as Bert or John, is always a great shock even when it occurs in later years. We send to the families of John and Bert our sincerest regrets. None of us really like to think that they will ever lose loved ones, but we do.
I think Bert did have a fortunate life. He was a great contributor to Australia. He was an opinion maker and somebody who, in my view, did something that I aspire to—and that was to tell the king he is not wearing any clothes, and Bert without doubt did that. He explained and proved to Australians, to members of parliament, that there was no substance to the views they held in those days. They were commonly held and they
were probably believed by most. But, of course, the effect that tariffs and other things were supposed to have did not really materialise—they just taught us to be lazy—and Bert was the advocate of all that.
I would like to close by recording my great support for a great man. The parliament has had others, but Bert's contribution was outstanding in a very significant area. What comes after disciples? There is a lesser row of people. I am afraid I am probably one of them. But I was glad to be amongst the Peter Shacks, the Jim Carltons, the John Hydes and others who so actively carried on. I might add that at the time our present Prime Minister (Mr Howard) might have been in my category—a bit more of a fellow traveller—but we were certainly all there arguing those particular issues and recognising the need for change.
Bert was a shining light and he will not be forgotten. I do extend my sympathies to his family. Notwithstanding his long life, people never like to lose their loved ones.
Mr McARTHUR
(Corangamite)
(8.07 p.m.)
—I would like to join the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) and yourself, Mr Deputy Speaker Andrew, in your excellent contribution on the life of Bert Kelly. Bert Kelly, as other members have said, made a magnificent contribution in the field of ideas both to this parliament and to Australia. He was always cheerful and he had great courage at a time when conventional ideas were very much against the arguments that he was putting forward in terms of tariffs and market economies.
Before I came to the parliament I used to have long discussions with Tony Street, the former member for Corangamite, about the ideas of Bert Kelly, his influence on the party room and the way in which he put those simple ideas to convince the prime ministers and the cabinet that maybe their ideas and their policies were incorrect. I well recall the story of Bert Kelly advocating in the party room that under the hen act in South Australia you were a professional hen operator if you had more than 25 hens. So he demonstrated in the party room that when you had 24 hens you were still a private operator and were not
part of the regulation, but if you had 26 hens you were then part of the South Australian government's regulatory regime and you had to pay all the levies associated with the poultry act.
After, in the party room he demonstrated with a piece of wire catching the last hen around the header. In his usual humorous way he had clearly identified the argument that the regulation of the poultry act in South Australia would not work, and there were many farmers in the seat of Wakefield who obviously were not conforming with that particular regulation.
Tony Street and I used to argue quite strongly and agree on the merits of those very powerful debates in those years when it was contrary to the wisdom of the day, with Black Jack McEwen advocating the higher and higher tariff barrier and, in my view, selling out country people. It was a lonely existence for Bert Kelly because—as other speakers have said, and the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) demonstrated it quite ably—Bert Kelly in the party room was generally against the whole conventional wisdom of the Liberal Party, and the National Party in particular at that time, yet he pursued the argument itself and the ideas of lower protection and a more efficient market economy.
The major argument of the farmers and the miners was that they were the producers of real wealth in Australia, yet the tariff redistributed that wealth to the manufacturers, who thought they were being protected from other so-called predators on the international market. That was of course linked in with the centralised wage fixing system, which said that people in the manufacturing sector were entitled to be paid the basic wage.
As other people have said, the Modest Member articles that appeared in the
Australian Financial Review
and other publications around Australia had a major influence in the way in which they were put in such a humorous manner. Some 898 articles I think were produced. The honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) said he read them in the back blocks of Australia and was influenced by the erudite economic wisdom that
those articles portrayed, influencing both country people and I think the bureaucrats in Canberra. The freer trade and the clarity of his views I think are the key features that he leaves with Australia and the parliament. He pursued those arguments because he felt—and he had researched the points of view and the statistics that gave very conclusive proof—that tariffs did no good for average Australians.
As other members have mentioned, the Society of Modest Members was formed in 1981 by Jim Carlton, John Hyde and others who wanted to develop the general concept that there should be a freer market economy and that tariffs were not conducive to a better economic Australia. It was on that basis that the Society of Modest Members was formed. It was a group that developed in Canberra and comprised like‐minded souls within the coalition. It now has like‐minded souls in every state around Australia and has a very strong membership which debates these matters, even though Bert Kelly is no longer with us.
As the deputy chairman of that society, I regard it as a great honour to be part of that ongoing legacy of Bert Kelly. The arguments range over issues such as the market economy, privatisation, deregulation and the ongoing tariff debate which is with us here in 1997. Under the diligent and excellent chairmanship of Len Bosman, the member for St George from 1963 to 1969, the society continues to provide an open forum for people who wish to look at the various ideas that might help and shape government policy on both sides of the parliament. So the legacy of Bert Kelly will continue through the Society of Modest Members, where people will openly and honestly debate the issues of the day with an orientation towards a market economy, lower tariffs and an opening up of trade throughout the world.
