It was a sad day in many ways when a number of us attended the funeral in Adelaide just 10 days ago as a mark of respect to a great life and a great contribution to the debate of ideas both in the parliament and in rural Australia. I acknowledge the fact that former Prime Minister Gough Whitlam was
present at the funeral. He, by his mere presence there and in the conversation I had with him, also recognised the contribution of Bert Kelly to the debate on both sides of the parliament and I think he—in reducing the tariff barrier by 25 per cent in one hit, in 1973, I think—recognised the very inadequate nature of the tariff barrier and the troubles it had caused in Australia.
Finally, we will all miss Bert Kelly—his famous case with `CRK' written on the side of it, as the honourable member for Wakefield will recall, his cheerful disposition, the way in which he presented a very compelling case to any meeting he attended and just that cheerful, humorous approach to a number of the arguments that persuaded the academics, the farmers and many of the political writers around Australia of the truthfulness of his proposition. So, on behalf of the Society of Modest Members, I express our deepest sympathy to his wife, Lorna, who had been his lifelong friend, supporter and adviser, and family who were there at that very moving service in Adelaide. Australia and the parliament have lost a very distinguished Australian who in many ways has made a lasting contribution to the changing climate of ideas and policies that have been developed in this parliament and throughout Australia.
Mr WAKELIN
(Grey)
(8.15 p.m.)
—I rise tonight out of respect for Bert Kelly and to recite a few instances where he touched my life, just as he touched thousands and, in an indirect way, millions of Australians. Like you, Mr Deputy Speaker, I share common ground with the electorates of Wakefield and Grey where they have varied their boundaries over the years. Therefore, some of the constituents who were Bert Kelly's constituents and your constituents are now my constituents.
One of my first memories of Bert Kelly—I did not know him as that at the time—was when I was a young boy on the farm and my father would get the weekly
Stock Journal
. Reading the
Stock Journal
was pretty serious business, but every week there would be this burst of laughter as my father perused `Dave's Diary', where Bert spun his famous web of words.
Perhaps my next memory of Bert was when he was a guest speaker at the Kimba Liberal Party branch. I was charged with the duty of going to Whyalla to pick up Bert. The hour that I travelled over a dirt road with Bert I guess fundamentally changed my life. We called into home on what was a pretty hot day. A cup of water was about all Bert needed to keep him going, and then he went into the meeting. His speaking style always gave messages in a very clear manner. When he got a hostile question from the crowd, he would simply say, `Well, how would you like to be a politician fronting up to all the various issues that politicians face up to?' He was that blunt and said things straight off the chest. You could not help but feel the integrity and the directness of the man.
I have a whole range of experiences of Bert in public meetings and all the rest of it. I will not dwell on them too long because, if he were here, he would talk about me giving tongue too long. But I have a couple of other memories that will stay with me forever. He had a wonderful saying that the trouble with the milk of human kindness is too much of it ends up on the cowshed floor. Bert was always able to bring that mixture of head and heart to the debate.
About three or four years ago, after Bert had left the parliament but I had entered it, I was going around the Wayville showgrounds and there was Bert. I did not think he would recognise me, a mere humble backbencher, but of course he did. He said g'day and asked how it was going. We had just lost the 1993 election, and he asked how this fella was going and that fella was going and about one thing or another. I said in relation to a particular individual who will remain nameless that I did not think he was enjoying it that much after the loss. Bert said to me, as quick as a flash, `You're not supposed to enjoy it, boy. What do you think this is?' That spirit of `you are here to do a job, not have fun' will stay with me, and that job involved tariffs.
Another part of my life which touched Bert's involved the Northern Territory and his interests in the north. As a young man I worked at Tipperary Station, and Bert paid it
a visit around that time. In one of his books he mentions the development of the north.
My final comment tonight is that Bert leaves us with a fine spirit of bipartisanship on this issue. The fact that Mr Gough Whitlam was at his funeral service and that Labor Prime Minister Mr Chifley visited the farm at Tarlee to be with Bert Kelly's father after the war showed the ability of Bert Kelly and his family to cross over the partisan boundaries in the national interest. In a book by Rattigan there are some fine words about the Tariff Board and about the integrity needed in this economic debate and which Bert Kelly gave Australia.
Ms WORTH
(Adelaide)
(8.20 p.m.)
—I would like to take part in this condolence motion tonight and to express my sympathy to the family and friends of Bert Kelly. Others, like you, Mr Deputy Speaker Andrew, have made significant contributions. I would like to speak briefly tonight and think it is appropriate to do so because the sacred sites that were the Kelly family sites were also my own family sites. When the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) spoke earlier today, he referred to Bert Kelly having being born at Riverton. My father was born at Riverton and so was I. The rolling hills referred to by the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Tim Fischer) were hills between Tarlee and Riverton, and that was Kelly country and McInerney country.
When I was growing up, Bert Kelly was my local federal member. I recall him speaking at a public meeting at the Riverton Institute. I recall `Dave's Diary' in the
Stock Journal
, which the member for Grey (Mr Wakelin) has also mentioned, and the stories that my father told. They went to school together and grew up together. They were roughly—within a year or so—the same age. They had competed in horse riding events at the Tarlee Show. My father likes to tell the story about how he won one of those despite the fact that Bert thought he had the better horse.
Bert, as others have said, had a wonderful sense of humour and a very genial nature. When I was elected to this place, I recall him, with a real chuckle, referring to `Vin's daughter being in Canberra'. That was the way he then often referred to me. I think about two
years ago, perhaps slightly more than that, I sat next to him on a plane and he gave me a book about the family farm to take home to Vin. He also told me that he had been invited by the Young Liberals to speak at one of their meetings. I mention that because there would not be all that many people who had been members of this place still being invited by the younger members of their party to speak at meetings.
We all have doorknocking stories to tell and stories of campaigns. One my father often jokes about is Bert telling him how he had been doorknocking for Condor Laucke when he was standing against Molly Byrne in a then state election—before Condor Laucke came to Canberra. Molly Byrne went on to win that election. Having disturbed a shift worker in the day and noting the size and the ferocious way in which the shift worker had answered the door, Bert very quickly said that he was calling on behalf of Molly Byrne and left quickly.
Bert is a legend in his own district. That is what I think is worth mention. The member for Barker (Mr McLachlan) has also said that Bert's family has every right to feel proud of him. I think that is true. While we, tonight and this afternoon, express our sympathy to his family and friends and to his extended family, his children and grandchildren, I think we also should be celebrating a great life. I think that is the way Bert would like to be remembered.
Question resolved in the affirmative, honourable members standing in their places.

Mr CREAN
(Hotham)
(8.27 p.m.)
—It is the intention of the opposition to allow the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) through the House of Representatives. But we indicate that we are concerned about the detail that may be contained in what is proposed here and we believe that the implementation of these proposed measures and the way they are to operate will require some closer attention. We know we will not get that attention in this chamber, because we never get a decent response from the government—in particular, the Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs (Mr Prosser). We saw yet again another appalling performance in question time today by the minister in attempting to say what he was going to do for small business. In this debate we will be foreshadowing action in the Senate to address the detail and the intent of this bill and to satisfy ourselves that it will achieve only its stated aim. I do not believe this approach would have been necessary if the processes of consultation that took place were not the sham we believe they were.
The bill deals with changes to the diesel fuel rebate. As many members of this chamber would be aware, the diesel fuel rebate is a very sensitive issue. It is sensitive because of the cost that is involved and the concentration—and this issue no doubt will be raised by members on the other side of the House; that is, how so few in the mining industry account for the bulk of the spend that is associated with it. But to argue that point misunderstands the size and scale that is necessary in large mining ventures. Underneath all of this it should never be forgotten that what the diesel fuel rebate seeks to do is to correct a distortion in the marketplace brought about by the levying of a fuel excise and the impact it has, as an input to the cost of production, on our primary producing sector.
It is a benefit—a correction if you like—that impacts both in the bush and in mining communities. It is something that was constantly trotted up to us in our 13 years in office by Treasury and Finance for abolition. When they failed on every occasion to secure
the abolition, there were always attempts to whittle it away. We are now at that again.
We on this side of the House believe that this is but the first wave in terms of the government's approach to trying to dismantle the diesel fuel rebate. We know it was a sensitive issue on the occasion of the preparation of the last budget because it went to the very credibility of the leadership of the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Tim Fischer) as Leader of the National Party. We know, for example, because the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr McGauran) admitted it, that the cut in the research and development tax concession from 150 per cent to 125 per cent was the trade‐off for retaining the diesel fuel rebate. In other words, it was the price of retaining Tim Fischer's leadership as Deputy Prime Minister in this chamber.
When you look at the amount of research and development that it has now been indicated will go offshore because of the cuts to research and development, one would have to argue that it was hardly a clever investment. Nevertheless, it again demonstrates the sensitivity of this issue—so sensitive that it was something that the Leader of the National Party, as the most senior member of the junior coalition party, was concerned about in that he saw it as a fundamental test of his leadership and his capacity to deliver.
I think the extent of the sensitivity of this issue is also borne out by the recent indication by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) that it will not be up for cuts again in the coming budget. Within 24 hours of identification in the budget honesty document of the Costello crater—the government's own black hole—and the indication the Treasurer used to suggest that there would be further significant cuts in the forthcoming budget, the diesel fuel rebate was yet again singled out for particular treatment, to be cut, because Treasury had tried it last time and failed. The Treasurer is, as we know, persistent if nothing else, and it is clearly his intention to try and bring these things back. But it is something that the Prime Minister ruled out within 24 hours of the suggestion.
I think it is interesting to look at the statement that the Prime Minister made. He told
reporters in Ballarat that the scheme had already been examined for savings in the lead‐up to last year's budget and he ruled out further cuts to the diesel fuel rebate. He reminded reporters at that particular gathering that changes were made and savings are coming from those changes and that, because they had already been subjected to cuts, they would be exempt from cuts in the forthcoming budget.
It is very interesting, because in question time today we sought to find out the extent to which this standard would be applied to other measures that clearly are in prospect for cuts in the forthcoming budget. If we take the figure of $440 million that is sought to be saved by this measure, that represents over the four‐year period something like a 6.9 per cent cut to the expenditure on the diesel fuel rebate. We asked today whether, since 6.9 per cent is a significant cut vis‐a‐vis the diesel fuel rebate and it is therefore exempted from further cuts, the Prime Minister would rule out further cuts to research and development, which copped a 19 per cent cut in the last budget; would he rule out cuts to the labour market programs; would he rule out further cuts to the ABC—you could go through the list, because all of these areas were the subject of massive cuts in the last budget. But the only thing the Prime Minister so far has indicated a preparedness to rule out is the diesel fuel rebate.
We will persist with this line of questioning because, quite frankly, the Prime Minister cannot have it both ways. He cannot rule one out and not the others. If in fact the test is that significant savings were achieved on the last occasion, it is a test that has got to be applied consistently, if the Treasurer's statement has any meaning and if the justification used by the Prime Minister in relation to the diesel fuel rebate late last week also has any meaning. Again I mention that point to indicate the sensitivity of this issue and why it deserves scrutiny, why we cannot simply assert that what we are doing here is simply tightening up to ensure that people who shouldn't be entitled to it don't get it. We on the opposition side don't quibble with that notion, but we want to ensure that it is being
applied correctly and that it is not a backdoor method to dishonour yet another election promise.
The other area where this has some sensitivity goes to the minister responsible for administering the Customs Act, the Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs. I notice that he is not in the chamber tonight, and little wonder, because we have pursued him on a number of occasions on the issue of conflict of interest. Remember that the minister for customs and excise is a director of and controls Prosser Automotive Engineers, a company in Western Australia that deals in diesel fuel. Here is the man responsible for administering the act that determines the retention, extension and application of the diesel fuel rebate, and yet he is personally a dealer in diesel fuel.
He argues—and I accept his word on this point—that he does not get the diesel fuel rebate himself. That is true, because he is not a user of diesel fuel. But because he supplies diesel fuel to a whole community around the south‐west corner of Western Australia and beyond, clearly it is of significance to his business in supplying that fuel whether or not the diesel fuel rebate is retained and the extent to which it applies.
We are not alleging that Minister Prosser has been a direct beneficiary of the rebate, but rather argue that the indirect benefit he gains at least raises the potential for conflict of interest and that he should have declared that interest when this issue was raised in the cabinet. That is one point at which we argue the minister is against not only normal practice in this place about declaring interests and declaring involvement in the area but also the Prime Minister's code, this new code that the Prime Minister beat his chest about. That was the first statement in this parliament a little under 12 months ago. He came into this place and said, `I'm a different politician. I'm going to raise the standards of parliament. I'm going to insist on a new standard of accountability from my front bench and, therefore, I'm going to produce a code of conduct by which I require them to operate.'
One of those requirements in the code of conduct is that no minister shall retain
directorship in a private company. Here is a complete and blatant breach of the code of conduct by the minister concerned because he is still director and holds the controlling interest in Prosser Automotive Engineers. He does not deny that. The code of conduct is explicit—it says that you cannot retain it—yet the Prime Minister has refused to require him to divest himself of it. That is the first breach of the code of conduct.
The second breach, in my view, is the one that I have already alluded to. Here is the appearance of conflict of interest—a minister that stands to gain indirectly from the extent to which the diesel fuel rebate continues to apply, a minister that has an active interest in understanding who can qualify for it and who can obtain benefit from it because he supplies the product that they are claiming the rebate on. Yet he does not declare that interest.
Contemptuously, we have the minister in this House, time and time again, when we have asked him to explain the conflict and to divest himself of it as the code requires, refusing to do so and the Prime Minister—leaderless, rudderless, without commitment to his code—refusing to act upon it. I think it is another demonstration of just how ineffective and weak a leader our Prime Minister is. This is his code. He has made great play of its importance, yet he refuses to act upon it.
As to the code of conduct itself, I would also like to make the point that we exposed the sham that this code of conduct was back in October of last year, not only in relation to the minister for customs but also in relation to the
the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Senator Vanstone)—the one who invented the Wright family, the family that did not exist—and the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism (Mr Moore), who was dealing in shares in venture capital when he had responsibility for that area.
We had the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Downer), who continues to make a galah of himself overseas, clearly against the national interest in relation to the DIFF scheme when he said that not one foreign government had raised the concern with him. We were
able to produce evidence that showed a legion of governments that were doing it. We find a position—
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Andrew)
—Order! I trust that these remarks are going to be related to the bill in short measure. We have ranged far and wide and I have deliberately not interrupted you to avoid doing so, but you must understand that at this point I am a little mystified.
Mr CREAN
—I understand why you might be, Mr Deputy Speaker, but I am making the point that here we have a minister in breach of the Prime Minister's guidelines and a Prime Minister refusing to act. Again we have seen it, even in the last day or so, with the report that came from Mr Max Moore-Wilton. He was given the task of looking into the affairs of Mr Prosser, the minister for customs, and advising the Prime Minister on what should be done. That report was in the Prime Minister's hands back on 15 November and the Prime Minister did not release it until last night. For almost three months he has been sitting on a report which should have required him to act in a way that addressed the concerns we have raised about Minister Prosser and his particular involvement in administering the act that covers the diesel fuel rebate.
In fact, this report says that it is appropriate for the Prime Minister to set out a code and that it is appropriate for ministers to report to the Prime Minister, but it sets out no requirement by which the Prime Minister is expected to take action. We believe this issue needs to be addressed further. The reason we argue it is that we have a litany of examples, only one of which involves the minister for customs and the administration of the diesel fuel rebate.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
—I would, however, appreciate the member for Hotham getting back to the bill before the House, which deals specifically with the mining industry rather than the diesel fuel rebate scheme in total.
Mr CREAN
—Well, Mr Deputy Speaker, I understand that point. But you, coming from a rural community, may be satisfied that this is a bill that applies only to the mining
industry. Part of my argument will be that, to the extent to which changes are made, there is no way there will not be future pressure to apply the changes implemented in relation to the mining industry to the farming sector. That is one of the points that I want to develop.
Let me just come to the question, first of all, of the figure that, it is argued, will be saved. I know the minister is not here, but there are advisers for him and I would hope he would address this in his reply. We are advised by public statements that over four years these measures will yield something like $440 million in savings. That is the figure that we have relied upon in terms of the 6.9 per cent cut to the overall scheme.
But if you look at the explanatory memorandum to this bill, there are calculations in that that can lead one to the view that the savings could be as high as $640 million. I would ask for clarification as to what the true figure is. I mean, $200 million is not an insignificant amount. In particular, given it is a 50 per cent jump in terms of that which is alluded to by way of savings, I would have thought it was an important issue to clarify.
I turn now to the concerns of the industry in relation to this bill and why we in the Labor Party believe that further responses are required, why further monitoring is needed and why further ability through Senate processes hopefully will get us to a clearer answer. I note that in the minister's statement, and indeed in his second reading speech, he said that these changes are the consequence of wide‐ranging consultations with the industry.
On the question of consultations, when the actual changes contained in the legislation were finally announced jointly by Ministers Parer and Prosser on 31 October, much was made of these close consultations. But following the introduction of the bill when the detail became apparent, the Minerals Council of Australia issued a press release expressing disappointment with the legislation as tabled and accusing the government of going beyond their agreement with them. I refer to the media release by the Minerals Council of Australia, which reads:
The legislation and the comments by the Minister in his Second Reading Speech appear to go beyond that agreement. They do not provide the certainty integral to our agreement. Following a detailed analysis of the legislation, the Council will be seeking the Government's cooperation to rectify the apparent unintended consequences of this legislation.
That was a statement made by Mr Ellis on behalf of the Minerals Council of Australia.
Turning to the constituency that you, Mr Deputy Speaker Andrew, raised by way of a comment from the chair—the impact on the mining industry alone: concern has also been expressed by the National Farmers Federation. I refer to a report in the Melbourne
Age
of Monday, 4 November. The National Farmers Federation is quoted as saying that it would be `appalled' if the mining industry's deal was extended to the rural sector.
What we have, Mr Deputy Speaker—and this point is important for you to understand—is that when this legislation is passed there will be a glaring anomaly between guidelines applying to the mining industry and those applying to the farming industry. We see that excluded from mining operations in this legislation and therefore from the eligibility to claim the rebate will be all vehicles with a gross weight of more than 3½ tonnes. The concern is that a substantial quantity of diesel is quite legitimately used on farms in such vehicles. I mention four‐wheel drives, utes, light trucks, self‐propelled boom sprays, et cetera. What will happen when this legislation is passed is that we will have a glaring anomaly in relation to the use of four‐wheel drives and utilities. The mining industry cannot claim with respect to them but it is alleged that the farming sector can. That is the agreement. But do you think Treasury is going to leave it there? Do you think Finance is going to leave it there?
The Expenditure Review Committee will trot out the argument that says, `Let's abolish the diesel fuel rebate because there are huge savings and we have to get the deficit down.' We will have all that drama again. We will have the Prime Minister riding in on the white horse, saving the day. We will have Tim Fischer going around on his two-minute stops saying that he will fight to the end to retain
the diesel fuel rebate. But having fought out that little charade, the fall‐back position for Treasury will be: if we have cut out the exemption, if we have cut out the entitlement, for these sorts of vehicles in mining operations, why should they be retained on farms?
I believe that, despite the assurances of the government—because we all know how many of those were scrapped in the last budget—the farm sector should not be resting easy. They should not be, because what we have here is an attempt to restrict eligibility for access to the rebate for certain sorts of vehicles in the mining sector and the argument will become one that says: if it applies to the mining sector, if we can get savings out of them—and they are not insubstantial savings—why should we not go after the farm sector? Of course what the government will say is: `We have retained the diesel fuel rebate. It is just that we are cutting off a whole range of options as to who can claim it.' In name we will have a diesel fuel rebate; in fact we will have a significant reduction in those seeking to claim it.
It was not just the farm sector that has expressed concern about consultations and the content of this bill, Mr Deputy Speaker; it was also the Petroleum Production and Exploration Association. I quote from a letter from the Acting Executive Director of APPEA, the Australian Petroleum Production and Exploration Association, of 6 November. The letter states:
More specifically, APPEA finds it difficult to understand how the Government can claim that the changes have industry support when an industry the size of the petroleum industry is opposed to the proposed modifications.
Here we have assertions by the government that they have consulted industry on matters affecting them contained in this legislation. But we have got doubts raised by the farmers as to whether there will be an attempt to encroach on them in the future. We have got the petroleum and production exploration industry saying that the legislation does not reflect any agreement that was had with them. And we have got the Minerals Council of Australia saying that the legislation goes far beyond anything that they had agreed to.
It is for that reason that we will support in the Senate the mechanisms that hopefully will ensure that these industries have the opportunity to put their argument through the Senate inquiry process. We know that the government will take the view that, because it has the overwhelming weight of numbers in this place, it does not really have to listen to us. We can get up and make the speeches but, in the end, they have got the numbers to roll it through.
It is a different circumstance in the Senate, and parliament should be about scrutiny. It should not be about frustration; it should be about scrutiny. And it should be about holding governments accountable for that which they promised—promised before the election and promised in consultation subsequently. It should be about ensuring that accountability is delivered. If we cannot get that accountability in this chamber, we will use our position in the other House to achieve that very result.
In the final analysis, we do not have a problem in principle with the view that, if tightening up is needed, if it is about ensuring that entitlements that should not otherwise be there are obtained because of flaws in the legislation, if it is about use of Administrative Appeals Tribunal procedures that seek to extend the thrust and the intent of the act beyond that which was intended, then by all means legislate to address those issues. But don't pretend that you have got agreement when you haven't and don't pretend that you are retaining the diesel fuel rebate when you are finding a backdoor method to emasculate it. And don't pretend that you have delivered on your promise to retain the diesel fuel rebate when in fact you have got sections of industry blatantly saying that you have not delivered on an agreement with them.
We know that, as a government, your standing with industry is at an appalling level. They say that you lack vision; they say that you lack industry policy. And it is not just the industry sector that says it; it is the Premier of Victoria that joins them. The fact of the matter is that this government has not got an industry policy because it does not see a role for government in terms of developing an
industry policy. It believes that what you should do is let everyone survive in the marketplace and let the marketplace rip, regardless of the consequences and regardless of the fact that we do not have level playing fields around the place. That is not a matter for government.
We in the Labor Party take a different view. We say that there has got to be a role for government. We say that, where there are market failures, we should seek to address them. We say that, where the level playing field is tilted against us, we should seek to address that issue. That is why we have been prepared to work in partnership with government to achieve a commitment to invest in this nation in clever activity, in innovative activity, in developing our natural resource base. Unless we back the mining industry and the farming sector in this country we can kiss goodbye value‐added activity; and that is where our future does lie despite what the minister for primary industries has to say about that.
The fact of the matter is that this is a vital measure of importance to the industry. It is something that cannot be glossed over as an administrative tightening and it is certainly something that cannot be swept under the carpet, the government saying it has got the agreement from industry when it clearly has not.
(Time expired)
Mr FITZGIBBON
(Hunter)
(8.57 p.m.)
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I must say that I am a little disappointed, due to no fault of your own, that I have not been given the opportunity to follow a government member in this debate. I would have been particularly keen to hear how government backbenchers are responding to the bill that is currently before the House. However, I have to say that during my first speech in this place I made reference to the significance of the mining and agriculture sectors in my electorate. Indeed, I suggested that my electorate forms the engine room of New South Wales, supplying most of the coal that powers its power stations, the lion's share of its export coal and, of course, a great deal of its agricultural product. I think members will understand why I would take the opportunity to speak to any bill which has
as its subject matter the diesel fuel rebate scheme.
Of course, the bill seeks to enact changes to the diesel fuel rebate scheme in order to restrict eligibility in the mining operations category to close loopholes and also to address recent Federal Court and AAT decisions that have had the effect of widening the definition of mining operations as it relates to the diesel fuel rebate scheme and to improve the accountability of the scheme and reduce the expenditure under the scheme from misuse.
I hope that by now members on both sides of this House recognise and accept that the rebate is not a subsidy but indeed is a legitimate recognition that those who enjoy the benefits of the scheme do operate off‐road and its retention is absolutely essential. Of course, it ensures that the mining and rural sectors are not hit or whacked with tax on their business imports. It is worth almost $800 million to the mining industry and almost that much again to the agricultural sector.
Of course, it is a well‐known fact that, in the lead‐up to its first budget last year during its budget deliberations, the now government did consider the total abolition of the scheme. But thankfully, due to community and industry pressure and, I am proud to say, pressure from those who sit on this side of the House, the government was forced into a backdown on that issue.
I laugh when I think back to the weeks—indeed, the months—immediately after the budget when the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Tim Fischer) and the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Anderson) were roaming the country espousing the good news to all and sundry that they were lucky, that they had been given a gift and that the government had decided not to abolish the scheme. I would suggest that that was a rather curious announcement which did nothing more than inform those who enjoy the benefits of the scheme that they would continue to do so.
I want to demonstrate the government's duplicity—its hypocrisy—on this issue. I want to share with the House a
Hansard
extract which I came across today. I want to conceal
the speaker's name until I have read the extract to the House. It says:
On budget night, the government proudly and loudly declared that it would leave the diesel fuel rebate scheme intact. After the controversy and the public debate leading up to budget night, with industry fearing that the diesel fuel rebate scheme would be curtailed or even abolished, the government's announcement was met with a great deal of relief and was endorsed by industry.
However, we now find that several substantial changes have been proposed by the government to determine eligibility for claiming rebates under the diesel fuel rebate scheme.
This is not someone on this side of the House speaking in response to the 1996-97 budget; this is the now Minister for Science and Technology (Mr McGauran) speaking to the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill 1995. The bill was an attempt to address the weaknesses in the system that have been highlighted by so many reports.
The bill of that day sought to save the government some $55 million per year. The bill before the House tonight, as the member for Hotham (Mr Crean) has pointed out, talks about savings of around $140 million per year. So the Minister for Science and Technology came into this place to speak to a bill not all that dissimilar to the one before us tonight and to complain about how the government of the day, having announced the retention of the scheme, was somehow coming in the back door and reducing the benefits of the scheme to the industry.
Mr O'Connor
—Hypocrites!
Mr FITZGIBBON
—It is hypocrisy and it is certainly worthy of note. I have to say that the scheme is a mess. I would be happy to support and be part of any bipartisan process to approach its repair.
The link between the fuel excise and road funding long ago disappeared. The cost of the scheme continues to blow out and now stands at nearly $1.5 billion. Rorting in the system does occur—we all accept that. But since the introduction of the diesel excise in 1957, the policy decisions relating to the protection of miners, forresters, those in the agricultural sector and those who provide essential services have been very poorly developed—I recognise that it has been very poorly devel
oped on both sides of politics—and have, in the main, been knee-jerk political reactions to fiscal challenges of the day.
So, too, is the list of reviews into the system indicative of the mess we have ended up with with the diesel fuel rebate scheme. Those reviews include the report of the Auditor-General of September 1984, the Joint Parliamentary Committee of Public Accounts report No. 224 of October 1984, the Joint Parliamentary Committee of Public Accounts report No. 234 of September 1985, the Joint Parliamentary Committee of Public Accounts report No. 241 of September 1985, the report by the Industries Assistance Commission in November 1986, the report of the Australian Customs Service of March 1987, the Auditor-General's audit report No. 27 of 1990-91 and most recently the Auditor-General's audit report No. 20 of 1995-96. So there has been a great list of reports or inquires into the scheme. Many of the recommendations coming from those reviews are yet to be developed and adopted by either side of politics.
The 1991 audit highlighted many weaknesses, most of which were highlighted in earlier reviews. They include: the lack of clarity in the scheme's objectives, a complex and ill‐defined eligibility criterion—something that has been made only more complex, I think, by the bill before us tonight—a self-assessment system that is open to rorts, overpayments in the system, the efficiency of the delivery of the scheme and the expansion of the eligibility criteria affected by Administrative Appeals Tribunal decisions and decisions of the Federal Court.
I do accept that the bill before the House is an attempt to address some of the weaknesses of the diesel fuel rebate scheme, but I must express my concerns—and join with the member for Hotham—in a number of areas, including the apparent decision by the government to renege on the arrangements it had with the mining industry. I want to reinforce the media release that the member for Hotham made reference to. The Minerals Council of Australia on 13 December 1996 stated:
Mr Jerry Ellis, President of the Minerals Council of Australia, expressed disappointment with the
Government's Customs and Excise Legislation tabled in the House of Representatives late yesterday.
"The minerals industry was committed to our agreement to work with the Government to develop and implement changes to the Diesel Fuel Rebate Scheme (DFRS). The intent of agreed changes was to achieve the dual objectives of facilitating an expanding, competitive minerals sector while containing expenditure growth flowing from widening eligibility beyond the intent of the Scheme", Mr Ellis said.
"The legislation and the comments by the Minister in his Second Reading Speech appear to go beyond that agreement. They do not provide the certainty integral to our agreement. Following a detailed analysis of the legislation, the Council will be seeking the Government's cooperation to rectify the apparent unintended consequences of this legislation", Mr Ellis said.
The member for Hotham has also referred to concerns expressed by the National Farmers Federation: the anomalies that would exist under the act as a result of the passage of this legislation and future flow-on effects to the agricultural sector.
I fear that the bill is more about fiscal tightening rather than a genuine attempt to improve the scheme's integrity and to help ensure its long-term viability and its long-term future. I think the main message in the course of the second reading debate on this bill is that those on this side of the House will continue to fiercely oppose any further or future attempts to either erode the value of the scheme to the industry or to abolish the scheme.
As I said earlier, I think we should all accept now that it is a legitimate recompense of a tax on business imports. I hope the government recognises that and I hope, having heard some more speculation in recent days about the future of the scheme, that the government recognises its importance and is committed to its retention, because those of us on this side certainly are.
Mr ANDREW
(Wakefield)
(9.07 p.m.)
—I am very keen to participate in this debate, albeit briefly, because people listening to the debate either in the gallery or over the radio must truly wonder where the opposition is coming from. If ever there were a classic case of the member for Hunter (Mr Fitzgibbon)
wanting to have a bob—or maybe it is a dollar—on the diesel fuel rebate either way, this was the debate where we witnessed it. He remarked that this scheme is a mess. He remarked that he was happy to support amendments to improve the delivery of the scheme.
The legislation we are dealing with tonight is legislation that amends the scheme to improve its delivery and to minimise the number of potential rorts that may occur. Not only is the legislation being supported by the opposition, but the member for Hunter might have been a little less churlish in his endorsement of it. His endorsement, however, was much more fulsome than that of the member for Hotham (Mr Crean).
The member for Hotham chose this debate to run a whole lot of red herrings that had nothing to do with the legislation before the House. The member for Hotham said, `We've had the Prime Minister stand up and reassure the mining industry and reassure the agricultural industry that there will not be further changes to the scheme in this budget.' Then the member for Hotham went on about a matter that I thought was totally unrelated and said, `I'm going to pursue the Prime Minister and pursue the Treasurer and seek the same sort of reassurance about the labour market, about the ABC and about every other area of government expenditure to see that it too will be quarantined from any changes in the coming budget.'
Of all people in the opposition, the member for Hotham knows that no government runs into a budget quarantining various areas from expenditure cuts. If it does, there is no end to the list. The diesel fuel rebate scheme is such a sensitive area. It is an area that running into the last budget—as the member for Hunter was generous enough to acknowledge—caused the government some angst. The Prime Minister (Mr Howard) has been keen to indicate that this is an area where farmers and miners have nothing to fear. I was very pleased to hear him say that.
In fact, what the member for Hunter alleged—and I think it was quite unfounded, although we will both speculate about that, I am free to concede—was that, running into
the last budget, this scheme was at risk. Let me tell the member for Hunter that, as a member of the government, I was never aware of the scheme being at risk. I was aware of the rumours that were run—and very conveniently fuelled by the opposition to their advantage—to suggest that the scheme was at risk. But, had the scheme been at risk, the member for Hunter might care to identify the number of people not only in rural Liberal seats, of which there is a multiple number, but also in National Party seats who would not have tolerated any such change, as he well knows. So prior to the announcement of the budget there was a reassurance that this was nothing more than nonsense, and precisely the same reassurance has preceded this budget.
What foundation is there then for the sorts of allegations that were made by the member for Hunter? Even more significantly, what foundation is there for the outrageous suggestions made by the member for Hotham that impinge directly on the character of the minister? If the member for Hotham had any evidence, he should have stood in this parliament and proposed a substantive motion critical of the minister. But no, let us just use this piece of legislation by innuendo to suggest that in some way the minister has failed in his duty and failed in his obligation before the Prime Minister.
What is the reality? The reality is that the legislation before the House deals with the mining industry only. The reality is that, whatever fuel excise does for any business run by the minister, precisely the same arrangements are available for any one of the minister's competitors. There is—as anyone objectively listening to this debate will know—no advantage in this legislation to the minister, and it is grossly irresponsible and an abuse of the House for the member for Hotham to suggest otherwise.
The scheme before the House proposes that potential rorts of the scheme in the mining industry should be focused more sharply by ensuring that any vehicle that weighs less than 3½ tonnes is not, in fact, able to be filled with diesel in the mining industry. It is a change I welcome, and it is a change I welcome because, as the opposition have cor
rectly identified, this scheme is always under the searching spotlight of Treasury. I want to ensure that I can eyeball any Treasury official and say, `This scheme is being run with all the integrity possible.' What we are proposing tonight adds to that integrity. Do farmers have something to fear in a flow-on sense? I would not have thought so. The use of a vehicle of less than 3½ tonnes on a farm is very different to its use within the mining industry.
Mr Fitzgibbon
—Don't put your house on it.
Mr O'Keefe
—Explain the difference to me.
Mr ANDREW
—I am very grateful for those interjections that help the debate so much. The simple fact is that the use of vehicles of less than 3½ tonnes in the mining industry is much more likely to be for the transportation of personnel to and from work and for a range of activities not directly related to mining.
I represent large rural holdings and small rural holdings. There are very few vehicles of under 3½ tonnes on rural holdings not being used simply on the farm for the immediate purpose of farm maintenance, whether it is for checking stock water, monitoring stock, moving tools or whatever.
Furthermore, as I and every other representative of a rural seat knows, the present administration of the act, as it affects farmers, already forces them to ensure that all on‐road use of diesel is accounted for. I have had instances, as I am sure all members opposite have had, of farmers coming to me saying, `Look, we have been obliged by the excise administrators to account for our diesel expenditure and to account for our on‐road and off‐road use and the proportion.' I have had, as honourable members would know—and I am sure it is no less true for the member for Burke (Mr O'Keefe)—instances of farmers having to then quantify the fuel use of the truck to ensure that the amount of fuel totally consumed on the farm was rightly apportioned for on‐ and off‐road use.
In all fairness, I should not be entertaining any of this because it is unrelated to the immediate legislation, which is about the mining industry. I merely felt obliged to pick
up the interjection from the member for Burke and point out that I was not debating this in some form of ignorance. The reality is that the allegation by the member for Hotham that the minister had some sort of vested interest in this was totally unrelated to this legislation. That is something that the minister, I know, will want to deny utterly. It is an allegation that I could not allow to sit in the chamber, having recognised that it is totally unfounded, particularly as this legislation deals with the mining industry and not with any other industry.
I want to pick up another point rightly made by the member for Hunter. I will endorse his comments wholeheartedly on this. The diesel fuel rebate scheme, whether it is in the mining industry or in rural industry, is frequently misunderstood because it is all too easily seen as some sort of gift to those who are the beneficiaries of the scheme. The reality, put by the member for Hunter and endorsed by me, is that this is not a case of the government giving something to those who are the beneficiaries of this scheme. Instead, it is a case of the government recognising the difference between primary industry and secondary industry and saying, `This tax which we the government levy on a number of industries and levy on all on‐road users, no matter whether they are in primary or secondary industry, is not appropriate to be applied to primary industries.' That is the point made by the member for Hunter and he is absolutely right. This is not a case of revenue being handed out. This is a case of tax being deliberately forgone in recognition of the primary role of those industries.
I would remind the House that that sort of approach to primary industry and to export income generating industries has always highlighted the tax attitude of the present government. It is true that a proposal that we had in 1993 is not now being considered, but this reinforces our long‐term attitude to tax on export industries—that we do not believe it is appropriate to burden them with the tax. In that context we have maintained the policy of the previous government, a policy which we had when we were last in government, which says that this inappropriate application of a
tax should have a refund mechanism. That is what the diesel fuel rebate scheme is all about.
Only this week I received from an organisation called NatRoad an appeal on behalf of road transport operators to have the diesel fuel rebate scheme changed so that only what they referred to as the `road user charge' should, in fact, be rebatable. They had calculated the road user charge at 18c per litre.
They, too, misunderstood the nature of the scheme. The nature of the scheme is not a technique for effectively handing money back to anybody but to avoid the government collecting tax from an industry or an industry sector that should not have to pay it. We have agreed that that sort of requirement should apply in the mining industry. That is what this legislation is about. We have also recognised, as has the member for Hunter, that within the mining industry there has been the potential for rorting that is now being addressed in this legislation. Because the legislation does nothing but reinforce the integrity of the scheme, it deserves the unqualified support of both sides of the House.
Mr O'KEEFE
(Burke)
(9.20 p.m.)
—The timing of this is all quite exquisite. After spending nine months talking about Labor's black hole, the opposition folk suddenly find they have got what we are choosing to call the Costello crater. I might say that, when you have got a novice in the chair, as you will come to understand, Treasury never gives up. I remember not very long ago, when this legislation was introduced and discussed in its first form, that there were announcements between the government and the mining industry and much was made of the consultations that had taken place and of the agreement that had been reached that this legislation was going to be simply tightening up loopholes within the industry. But of course what we find, now that the amendments have come back, is that it has gone considerably further.
I understand that there have been discussions between representatives of the mining industry, the government and Customs officers about the effects of some of these redefinitions, and they are hopeful that they
are being listened to. I would not hold out too much hope that they are being listened to because I think what is being flushed out here is a deeper agenda.
When the government announced the tightening up of the diesel fuel rebate scheme, it costed the savings to budget at $441 million over four years. But the explanatory memorandum now proposes a financial impact of $60 million per annum—that is, $240 million over four years—and, in addition, it refers to an extra $100 million saving of additional outlays relating to the AAT and Federal Court decisions.
If all this is added in, the saving is $640 million over four years. That is considerably greater than the assurances given to the industry last year. If those figures are correct—they come from the government's own estimates—then I wonder whether the government have any idea at all what the savings really are. If they do, then they have slipped this through the very people who have been quite close to them. This is a case of good friends being ratted on. They are taking it pretty hard, too, I might say. They have not only slipped it through but also added another 30 million bucks worth via some redefinitions in these new proposals.
I said that I think there is a deeper motive at work here. In January, during what they call the silly season—maybe it was a silly statement—the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Anderson) let out a press comment which gave us some focus on the direction of this government towards the priorities in commodities and primary industry. His comments were that Australia should focus more on improving its exports of raw materials than on developing processing industries. For that, read `downstream processing, value adding, extra jobs'. Minister Anderson said:
It is likely that improving the quality of our raw materials will become much more important than value adding.
Where, in this little piece of legislation, is the extra bit of revenue being dug out? It is in the changes to a process, which they have dreamed up, called `beneficiation'. Put in layman's terms, it is where you use diesel
fuel as part of the heating and energy process in doing a bit of downstream processing somewhere between the end of the line and the start of the line where the raw material has been extracted.
Some examples in the mining process which are closer to the mined and extracted end than the final marketable commodity, such as a slab of processed steel, for instance, are processes such as roasting, sintering, smelting, calcining and leaching. It applies right across the mineral sands, gold and coal industries. They have these integrated processes that are part of taking the raw extracted product—you understand this well, Mr Deputy Speaker Adams, because of the work that takes place in your electorate—and preparing it for the phase of refining and downstream processing. Admittedly, it is further than the stage where you dig it up, stick it in a boat and sell it as a raw product. It actually involves the part of the process that starts to create a few extra jobs. I go back to the minister's comment. He said:
It is likely that improving the quality of our raw materials will become much more important than value adding.
What on earth is wrong with these people? We have just been through the traumas, as a nation, of transposing ourselves from being `chop it down, dig it up, send it off in ships' people to actually trying to add a bit of value in the nation. Now they are turning back. More importantly, this legislation exactly reflects that trend.
While we are committed to not opposing the legislation as it goes through this House because that is the undertaking we have given, I am making it very clear to the parliamentary secretary and the minister at the table, the Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs (Mr Prosser)—I hope he will pass these views on to the minister—that if ratting on the agreements you made last October with the mining industry is unintended, then you have the opportunity in the phase in the other house to take account of the amendments that have been proposed to you and that are under discussion at the moment by representatives of the mining industry. This is where they will find out whether they
have been ratted on or whether it is an unintended consequence that can be finetuned. My view of it is that they should not hold out their hopes.
I am making it very clear that, although we on this side of the House will not be voting against the legislation in this phase, we will be indicating in the other place that we expect these amendments to be picked up. It is not solely around the points I have already made. There are some other signals now coming in about investment trends in the Australian economy that roll, in part, off these sorts of issues. Nobody in either agriculture or farming expected that the diesel fuel rebate would turn up on the budget table again. They had been through many years of seeing it examined. Successive Labor governments had maintained the diesel fuel rebate, in the face of considerable pressure from Treasury, as an obvious cost saving measure.
When many in these industries supported the coalition at the last election, the last thing they expected was that their diesel fuel rebate would turn up on the table. They made their way through it, but they did not expect it to turn around and bite them again they way it is now.
The member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew) touched on the issue of farmers not needing to have any concern. For heaven's sake, the miners were told last October: `This is as far as we intend to go.' Now, by January, which is just a quiet three months later, we have already slipped another $30 million worth in, including the vehicles under 3.5 tonnes. Farmers of course can do little else but stare at the media about the Costello crater. They know that there are going to be more budget cuts from this government because they got it so wrong and, no matter what assurances they get, they are going to have to seriously expect that the case for 3.5‐tonne or less vehicles out on remote mine sites is absolutely no different from the use of vehicles in that weight category, whether they are spraying equipment or four‐wheel‐drives driving around the farm, when it comes to farming or mining.
I think those members, particularly of the National Party, who are sometimes described
as Liberals in sheep's clothing will be much better defined as sheep in Liberal clothing by the time this particular issue sees its way through. Those people would want to be looking very closely after the interests of their constituents, because this is very much on the table. There is no way it could not be.
There is one other aspect of this that I want to touch upon. Some figures released yesterday from the Bureau of Statistics show that the mining and exploration industry has increased its investment in offshore exploration—I do not mean off the Australian coast; I mean exploration in other countries vis-a-vis exploration in Australia—by 13 per cent in the last 12 months. When you ask the industry why they have taken that investment offshore, they tell you that a number of factors taking place in Australia are causing them to be less certain than they were when they were investing their heads off in exploration and development under Labor.
One of those comments that they make, and one of the key factors they give, is the now intense confusion, uncertainty and distrust over the diesel fuel rebate because many of these companies are actually now anticipating a substantial increase in energy costs. As those familiar with these industries know, energy costs, particularly if diesel fuel is your only form of energy, are significant in the make or break of the exploration or what it might lead to.
This government, which runs around boasting about low inflation and low interest rates—in a country that ought to be comfortable and ready to invest its head off—wants to have a good hard look at what it has created in just 12 months in this industry: a 13 per cent increase or drift offshore to other countries of investment capital in this industry for these reasons, and the government knows it. The industry has told it, but it does not have any answers for the industry.
The government are sitting there with this Treasury driven budget process. We have been through it; we know what it is all about. We know how relentless it is. As I said, when you have a novice, he is easy bait. That is what has happened here. You have an industry that has been a very strong supporter of
the coalition government now in deep despair about the fact that it is being turned on and in such an untrustful way.
I make those few points to make it clear to the Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs (Mr Prosser) and the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Mr Abbott), who are at the table, that we will be not opposing the passing of this legislation. But, as has already been pointed out by my colleagues the member for Hotham (Mr Crean) and the member for Hunter (Mr Fitzgibbon), we have severe reservations about what has developed in these three months since the original announcements in October. We expect in particular that the proposals being requested by the industry will be considered in the Senate phase. We will be reconsidering our position in the Senate phase if that does not come to pass.
Mr CAMPBELL
(Kalgoorlie)
(9.36 p.m.)
—I was not going to speak on this customs and excise bill but, sitting in my office listening to the self-justification and hyperbole on both sides, I felt compelled to. The truth is that, in Australia today, we have a one-party system. We have branches that will not part on each side of this chamber and there is really nothing to choose between them.
I want to go briefly to the recent history of the diesel fuel rebate. It is absolutely clear that, once Senator Walsh left the Finance portfolio, the so-called Treasury boffins had it very much their own way. There was no doubt that they were giving advice to the Labor government to impose a diesel fuel rebate. It was certainly on the cards. It was justified by all sorts of reasons.
I believe the great credit for it not occurring does not belong in this House; it belongs to the state member for the seat of Eyre, Julian Grill, who lobbied Beazley very hard on this issue and pointed out to Beazley that one of the great losers would be his own electorate for which he was unlikely to be forgiven.
With the advent of the new government, Treasury were back again with the same sort of advice. I want to give you a little insight into the ability of these gentlemen from
Treasury. I go back to the gold tax days, back to 1986, when there was a strong move to bring in a gold tax. I argued against it very strongly. I remember having a meeting with Hawke and Keating. I said, `If you leave gold alone, it will go through a billion dollars.' In those days I think it was something like $300 million a year. `What rubbish,' said Keating. He said, `I talked to the mining industry,' by which he meant Western Mining. He said, `My experts in Treasury tell me it will peak at $800 million.' It went to $4 billion. I was wrong at a billion dollars, but I was a damn sight closer than Treasury. That is the intellect you are dealing with here. If they see a ready source of income, they will grab it no matter what the consequence is. Contrary to the argument by the member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew), this is not tax forgone; it is simply tax that should never be imposed.
The tax on diesel was originally supposed to be for funding infrastructure. The mining companies and the farmers do not use that infrastructure; they create their own. They therefore should not be paying for it. The member for Burke (Mr O'Keefe) said that this is still on the agenda. Actually I do not think it is. The government would not be game to do it again because the mining companies showed how angry they were. Farmers are powerless. There are so few of them. They have no lobbying power. They have become political eunuchs. But the mining industry would not cop it. They have been dudded, because in my estimation it is another $100 million they have been hit for, not $30 million. The government is clamping down in all sorts of ways. There is the absurdity that there is no diesel rebate for mine water pumped off a mine site. You cannot legislate for where the water occurs, you actually have to get it where it is, and in some cases it is off the mine site.
The truth is that there was very little rorting in the mining industry; there really was not any scope for it. There was rorting in primary industry, and I do not blame them. Given the pressure on primary industry today, very few of them could exist without fudging at the edges things like the diesel fuel rebate. But there was very little abuse of the system in
the mining industry. The miners today, even with the diesel fuel rebate, are paying more for diesel than any of our competitors. That ought to be made clear. The government, at the behest of these wizards from Treasury, wants to make this industry, which is so important to Australia, more difficult; yet the industry is already paying more for diesel than all our competitors. That is an inescapable fact.
There is no doubt that this was an ill‐conceived grab for more money. There is no doubt that it would have succeeded had the mining industry not realised the dire danger it was in. There are many small gold mines operating today whose margins are less than the diesel fuel rebate. The rational economist would tell us, `Let them close down. Let them depart the scene.' They are doing a great job for Australia. It is good for the country that they are employing people and tax is being paid on their income. But they are working on very fine margins because gold is at a very low price in Australia today, and it is a great tribute to the industry that we have become so efficient in the mining of it.
We ought to have a look at what is really happening. If these people who advise governments thought about it, they could do the country some good. There is no reason in most cases why the mining industry cannot use light crude oil for a lot of its energy sources. Certainly in powerhouses it is a sensible option. It is much cheaper. What is happening now is that we are pumping out the light crude, we are exporting it to Singapore and then reimporting the refined diesel. I am sure there is an absolute net loss to us in that transaction. Also, we are importing a lot of high‐speed diesel engines. Because of the high wear on them, we give them a tax write‐off over five years whereas the big, slow revving engines that use light fuel oil get a tax write‐off over 25 years. So the country gets another whammy while we keep importing these high‐speed diesel engines mainly from America but some from Europe.
The mining industry should be given a lot of encouragement to shift, where it can, to light fuel oil with absolute guarantees that we are not going to tax that. What have we done
in that regard? The Apache oil company Stag No. 1 well is pumping light crude oil out of the ground. It is quite suitable to be used in powerhouses just as it is—it needs no refining—but the government will not give it a tax exemption because it is not polluting enough. It does not have enough contained carbon. It does not give off enough black smoke. It burns too clean. What a lot of nonsense—these genii who think they have a way to pay government expenses by taxing the very industries that make this country viable.
If we said to farmers, to local governments around the country and to state governments generating power, `We recommend and we urge you to use this fuel oil so that we can save the cost of importing fuel oil and importing high‐speed engines,' this country would be a long way in front. But no-one there has the nous to understand it. The Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs (Mr Prosser), who is at the table, has written me many letters which indicate that he never had a clue what it was about.
The member for Burke mentioned that mining companies were going offshore. There is absolutely no doubt about this: they are going offshore. But it is not because of the diesel fuel rebate. They know that if there is any more tampering of this they will fight and they will win, because they can certainly bring to bear the sort of firepower that no government can resist. What is driving companies offshore is sovereign risk, and that ought to be clearly understood. Sovereign risk is the great thing that is making our mining companies look offshore, and I think the Labor Party ought to give this some serious consideration in the native title debate which this House is going to have. Mr Deputy Speaker, I thank you for the opportunity to speak in this debate. For the time being I think they are all the points I wanted to raise.
Mr PROSSER
(Forrest—
Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs)
(9.44 p.m.)
—in reply—In concluding the debate on the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1996, I thank the members who made contributions. However, I think some issues need to be set straight. The government's approach to this scheme was to
try to contain the expotential growth of the diesel fuel rebate scheme. In the 1996-97 budgetary year, the outlays of the scheme for the mining category were in the order of $793.7 million. Why the scheme had grown beyond its original intent was in some part due to successful claims to the courts and the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. The legislation seeks to contain that growth and to correct that movement of the scheme into areas it was not previously intended for.
The member for Hotham (Mr Crean) made a number of statements and the member for Burke (Mr O'Keefe), I note, said that in October the mining industry was basically told—I think these were his words—one thing and then by January we had slipped in the 3.5 tonne vehicles. I want to correct that incorrect assertion. In a memo dated 9 October 1996 the Minerals Council confirms for their members a schedule which says:
Accordingly, we seek your agreement to the following package for the resolution of outstanding issues relating to DFRS:
They put up 12 items. Four of the items mentioned were already not eligible for rebate, but item 11 of the proposition put to the government reads:
all vehicles under 3.5 tonne GVW suitable/capable for use on public roads whether registered or not;
So there is no question that we changed in any way the rules to the agreement we arrived at with that working group of the Minerals Council. Reference was made to concerns by APPEA. I point out that Mr Wells was then the CEO of the Australian Petroleum Production and Exploration Association, so he too was very involved in the negotiations the government had with regard to those areas.
The member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell) made reference to light crude oil. I point out to the member for Kalgoorlie that light crude is now in fact subject to excise at the same rate as diesel—that at present being 34.5c per litre. That amendment was introduced by the previous government and probably at a time when he was a member of that governing party. So whether, in the case he was making, power stations use diesel or light crude for their power generation, in that instance they
are not eligible for rebate and both products are excisable at the same rate.
In regard to the tightening of the scheme, members may be aware that the Auditor-General, in a review of the administration of the scheme, made several references and recommendations with regard to the accountability of that scheme. That audit report, as I recall, was Audit Report No. 20. It made reference to overclaiming and the need for tighter compliance with and administration of the scheme. The bill picks up that tighter compliance and better administration and better accountability referred to by the Auditor-General's report.
In closing, I note the comments of the member for Burke. I can advise the member for Burke that the government has been having discussions with the minerals industry and that to overcome some matters the government may well amend the legislation in the Senate. I thank members for their contribution to the debate on this legislation.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Message from the Governor‐General recommending appropriation announced.
Third Reading
Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
Bill (on motion by
Mr Prosser
) read a third time.

Selection Committee
Report
Mr NEHL
(Cowper)
(9.51 p.m.)
—I present the report of the Selection Committee relating to the consideration of committee and delegation reports and private members business on Monday, 10 February 1997. The report will be printed in today's
Hansard
, and the items accorded priority for debate will be published in the
Notice Paper
for the next sitting.

Report relating to the consideration of committee and delegation reports
and private Members' business on Monday, 10 February 1997
Pursuant to sessional order 28D, the Selection Committee has determined the order of precedence and times to be allotted for consideration of committee and delegation reports and private Members' business on Monday, 10 February 1997. The order of precedence and the allotments of time determined by the Committee are shown in the list.
PRIVATE MEMBERS' BUSINESS
Order of precedence
Notices
1
Mr Latham to present a Bill for an Act to amend the Trade Practices Act 1974 to declare downstream access and price competition on petroleum terminals and their products. (Notice given 10 December 1996.
2
Mr Alan Morris to present a Bill for an Act to amend the Commonwealth Employees' Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 1988, and for related purposes. (Notice given 11 December 1996.)
3
Mr E. L. Grace to move—
That this House:
(1)
condemns the proposal by the Prime Minister to establish a People's Constitutional Convention and to promote at a referendum any consensus that emerges on the question of a Republic;
(2)
notes the likelihood that a People's Convention would comprise appointed representatives only and that such a Convention would be biased in its recommendations;
(3)
calls on the Government to hold an indicative plebiscite to enable Australians to decide whether they want a Republic or not; and
(4)
calls on the Government to legislate to exclude persons who are not Australian citizens from voting in referenda or plebiscites. (Notice given 16 September 1996.)

Mr Sinclair to move—

deplores the assassination of Premier Theodore Miriung of the Province of Bougainville in Papua New Guinea;
(2)
recognises the courage and dignity with which he pursued solutions to the conflict on Bougainville;
(3)

urges the Government of Papua New Guinea and the members of the Bougainville Revolutionary Army to renew the reconciliation process in the aftermath of his death; to end all human rights abuses; to restore the rule of law and to accelerate the reconstruction process. (Notice given 16 October 1996.)

Mr Sercombe to move‐

warmly welcomes the report of Fiji's Constitutional Review Commission;
(2)
congratulates the members of the Constitutional Review Commission for producing a report containing fair and democratic constitutional proposals to meet the present and future needs of Fiji, promote racial harmony, national unity and the economic and social advancement of all of Fiji's communities;
