TELECOMMUNICATIONS (NUMBERING FEES) AMENDMENT BILL 1996
Cognate bill:
TELECOMMUNICATIONS AMENDMENT BILL 1996
Second Reading
Debate resumed from 30 October, on motion by
Mr Warwick Smith
:
That the bill be now read a second time.
Mr LATHAM
(Werriwa)
(9.52 p.m.)
—The Labor opposition does not oppose the passage of the Telecommunications (Numbering Fees) Amendment Bill 1996 or the Telecommunications Amendment Bill 1996. These two bills are fundamentally linked to the large package of legislation concerning the regulation of the telecommunications industry post-July 1997. The policy principles on which this package of legislation was based were drafted by the former minister, the member for Dobell (Mr Lee).
The post-July 1997 legislation is currently the subject of a public inquiry being conducted by the Senate Environment, Recreation, Communications and the Arts Legislation Committee. Public hearings of the committee commenced on 29 January and continue on 7 and 14 February. The committee is due to report to the Senate on 25 February.
While the Senate did not formally refer these two bills to the telecommunications bills inquiry, the bills have been the subject of extensive debate by witnesses appearing before the Senate committee and by members of that committee. This is the situation in the Senate. I am not always so fulsome in my recognition of events in the other place, but both the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Senator Alston) and the shadow minister for communications dealing with this matter are senators. I understand they have had some discussion as to whether these bills should be before the House tonight, because they have obviously been trying to progress some of these matters with the witnesses and the evidence that has been placed before the Senate committee—of which Senator Schacht is a member.
Given the obvious interrelationship between the post-July 1997 legislation and these two bills, no members of the Senate committee, which is chaired by Senator Short, objected to the issues contained within the bills being discussed at length. What I am foreshadowing essentially is that any items the Labor Party might want to move by way of amendment will flow through the Senate process following the deliberations and report of that Senate committee. Those matters will be addressed by the shadow minister for communications, Senator Schacht.
While the Labor opposition supports in principle the two bills currently before the House, members of the Senate committee have expressed concern that, given such considerable debate of the bills before their committee by key industry participants and consumer representatives and given the fact that witnesses have raised a number of seemingly valid points in relation to the bills, consideration should await that particular Senate committee report. Accordingly, it is our strong belief that the final passage of these bills should not proceed in the Senate, and if need be by way of consideration of Senate amendments, in this House until that process is complete. A further reason for delaying final passage of the bills is that the Senate committee is still waiting for answers to questions on notice on these two bills—including information from the Department of Communications and the Arts. This information may be relevant to the final wording of the bills.
Generally, it needs to be recognised that, in this period of telecommunications competition, some telephone numbers are commercially valuable. It is no secret that for most businesses the requirement of a recognisable, easy to remember telephone number has commercial value. In that sense, the numbers should be regarded as a community resource. It is quite proper, the Labor Party believes, for the government to levy fees, charges, taxes, whatever is necessary, to place a premium on that particular community resource.
We do not believe for a single minute that any of those principles should apply to nor
mal residential telephone numbers. They should not be covered by any user fee or any attempt by government to raise revenue. It has been an Australian tradition, I understand, from the good old days when Telstra was the public monopoly and had all the numbers, that they were provided free of charge. We recognise the community resource, the commercial importance of some telephone numbers—the ones that are easy to recognise and easy to remember—and government has a legitimate revenue raising function in that area, but it should not be expanded to cover any of the allocations of telephone numbers for residential use.
The other matter I wanted to raise is somewhat closer to home—the question of telephone numbering and telephone zones. This is a particular issue in my electorate of Werriwa. The seat spans the south-west of Sydney. Two-thirds of the seat, from Minto north, is in the 02 telephone zone, and the bottom third, or southern third of the seat, is in the 046 telephone zone. So the northern two-thirds of my electorate is within the Sydney metropolitan zone and the bottom one-third of the electorate is in the 046 zone. This is a particular issue in my electorate. I would hope that if competition and technological progress in telecommunications is to bring benefits to average Australians—
Mr Reid
—A bit of competition might help that.
Mr LATHAM
—The member for Bendigo interrupts that more competition might help. I hope that is the case. If competition in telecommunications is to bring benefits, surely one of the benefits must be a breakdown in the artificial barriers, the archaic telephone zones, that Sydney has inherited from a time when Sydney was much smaller.
That has always been the irony of the 02 zone. The eastern half of that zone—if you draw the full circle—is across the ocean because the zone is centred on the Sydney CBD. It was drawn in a configuration when Sydney was a much smaller place, when Campbelltown, which is now disadvantaged by being placed in the 046 zone, was literally a country town. It is no more in the country these days than any other part of the great
Sydney metropolis. As a consequence, businesses and residential phone users in the city of Campbelltown are extremely disadvantaged by having to pay more by virtue of their location in the 046 telephone zone.
If competition is to bring a benefit to consumers, I could not imagine a greater benefit than on the urban fringe. This applies in Sydney not only for the 046 zone but also for the 047 zone and right through to the 043 telephone zone on the central coast. As we have more active competition and a greater number of residential telephone providers, they should be actively competing in the urban fringe market to break down the sort of disadvantage that consumers have suffered for far too long.
That is the problem. Citizens in the southern portion of my electorate in Campbelltown are no different to citizens in the northern part—no different in their lifestyle, no different in their commuting habits and no different in their economic development and employment requirements—but they are treated very differently in their telephone consumption. That should not be the case in a period when technology is advancing so rapidly and when competition promises to deliver so much.
I urge the government to address this serious issue. It is most acute in terms of business development. I mentioned that the boundary between the 02 metropolitan telephone zone and the 046 zone cuts through the suburb of Minto in my electorate. Minto actually has an industrial estate. You can tell the business consequences of this. The portion of the Minto industrial estate in the 02 zone—that is, the northern portion—is fully built out. There is full economic development and location of firms in that part of the estate. Where they move into the 046 zone—you can literally see the divide at the boundary between the two zones—there is no take‐up of the residential land. Business is obviously discouraged by the fact that they would be located in the 046 zone and have much higher telephone costs in the normal conduct of their business activities.
I can give the House some examples of what this means in practice. On 1 May last
year I placed a question—question No. 35—on notice to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government (Mr Warwick Smith), who represents the Minister for Communications and the Arts, to try to flesh out and gain the detail about the level of disadvantage in the two telephone zones within my seat. I was disappointed that the minister would not provide information about the unit cost of telephone calls out of the 046 zone. He said that that information was commercial-in-confidence. As long as Telstra is publicly owned—it still is majority publicly owned—I think there is an important responsibility to have some information available to the public as to how its cost structure is framed and what element of cost recovery or more applies in that 046 telephone zone.
I was a bit disappointed that the Minister representing the Minister for Communications and the Arts—he has now joined us in the House—was not able to provide that information. I suppose his hands were tied. The useful part of his answer was just to point out the difference in telephone charges from 02, the Liverpool portion of my electorate, to 046, the Campbelltown portion. For instance, to make a telephone call, day or night, out of Liverpool to the Sydney CBD—this must be the most frequent call that businesses in my electorate make—there is a 25c flat charge. The local call rate applies. The Campbelltown portion of my electorate, to the south—in some instances, merely 100 metres from one business to the other as the boundary is formed—the rate is 25c per three‐minute call. That is a severe disadvantage for businesses that frequently make their calls to the Sydney CBD.
In Blacktown, from the 02 portion at Liverpool, a 25c flat amount is charged day and night. From the Campbelltown 046 zone there is a 12c per minute charge by day and nearly 9c per minute at night. In Dural the same figures apply, essentially. In Avalon Beach to the north of Sydney the community call rate of 25c per three‐minute period applies from Liverpool. Then the night time call is up towards 9c per minute from Campbelltown to the northern suburbs of Sydney. This is undoubtedly an artificial and unfair barrier to
economic development at the southern part of my electorate. The government needs to do something about this to try to accelerate the way in which competition might deal with this particular problem. It is a major concern right around the Sydney urban fringe.
I asked a question to that effect, question No. 476, placed on notice on 25 June. All that the Minister representing the Minister for Communications and the Arts could tell me was that the charging arrangements in the electoral division of Werriwa are consistent with those applying to similar areas throughout Australia. I know that that is not the case. I invite the member for Bass—I know he comes to Sydney a bit these days; I was in Tasmania and noted the speculation about that—to visit the Minto industrial estate in my electorate and see for himself that the portion of the estate within the 02 zone to the north is fully taken up by industrial development. The portion to the south—the 046 telephone zone, an extra telephony cost—is totally vacant. There is no take‐up rate at all for industrial development.
It has been a major source of economic disadvantage for the southern portion of my electorate. That also applies to the electorate of Macarthur. I know that the member for Macarthur (Mr Fahey) does not do a lot for his electorate, least of all on aviation matters, but at least he should get active on this issue. I would invite him to join my campaign to bring some fairness to the way in which telephone calls are levied throughout the south‐western portion of Sydney, right through from Minto and Campbelltown and on to Camden and those growing suburbs in the seat of Macarthur.
Something needs to be done about this. We have heard a lot about technological progress in telecommunications and we have heard a lot about the potential benefits of competition. Let us see some evidence of it and let us see this government try to advance benefits as quickly as possible to end the inequity in the 046 zone. People in Campbelltown should be treated the same as those in Liverpool. They are all part of the Sydney metropolitan area in their lifestyle and economic employment aspirations. The sooner the government ends
this artificial barrier that has been there for so long, the sooner people will feel that they are being treated fairly by the telecommunications regulations set by the Commonwealth parliament.
Mr BILLSON
(Dunkley)
(10.05 p.m.)
—I share some of the comments that the member for Werriwa (Mr Latham) was making about metropolitan area zones. I have actually raised this matter in this House once before about part of Frankston. It is surrounded by metropolitan phone areas but there is this little enclave that just happened to be subdivided at the wrong time and attached to what is now the 0359 telephone exchange at Baxter. We are battling away. I wish you luck with your situation. I am peppering the board of Telstra and seeing how I go. Perhaps we can compare notes at some stage.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Nehl)
—Perhaps I might just interrupt the member for Dunkley very briefly, as I was about to do to the member for Werriwa, when he finished. Could I suggest to you that, unlike the member for Werriwa, you might speak to the bills. I am delighted that you have both realised the difficulties inherent with having telephone calls outside the Sydney metropolitan area.
Mr BILLSON
—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. I thought you may have indulged me with maybe eight lines, compared to the member for Werriwa's eight minutes, on the subject. The Telecommunications Amendment Bill and the associated bill on numbering fees are relatively small but still important parts of the coalition government's creation of a fair and certain regulatory environment for one of Australia's economic powerhouse sectors.
The telecommunications industry has been a star performer over the past few years. In 1986-87 the communications industry's turnover was about $6.5 billion, or two per cent of gross domestic product. Nine years later, in 1995-96, the sector comprised 3.6 per cent of GDP, its total output a massive $15.3 billion dollars. There are not too many industry sectors which have almost doubled their contribution to GDP in under 10 years.
Despite some recent pessimism about employment in the telecommunications sector,
employment opportunities have grown strongly. While employment figures include postal and courier services, these are not major employers in this sector. It is interesting to note that in Victoria the job rise in this sector has been a creditable 27.3 per cent over that period, compared with an Australia-wide rise of 14.6 per cent. So things are happening in Victoria in this sector. These bills go some way towards encouraging that continuing growth.
With the forthcoming era of open competition in the telecommunications sector from July, the industry has a chance to power ahead even further. Of course, the part‐privatisation of Telstra will give that major player the freedom and ability to continue to grow even more strongly. As the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) has noted, the partial sale of Telstra will allow Telstra employees who live in Dunkley and elsewhere to own shares, and this will help Telstra to be even more responsive to the needs of its customers, and will enable Telstra to focus more on growing its business opportunities.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Nehl)
—Order! I invite the honourable minister at the table to observe standing order 57.
Mr BILLSON
—Telstra's own capacity and experience will ensure that it is a fierce competitor in its own right, a position that need not be further enhanced by special service telephone numbers being captive to it or any other established service provider. Other companies such as Optus and AAP Telecommunications will also be able to focus on the increasing potential of the sector, which is changing almost every other week. The growth of the Internet and other new technologies which were unheard of 10 years ago means that the focus has to shift towards asking what the customer wants rather than asking, as was the case 20 years ago, what the telecommunications company's engineers want for themselves.
The diversity and responsiveness of telecommunications technology, carriers and service providers will further flourish under the regulatory regime being pursued by this government. These bills seek to ensure that an important and finite resource within the sector
is properly managed and that the community can enjoy optimum emergency service response at a time of competing and changing methods of service provision.
Part of a fair regulatory environment is ensuring that assets that can be used by more than one service provider are not unfairly available to one company to the exclusion of others. The Telecommunications (Numbering Fees) Amendment Bill 1996 will provide for carriers and service providers to be charged for an allocation of blocks of numbers that they receive from Austel, the telecommunications industry umpire.
Efficient and fair use of telephone numbers is important. The staged changes to telephone numbers, in line with Austel's national numbering plan, have proceeded smoothly. My office has received very few complaints about the change in Mornington and Frankston South numbers from an 059 to an 0359 prefix, other than in relation to the issue of metropolitan codes, which I very briefly alluded to earlier.
The growth in telephone number usage overall brings home the realisation that the numbers are a finite resource. They cannot be used in a fickle or cavalier manner, or hoarded for a rainy day or for anti-competitive reasons by telecommunications companies and service providers. These bills ensure that the chances of this happening are minimised, because stockpiling of telephone numbers by an established provider will not be free of commercial implications and will not be allowed as a tactic to bar new entrants into the telecommunications sector under the provisions of this bill.
The government has decided to protect business and residential customers who use standard telephone numbers from any charges for allocation of these numbers. So a number such as 03 9781 223, my electorate office number, or an O359 number, will not attract a charge from Austel when it is allocated to Telstra, Optus or any other carrier or service provider and in turn provided to the residents and businesses of Dunkley.
A ministerial direction will be issued to prevent a charge being levied for the allocation of basic telephone numbers used by
mainstream residential and business users. However, premium special service numbers are likely to attract the highest charges. These special network, freecall and information service numbers, such as the 13, 1800 and 0055 series, have a significant commercial appeal over and above the value added services that attach to them. The bill seeks to ensure that the broader community benefits from the commercial appeal and relative value of a select range of telephone numbers made available to carriers for their commercial exploitation.
Commonwealth revenue is expected to benefit to the tune of $30 million as a result of the charging scheme, a very small percentage of the revenue these numbers generate for carriers and service providers. The minister, the member for Bass (Mr Warwick Smith), mentioned in his second reading speech how carriers have been pocketing windfall gains of millions of dollars when they have charged their own customers for 13 six-digit Australia-wide numbers, 0055 information service numbers, which have nine digits, and the 1 800 freecall 10-digit numbers.
An experience more familiar to me and the people of Dunkley would be our contact with pizza businesses. Whether it be the Pizza Hut's 13 11 66 number or Pizza Haven's 13 12 41 number or the like, their whole argument around convenience and their marketing campaign turns on their 13 numbers and on building consumer recall of them.
The importance and commercial value of their 13 number is obvious. In fact, for Pizza Hut its 13 number appears to have replaced direct access to its establishments via basic telephone services. Despite recently dialling the Frankston restaurant directly—I might add that some of the health conscious remarks about KFCs over the Christmas break that we have heard around the place I have not translated into my pizza eating habits—that call was routed through the now centralised phone order centre.
On my way home from Melbourne, I had to first explain why I wanted to collect our pizza from a store that was convenient to my travel, establish which store that was, convince the operator that that was where I
wanted to pick it up and then actually place an order. So their whole customer service system is being built around their 13 number, Mr Deputy Speaker. I am happy to discuss that further with you if you are having difficulty ordering pizzas.
Optus's published tariffs include a monthly charge reflecting the intrinsic value of a particular number. This intrinsic value is based on the ease of recognition of patterns of digits. For mobile digital services, Optus can charge an initial administration fee of $100 and an ongoing monthly charge of between $10 and $170, depending on the level of intrinsic value. Optus's total access service charges include a number usage fee for numbers with intrinsic value. A connection premium of an additional $350 is charged for keyword numbers and monthly access fees range from $600 to $3,000 for other classes of services.
Monthly fees of up to $625 are charged for reserving numbers that perhaps are not even in use. Some numbers carry the additional requirement of having at least tens of thousands of dollars worth of calls recorded on them each month if the customer is to retain that number. Clearly, special service numbers can be extremely lucrative and should not be made available free of charge to a few established carriers for substantial commercial benefit.
Austel is still consulting with carriers, service providers and groups such as the Numbering Advisory Committee on the final method of charging to be adopted, but many numbers will individually attract charges of less than $1 when they are allocated as part of a block. I understand that the most likely option is for numbers with the most digits, such as the 190 series, to attract the smallest charge because there is a clear attraction to customers in easily dialling a 13 six‐digit number by comparison.
Optus clearly has already developed a commercially accepted method of determining the intrinsic value of different numbers based on the ease of recognition of digits or a key word. This methodology could well be the basis of future consultations with Austel on how the charging system should operate. For
example, I believe that a number such as 13 13 13 or 13 13 00, the Qantas and Ansett Australia numbers respectively, should attract a higher provider charge than the 13 22 32 number that the national rail reservations service operates from, because the first two are clearly more readily remembered and therefore have a higher value in the marketplace.
The bill establishes a maximum charge for an individual number of $100,000. While a tender bid system for each number has some appeal and may maximise government revenue, it is acknowledged that if this is to be instituted for already allocated numbers there could be some disruption to consumers who might not wish to change their carrier or service provider or run the risk of an allocated number perhaps changing hands. Instead, the charges that Austel will determine will be disallowable instruments, so parliament will have the opportunity to scrutinise the level of charges. Carriers and service providers who, say, pay $200,000 for a block of numbers will be able to levy differential charges on the numbers they perceive as the most and least valuable to their respective customers.
Importantly, when this bill is passed there will be an incentive for carriers such as Telstra and Optus who might have been allocated large blocks of numbers to return unused series to Austel for redistribution to new entrants. This is most important because a new carrier or service provider without reasonable ready access to telephone numbers as well as reasonable access charges is like a week in Melbourne without a special event.
Telephone numbers affected by the Telecommunications (Numbering Fees) Amendment Bill 1996 are a public resource. It is appropriate that the government recover a part of the costs of their provision to telecommunications companies and service providers.
The other bill that we are discussing today, the Telecommunications Amendment Bill 1996, relates to the Telecommunications Act 1991. It gives Austel the authority to actually collect the numbering fee charges imposed by the legislation I have just spoken of as well as clarifying exemptions for employees of carriers and service providers who disclose
customer information to emergency service operators. My colleague the member for Bendigo (Mr Reid) will discuss this matter in more detail.
Let me simply say that the act currently provides for this information to be provided directly to police, fire and ambulance service officers but not directly to people who are contracted by these emergency services to assist in the call response and dispatch system. I would hate to see constituents in the electorate of Dunkley disadvantaged purely because of a decision by a government on how it chooses to provide those emergency services, perhaps involving a private contractor, meaning that information which is available is not conveyed to those emergency service personnel, is held back for fear of prosecution.
As I indicated above, these two bills are part of the coalition government's emphasis on encouraging the telecommunications industry—a provider of critically important services to business and householders, a sector that can grow, guided by a fair and contemporary regulatory system. While less momentous than the comprehensive industry competition and regulation package to be debated in the House later in this session, these bills are nonetheless important. I am confident that over the next few years the quality of service provided by an increasing number of carriers and service providers who will enter the market will only improve under these sorts of reforms. I commend the bills to the House.
Mr REID
(Bendigo)
(10.20 p.m.)
—I want to make a few brief comments on a very important aspect of the telecommunications legislation. They relate to the amendments to the Telecommunications Act relating to disclosure of information to emergency services which implement minor policy changes that are necessary to address recent changes in the way that telecommunications companies and emergency services interact and coordinate their respective operations.
My reason for doing this is that we are constantly reminded in Victoria and in Australia that we do live in fire prone environments. No-one needs to be reminded of this,
with the recent tragic loss of life and damage to homes in Victoria. The need for our emergency services to be able to coordinate their respective operations with the telecommunications system in Australia is vitally important.
The bill in fact amends section 88 of the act to permit information about persons telephoning for emergency assistance to be disclosed to emergency service operators where calls are made on any telephone number identified by Austel as an emergency number in the national numbering plan. The fact is that 000 is now not the only emergency number—112 has also been specified by Austel in the numbering plan as an alternative number for callers using mobile phones. There is also a proposal to allocate another short number for access by the hearing and speech impaired, who must currently call a 1800 number to access emergency services as access through the 000 number is impractical.
I want to return briefly to the role that was played by our emergency services during the tragic fires in Victoria and pay a compliment to all of the members of our emergency services—the Victoria Police, the Country Fire Authority, the Metropolitan Fire Brigade, the state emergency services, the Red Cross, the Salvation Army and all of the welfare agents who do play a vital role in assisting when we do have an outbreak of fire in parts of Australia, particularly in Victoria.
I will keep my comments brief, but I believe that this is a very important matter being addressed in this bill. I compliment the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government (Mr Warwick Smith), who is at the table, for his role in this and also the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Senate Alston) in another place.
Mr WARWICK SMITH
(Bass—
Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Sydney 2000 Games)
(10.23 p.m.)
—in reply—I want to take a few moments to summarise the debate. Firstly, I thank the members for Werriwa (Mr Latham), Dunkley (Mr Billson) and Bendigo (Mr Reid) for their contributions, particularly the members for Dunkley and Bendigo, who elaborated on the
second reading speech when we introduced these two bills late last year.
The member for Dunkley talked at length about the concerns and the rationale behind changing the numbering fee charging system. It will be done by Austel, the experts in this field. It will be a disallowable instrument and it will reflect the true value of those numbers—they have been talking about specialised numbers, not about the standard or business connection phones—to recoup, to the benefit of taxpayers and the Commonwealth, significant amounts of money because of the value of those numbers. I thank him for his contribution which was very erudite.
The member for Bendigo referred to the other bill that is being introduced primarily in relation to emergency services, and what is emerging as an increasing reliance on emergency services being accessed other than by 000 numbers. He did not mention at any length the privacy considerations, but they are also taken care of in that amendment bill. I thank him for his remarks about those matters that we see as a proliferation. He mentioned the TTY services for the hearing impaired, for example. It is extremely important that they be able to access emergency services. He cited the recent difficulties in Victoria where we saw the requirement because of the fires for people to access emergency services very quickly.
There was one point that was mentioned by the members for Werriwa and Dunkley and it related to zonal charging arrangements. Mr Deputy Speaker Nehl, I think you even mentioned it yourself. Communities outside urban centres have difficulties with the charging regimes because of these zonal arrangements. This was identified in a report in 1989 called
Poles Apart
. It has been a continuing issue. I think the member for Werriwa, in a moment of complete honesty, indicated that this has been a problem for some considerable time. I notice that the shadow minister at the table, the member for Holt (Mr Gareth Evans), was the Minister for Transport and Communications at the time we first started to discuss how to deal with this problem.
There have been some arrangements put in place to extend untimed charging zones.
Those matters will obviously continue to be considered by the carriers and the government. Difficulties arise at times, and of course we are aware of those. We hope that as we move to a more highly deregulated and competitive arrangement in telecommunications these issues will be addressed successfully to the benefit of consumers.
With those few remarks, I thank those speakers for contributing and commend the House for its anticipated support of both of these matters. They are important matters. They are interim in nature until the full package of telecommunications legislation is passed by the House and the Senate to reflect the changes that have been made now to become part of that total reform package, which will take effect in the middle of the year.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Third Reading
Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
Bill (on motion by
Mr Warwick Smith
) read a third time.
TELECOMMUNICATIONS BILL 1996

Consideration resumed.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

Mr Warwick Smith
) read a third time.
CHARTER OF BUDGET HONESTY BILL 1996
Second Reading
Debate resumed from 11 December, on motion by
Mr Costello
:
That the bill be now read a second time.
Mr GARETH EVANS
(Holt—
Deputy Leader of the Opposition)
(10.29 p.m.)
—It takes a very considerable degree of chutzpah
for a government to introduce a Charter of Budget Honesty Bill when it has been responsible for the most dishonest budget probably introduced into this country since Federation. How can the government credibly choose to talk about budget honesty when in last year's budget they broke at a minimum $17 billion worth of promises? To give just a sampling of the scores of broken promises that did occur in last year's budget, let me mention these: for a start, the coalition promised `to maintain existing levels of Commonwealth funding to the ABC'. That was broken before the budget with there now being a $209 million cut to the ABC scheduled over a four‐year period. The coalition promise that it had no plans `whatever to change the operational subsidy to the community based long day care sector' was broken by the budget abolishing operational subsidies for community based long day care which will increase fees by at least $14 per child per week.
Debate interrupted.
ADJOURNMENT
Mr SPEAKER
—Order! It being 10.30 p.m., I propose the question:
That the House do now adjourn.
ACT: Economy
Ms ELLIS
(Namadgi)
(10.30 p.m.)
—I think it is important for me as the member for Namadgi and as a member of the ACT community to bring to the attention of members of the House, should it so miss their attention, that Access Economics—a firm I think people on the benches opposite know quite well—had the job last week of announcing that the ACT is now formally in a recession and a very serious one. In no part is the blame for this due to anybody other than the Liberal-coalition government federally and the Liberal government at the ACT level.
We are seeing continuing unemployment in the ACT holding at a very alarming level, particularly in relation to youth unemployment. We are seeing the effects of the government's cuts to higher education, the changes to HECS and the impact that these decisions are having within the ACT. We are seeing in the ACT a dramatic and continuing
fall in house values—not house prices per se but house values.
People in the community are alarmed to the point of despair as to what they believe they have done to deserve such treatment from a government of this calibre, particularly when we recall not that far back the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) kept making statements such as, `We will govern for all of us. This is a parliament and a government for all of us.' It seems that the government has excised the ACT out of the map of Australia, because I cannot think of any other reason why the ACT is being treated in such a draconian fashion.
The most alarming thing about Access Economics' announcement that we are now in a formal recession is that this really cements very clearly in the community's mind the fear that they have been suffering and experiencing over the last few months. I do not think I can recall in all of the many years that I have lived in the ACT a lack of confidence both on the part of individuals and on the part of some business in this town as to their degree of spending.
I was speaking to a family last week who live in my electorate, in the Tuggeranong Valley. The gentleman concerned is a middle ranging public servant whose wife works part time. They have two old bombs of cars. They decided a few months ago that they would trade them both in and get a new car, but they have not done that. They have not done that because they are scared to spend their money. They are scared because they do not know whether either or both of them will have their job next week or next month.
This couple are not an isolated case; they are typical of many ordinary families—who, I might add, I thought this government was standing up for—who are terrified that their future tenure in this community is at such threat that they will not spend their money, if in fact they have any. The ongoing effect of that is that you have this down spiralling of economic confidence and business suffers as a result. Because of this lack of confidence, you have businesses unwilling or scared to employ anybody new.
The forthcoming budget in May is being treated with a certain amount of dread in this country. We have already received dramatic cuts not only to the public sector, which we talk about often, but to government spending in sectors of private industry which have until now had a viable future in the ACT.
The feeling amongst the community now is: what on earth will this forthcoming budget hold for our community? What sorts of cuts will continue? What will they be? At what level will they be? What sort of rate will they be held at? More importantly than ever from the community point of view: at what price will those cuts occur?
Does the government and the Prime Minister really care what they are doing to the national capital? Not only do we have a community here of families of ordinary working‐class people; we also happen to live in—and are very proud of the fact that we live in and support—the national capital of this wonderful country. Tourists to the ACT are very proud to see the ACT look the way it is.
No wonder the people in the electorate of Fraser last weekend voted to the point where we will hold the seat of Fraser on a two-party preferred basis by the biggest margin we have ever held that seat by. Surely to heaven the government and the Prime Minister must get a message from that. Enough is enough. Stop doing this to the national capital. Stop raping and pillaging this community and start to realise that you are having an effect on a range of people who have done nothing to deserve it. They deserve no more nor less than any other people in this country.
When you talk about and look very carefully at the words of Access Economics—as I said, a business you know very well—take their words very seriously and consider very seriously the impact of your decisions on this community.
(Time expired)
Rural Training Program
Mr TONY SMITH
(Dickson)
(10.35 p.m.)
—Before in this House I have mentioned the Bunya Bunya rural training program. Just very quickly to recap, this program is undertaken by Fusion Australia at the former
Marsden Home for Boys situated at Kallangur in my electorate. The rural training program basically addresses the needs of very disadvantaged youth. I speak in particular of young people who have in many respects come on the wrong side of the law, have come from broken homes and are very difficult to manage and, more particularly, to get into and keep in a program of this nature.
It was my great pleasure just before Christmas to attend the Marsden home for the graduation ceremony of six graduates from this course. Seven people were enrolled in the course, but one could not complete for a number of reasons that were not relevant to the capacity of the trainers. Six people completed the course and all six were placed in out-stations all around Australia, particularly in the Northern Territory, Western Australia and parts of Queensland, I am pleased to say.
At that graduation ceremony we witnessed a number of demonstrations by these boys—the course is also open to girls—all aged between 18 and 22. We saw such things as the use of the tractors; riding of horses; operation of chainsaws, in particular in relation to fencing; and some skills in relation to the growing of small crops. It was a great pleasure to be there and present these boys with their graduation certificates and, as well, to hear them speak about the pleasures and benefits that they gained from doing such a course.
I emphasise how important this is to the community and how, whilst in this particular case the trainers had an almost 100 per cent success rate in terms of outcome, we ought not necessarily focus on outcomes as an economic rationalist way of looking at training in this particular case. We should have regard to the nature of the boys who come to do these courses—their background and the sorts of problems they have had in the community. The fact is that it is saving the community an awful lot of money to have them training in this way and also going to jobs rather than have them on the wrong side of the law, re‐offending and causing enormous social dislocation in the community. So I was very pleased to see that they did graduate.
However, I have since had an unfortunate occurrence. I have now been told by Fusion that the department has come back to them and said that their outcomes are not sufficient and that they need better outcomes overall. Figures were produced to show that over a period of time their outcomes were down to about 25 per cent. As the head of the program said to me, `Well, anyone can produce figures. We had 100 per cent last time.' Apparently, they have looked into the system and found that over time a number of people have gone back on unemployment benefits. However, the fact of the matter is that, even if only 25 per cent of these boys and girls are placed in work, in a situation where we are dealing with this sort of disadvantaged youth we are achieving great outcomes and savings to the community.
In my view, any criteria on the basis that there must be guarantees in relation to outcomes really has to be looked at again, since it has been said to me by the trainer that they are looking for a guarantee that there will be a 70 per cent outcome. In my respectful opinion, that is not realistic in relation to disadvantaged youths in circumstances such as these.
So I hope that this situation will be reviewed and that there will be a continuation of the Bunya Bunya training program. It is serving the people of Dickson, serving the people of Pine Rivers and, overall, saving the community enormous sums of money by not having these people incarcerated.
Blacktown City Chamber of Commerce and Industry
Mr MOSSFIELD
(Greenway)
(10.40 p.m.)
—In this adjournment debate I would like to speak about the work of the Blacktown City Chamber of Commerce and Industry. This chamber has been promoting business and employment growth in western Sydney for over 40 years. The chamber represents some 1,000 businesses in western Sydney and is active in seeking ways to assist both business and local communities by promoting full employment and business opportunities.
The chamber was active during the term of the previous government in promoting labour
market programs and is equally interested in continuing this cooperation. To this end, the chamber recently accepted responsibility to promote traineeships as part of a national program which has proved to be of enormous assistance in providing trained candidates with employment. The chamber's responsibility in this program is designed to promote traineeships from the Hawkesbury through to Burwood.
The Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry, DEETYA, Nettforce and the Blacktown City Chamber of Commerce and Industry are working together with group and industry training companies on a pilot program. John Camp, who is the chamber's regional training marketing consultant, is one of 10 consultants who has been selected to coordinate this national program. With the upcoming Olympic Games, considerable employment growth is expected in western Sydney. Industries such as the media, information technology, sport and recreation, hospitality and business services will attract future employees and apprentices of all ages. With progressive organisations like the chamber operating in the region to tap into major projects like the Olympic Games, the prospect for employment of young people should improve considerably.
Already the success of this program is evident. In the December period the chamber handled 55 successful placements—15 were apprenticeships and 40 were traineeships. As the facilitator and coordinator, the chamber is putting into practice the very plans and policies that were the hallmark of the previous Labor government's approach to labour market issues; that is, involving all the local community in the problems and the solutions.
The chamber, through its chief executive officer, is an active member of the Blacktown Workplace Learning Committee which, for over three years, has been promoting workplace learning for local year 11 and 12 school children in industries. The chamber has developed close links with over 50 government, education and community groups in this region to promote business opportunities. In addition to those that I have already mentioned, these include the Blacktown City
Council, TAFE, the University of Western Sydney, Skillshare, the Salvation Army, the Blacktown Migrant Resource Centre and the Blacktown Aboriginal Corporation.
The chamber is administered by a full-time chief executive officer, Ms Bev Norton, who has been the CEO for five years. Ms Norton has a full-time staff of 10 professional and clerical employees. Bev Norton, prior to becoming the CEO, held the position of president and vice-president during her 26 years of association with the chamber.
The chamber is currently considering a project for 1997—the development of a research department. This department will determine the needs, strengths and weaknesses of small business at a local government, regional and state basis. The purpose of this project would be to develop a structure that could establish information relating to the reasons for the success or failure of small business in a defined area, to determine areas where additional training is required and to advise governments on legislative changes to assist small business. The research project is aimed at a wider area than western Sydney and would focus particularly on small- to medium-sized businesses.
In summary, the project is aimed at improving economic development, increasing membership, improving services to members, obtaining information to lobby government, training in public relations development and establishing a statistical research unit which would be able to be self-funding. The chamber would be seeking funding from DEETYA to assist them to set up and train the research team. There is sufficient evidence available, based on previous successful chamber projects, for this particular idea to be the subject of further joint investigation. As the federal member for this area, I would be actively supporting this chamber's many employment generating projects.
Lilley Australia Day Awards
Mrs ELIZABETH GRACE
(Lilley)
(10.45 p.m.)
—It was my privilege on Australia Day to participate in the Lilley Australia Day Awards. The Lilley Australia Day Awards is a community based awards scheme that sym
bolises our appreciation for the hard work and diligence of our quiet achievers in my electorate. This year over 500 people paid tribute to 53 quiet achievers from the Lilley electorate.
As the federal member for Lilley, I was honoured to have played a role in this year's awards and would like to take this opportunity to thank the dedicated committee of locals who worked non‐stop since April 1996 to make the Lilley Australia Day Awards such a success.
The chairman of the committee, Mr Ken Ryley OAM, has said this year's awards were the best ever. The quality of the nominees for this year's awards were outstanding and the Lilley community is very fortunate to be served by such people.
The Lilley Australia Day Awards recognise the efforts of everyday people who make such a difference to the daily lives of the many residents in Lilley. The outstanding community contributions of these selfless volunteers cannot be underestimated.
What was also special about this year's awards was that the recipients came from a wide range of age groups and were involved in a wide variety of community activities. These activities included community service, education, sport, youth, cultural and environmental activities.
The day was a great success and really made me proud to be an Australian. Before the presentation ceremony, we were entertained by a local poet called Herb Wegener, who is a bush poet from the old school. His poems were very original and laced with good old Australian humour. Bishop John Gerry, the auxiliary bishop for Brisbane, and I proudly presented the 53 quiet achievers with their commemorative badges and certificates. A shiver went up my spine when the day was capped off with over 500 people singing
Advance Australia Fair
in unison and waving miniature Australian flags. The room was literally ablaze with red, white and blue and it was a great moment to be an Australian.
The generosity of Bill Gollan Car Sales, Golden Circle, Comprite, Kedron Wavell Services Club and the Returned Services League helped sponsor this year's event.
Without this sponsorship of local businesses, the community would not benefit by these awards.
I would also like to pay special tribute to Ted Tremayne. Ted unfortunately passed away a week before the awards, but it was Ted who first came to me and said, `Let's get on with it. Let's get these awards under way.' It is a great privilege to be the member for Lilley in these circumstances when you have people like that in your electorate.
Telecommunications Tower
Environment
Mr LEE
(Dobell)
(10.48 p.m.)
—I would like to begin by advising the House of some public meetings in my own electorate, called by residents in opposition to a plan by Vodafone to build a 30‐metre telecommunications tower in Bon Mace Crescent in Tumbi Umbi. The first I learned of this was in mid‐January when local residents advised me that they were planning to hold a public meeting a couple of days later in a park adjacent to the proposed site of the Vodafone tower. That public meeting was surprisingly well attended, with 150 to 200 local residents expressing their opposition to Vodafone's plans to build the mobile phone tower in an area that has quite a dense residential population and is relatively close to a number of local schools.
There were a number of questions from members of the public to the mayor, Doug Eaton, and me about whether we were aware that Vodafone had originally sought an alternate site—an alternate site that some members of the public thought was on a ridge away from the residential population at a location in Anderson Road. The mayor advised the 150 residents that he had checked this out and it was incorrect. I discovered a few days later that, contrary to the mayor's claims and the advice that he had given to the residents at the public meeting, Vodafone did in fact lodge a formal application with Wyong Council to build the tower on a ridge in Anderson Road in Berkeley Vale. I am very pleased that, at its last meeting, Wyong Council reconsidered its position and has now resolved to oppose Vodafone's second pre ferred site in Bon Mace Crescent, Tumbi
Umbi, and the council is now willing to accept Vodafone's original site of the ridge in Anderson Road, Berkeley Vale.
I have to say that I hope Vodafone takes note of the council's new position of supporting the site in Anderson Road. It is certainly the very strong view of the people who work in the industrial estate at Tumbi Umbi and the local residents who live in Berkeley Vale nearby that Vodafone should go back to their original site on the ridge in Anderson Road, Berkeley Vale.
I would also like to take this opportunity to express my concern about plans by this government to provide an additional period to telephone companies to be exempt from the local and state planning laws. I think at the moment the Minister for Communications and the Arts, Richard Alston, is planning to allow the telephone companies an additional two months past the 1 July deadline this year to be exempt from the planning power, and I think that is something we should resist wholeheartedly.
I also think we have to be careful about any transitional provisions that allow telephone companies to build willy‐nilly these mobile telephone towers simply because they have lodged some notification with the local council. If 1 July comes and a telephone company hasn't finished the construction of the tower, the government's transitional provision shouldn't allow the telephone companies in effect to have an exemption from the federal and state planning powers for years to come. I think that 1 July deadline should be quite firm.
The second issue I would like to raise tonight concerns the environment. I would like to express my concern about a number of changes that the government made in last year's budget that will affect a number of local people on the Central Coast who will be able to work on employment improvement projects.
Under the LEAP scheme in 1995‐96 we had 920 commencements by local unemployed people on not just the Central Coast but the wider Hunter northern area but not including Newcastle. In my own electorate, they carried out bush regeneration and the construction of
nature trails in Ourimbah, landscaping and planting native gardens at a number of schools in the Wyong district and beautification of local parks. A lot of good work was done under LEAP.
This year the government has axed LEAP and tried to replace it with the Green Corps. Unfortunately, the Green Corps projects that have been announced to date do not include any projects on the New South Wales Central Coast. In fact, only 440 places will be funded Australia‐wide—much less than in 1996‐97 and much less than the 920 we had in our own local regional area. I would hope to have the support of my colleague the honourable member for Robertson (Mr Lloyd) in asking the government to perhaps reconsider its decision to axe LEAP and, at the very least, to match the Labor government's ability to provide 920 placements on the Central Coast and in the Hunter northern region in this financial year.
Environment
Interest Rates
Mr LLOYD
(Robertson)
(10.53 p.m.)
—Firstly, in response to the member for Dobell (Mr Lee), obviously I will be supporting the need for the Green Corps on the Central Coast. There are other initiatives which are happening on the Central Coast. Only last week, under the coast care and dune care initiatives, I announced five separate projects in my electorate to help with the regeneration of our environment on the Central Coast. So the government is doing something about the environment on the Central Coast. I certainly will be pushing for additional Green Corps funding, as well as supporting the member for Dobell in that initiative.
Tonight I want to raise my concerns about interest rates, particularly high business loan overdraft rates. Home loan interest rates have continued to fall by up to 2½ per cent since the coalition took office less than 12 months ago, to the lowest levels in 30 years, creating massive savings for families and first home buyers in the range of $188 per month. Coupled with continued low inflation and sound economic management by our govern ment, most Australians can look forward to
1997 and beyond with optimism and confidence.
However, I wish to raise my concerns over business interest rates. Whilst banking deregulation has seen intense competition in the home loan market, business interest rates have remained unacceptably high. During 1996, we saw the major banks announce massive profits. On 12 November last year, Westpac announced a net annual profit of $1.13 billion. On 20 November, the ANZ Banking Group announced, according to the
Canberra Times
, a dazzling, higher than expected profit of $1.116 billion for 1995‐96. The National Australia Bank also released a record net profit of $2.1 billion. Even the St George Bank released a 1996 net profit of $148.3 million—a rise of nine per cent over 1995. I understand that these financial institutions have obligations to their shareholders, but I also believe the major banks have an obligation to pass on reductions in official interest rates to the small business sector.
Whilst home loan interest rates have fallen to levels that we have not seen in this country for 30 years, business and personal loans remain high. Businesses are still burdened with interest rates of 14 per cent or higher, with penalty rates of up to 17 per cent if you should exceed your overdraft limit, even for one day. In addition, many banks have now introduced increased charges; for example, $15 for each and every cheque that is cashed while the business account remains in excess of the approved overdraft limit.
For 13 years small businesses suffered under a Labor government that had no idea how to run the economy—a government that presided over record interest rates and unacceptably high levels of inflation. Thousands of small businesses were destroyed by the recession that we had to have. Thousands of families were destroyed, dreams shattered, lives shattered. Only now can small business begin to invest with confidence in the sound economic environment of consistently low interest rates and low inflation. Major banks must begin to offer more competitive loans for businesses and examine some of their many charges and fees which are a disincen
tive to invest, to expand and, most importantly, to create jobs.
My electorate of Robertson on the New South Wales Central Coast relies heavily on small business. We have few major employers, but we have a vital economy with new businesses opening up every day. Robertson is the fastest growing electorate in New South Wales and the seventh fastest in Australia. We need the banks to get off the back of small business and to pass on the falls in official interest rates not only to home loans but to business overdrafts as well.
The government's efforts to revitalise small business are being stifled and blocked at every corner by the attitude of the major banks: by their never‐ending increasing fees and charges, by their unwillingness to pass on realistic lower interest rates, and by the distinct change in attitude that has occurred in relation to customer service by the major banking organisations over the past decade. It would appear that the banks are preoccupied with profit, preoccupied with forcing customers to use electronic and telephone banking services and preoccupied with the reduction of branches and staffing levels.
Another negative by‐product of this attitude is the lack of savings incentives, particularly for young people. Australians have a dangerously low level of savings, and yet the big brother, standover attitude that is often experienced when young people attempt to open savings accounts is hardly conducive to creating increased savings habits. There is something drastically wrong when you receive three per cent to save and yet are charged 15 per cent to establish a business investing in the future of this nation and creating jobs for all Australians. This cannot be allowed to continue.
Unemployment
Mr STEPHEN SMITH
(Perth)
(10.58 p.m.)
—In the very short time available to me, I would like to make some remarks this evening on what I regard as the most important economic and social problem and issue facing Australia at the moment—continuing high unemployment.
The Mid‐year Economic and Fiscal Outlook released by the Treasurer (Mr Costello) in the last few days with great fanfare is a searing indictment of the government's attitude to continuing high unemployment. Page 1 of the Mid‐year Economic and Fiscal Outlook refers to growth in GDP of 3½ per cent expected in 1996‐97, unchanged from the forecast at budget time. The paper then refers to it being accompanied by moderate but continuing employment growth, and the forecast for employment growth is unchanged. On page 4 of the outlook document we see the comment:
The labour market is expected to improve, but only at a pace sufficient to generate a gradual decline in the unemployment rate. Achieving faster reductions in unemployment will be dependent upon opportunities taken to adopt more flexible arrangements in the labour market.
When you turn to the key table on page 4, you find that, so far as the labour market is concerned, the employment forecast has not changed from the budget to the revised forecast. The participation rate from the budget forecast to the revised forecast has not changed either—63¾per cent. But, for the unemployment rate, the forecast is from the budget forecast of 8¼ per cent to an increased revised forecast of 8½ per cent.
Here we see the government presiding over 3½ per cent growth in GDP in the economy, with increasing unemployment. What commitment do we see from them on reducing unemployment? The only commitment we see from them is the mystical solution that achieving faster reductions in unemployment will depend upon opportunities taken to adopt more flexible arrangements in the labour market. They are handcuffed to that. When those changes do not improve unemployment one iota, the government will stand absolutely condemned.
House adjourned at 11 p.m.
REPLIES TO REQUESTS FOR DETAILED INFORMATION
Rwwanda: Gallantry Medals
Mr Price
asked the Speaker on 2 December 1996:
I have a question for you, Mr Speaker, and I do concur in the remarks that you made. As
you know, a number of members and senators were privileged to visit Rwanda and Kibeho, the camp where the massacre subsequently occurred. Could you take up with the minister and the Governor-General whether or not it would have been appropriate for those members so privileged to have witnessed the soldiers in the field to have been privileged to witness the presentation of the medals for gallantry.
Mr Speaker
—The Minister for Defence Industry, Science and Personnel has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:
Thank you for your letter of 9 December 1996 concerning the presentation of the Rwanda Gallantry Medals and the various suggestions contained within.
With respect to Mr Price's question as to whether Members of Parliament who visited Rwanda might have been present to witness the presentation of the medals, the Investiture Ceremony was organised by Government House and my office had no involvement in the determination of the invitation list. However the Opposition Spokesman for Defence was invited and attended the ceremony.
In response to the question put to you by the Leader of the Opposition proposing a parliamentary statement on the medal presentation, the Chief of the Defence Force made a public announcement of the awards on the 25th November 1996 with little resulting publicity. I then decided that the use of question time was the most appropriate forum to give these people the proper public recognition they deserved. I do not believe that the awarding of Gallantry Medals should be a matter for debate which a Ministerial statement would entail.
In relation to your suggestion of assembling the medal recipients in the House of Representatives Gallery to be recognised by the Chair, the four recipients of the Medal for Gallantry are based in Townsville QLD, Kapooka NSW, Swanbourne WA and Heatley QLD respectively and it would be impractical and costly to assemble them in Canberra in the short amount of time available during the current sittings. However I will pass on your
kind words to the Chief of the Defence Force in recognition of their feats.
Question Time
Mr Price
asked the Speaker on 6 November 1996:
Mr Speaker, I have two questions to you relating to question time yesterday. After the response of the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training in answering a question, the Prime Minister rose in his place and asked that further questions be placed on the
Notice Paper
. However, a further question was allowed by the member for Capricornia. Can you look at the videotape of proceedings of question time and determine whether page 6311 of
Hansard
accurately reflects what actually occurred in question time.
My second question relates to page 6305 of
Hansard
and the question asked by the honourable member for Hinkler regarding pensioner entitlements. According to House of Representatives Practice, page 524 of Browning, questions should not be asked without notice reflecting questions on the
Notice Paper
. I draw your attention to questions No. 905 to the Treasurer, No. 907 to the Minister for Social Security and No. 908 to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. Whilst I appreciate that this was not brought to your attention at the time, would you consider writing to the ministers in view of the breach of standing orders and requesting an early response to those questions on notice.
Mr Speaker
—The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
I refer to your question of 10 September to the Acting Speaker concerning my replies to questions to me.
I would not propose to respond in the House to all questions to me. I will however see that on those occasions when I do write to a Member, the response will be included in Hansard in much the same way as questions on notice.

Department of Veterans' Affairs: Grants
(Question No. 308)
Mr Martin Ferguson
asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 30 May 1996:
(1) Did the Minister's Department, any agency or statutory authority for which the Minister has portfolio responsibility, or their predecessors, approve or make available grants or other forms of financial assistance in (a) 1993‐94, (b) 1994‐95 and (c) 1995‐96 to (i) employer organisations or (ii) individual companies; if so, in each case, (A) what was the name and address of the recipient, (B) what sum was involved, (C) what was the purpose of the grant or payment, (D) under what program was it made, (E) who approved the payment, (F) what acquittal requirements applied to the grant or payment and (G) is acquittal outstanding.

Child Care: Funding
(Question No. 626)
Mr McClelland
asked the Minister for Family Services, upon notice, on 9 September 1996:
(1) Has her attention been drawn to a public meeting held in Hurstville on 30 July to discuss the Government's plans to abolish child care subsidies, remove operational funding for public child care centres and replace the current system with a means tested benefit.
(2) Has her attention also been drawn to a statement by the Mayor of Hurstville that his Council was likely to lose its family day care scheme if the Government's cuts went ahead and that this would mean the loss of care for more than 157 children and the loss of jobs for at least 27 people.
(3) What reduction has taken place in funding for and on child care facilities in the electoral division of Barton following the 1996 Budget.
Mrs Moylan
—The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1) Yes
(2) Yes
(3) Currently there are 30 child care centres, two Family Day Care Schemes and 21 Outside School Hours Care Services in the electoral division of Barton eligible to receive Childcare Assistance on behalf of parents using the services. Operational subsidies will continue to be paid for Family Day Centres, Outside School Hours Care, Occasional Care, Multi‐Functional Services and Multi‐Functional Aboriginal Children's Services.
The Budget includes some changes to Childcare Assistance but as these do not come into effect until after 1 April 1997, to date there has been no reduction in funding.
There are 30 centres in Barton. Of these only five are community based, and Operational Subsidies will be withdrawn from these five centres on 1 July 1997. However, the Budget includes $8.3 million over two years to help these services identify efficiencies and so minimise the impact of the loss of operational subsidies. Extra funding for Supplementary Services (SUPS) and for additional hands‐on care for children with `high needs', particularly children with a disability, will assist these centres to continue to provide care for these children.
Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport: Safety Incidents
(Question No. 652)
Mr McClelland
asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, upon notice, on 10 September 1996:
(1) How many reported incidents involving breaches of safety procedures or near collisions at airport runway intersections have occurred in the period 1 January 1990 to 9 September 1996 at (a) Sydney (Kingsford‐Smith) Airport, (b) other airports throughout Australia where cross runway operations have been used and (c) airports throughout the world where cross runway operations are utilised.
(2) Is he able to provide (a) the dates and (b) a brief description of each incident referred to in part (1).
(3) Has the Sydney Air Traffic Management Task Force of Airservices Australia requested either the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation or the Civil Aviation Safety Authority to research these occurrences and report to the Task Force in order for
details of such incidents to be considered by the Task Force before it reports to him on or about 16 December 1996; if not, why not.
(4) Will he direct the Sydney Air Traffic Management Task Force to have regard to this information before it reports to him.
Mr Sharp
—The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1) (a) The Bureau of Air Safety Investigation (BASI) has advised that during the period 1 January 1990 to 9 September 1996 a total of five (5) occurrences were reported to the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation (BASI) involving a breach of safety procedures at runway intersections at Sydney (Kingsford‐Smith) Airport.
(b) During that same period, the number of reported occurrences involving a breach of safety procedures at runway intersections at other airports throughout Australia were as follows:
one (1) at Wagga Airport; three (3) at Canberra Airport; one (1) at Adelaide Airport; and two (2) at Essendon Airport.
(c) The Australian Bureau of Air Safety Investigation does not and is not required to keep records of overseas air safety occurrences. Therefore, my response to the honourable member's question is based on reported occurrences involving aircraft operations in Australia.
(2)(a) and (b) A synopsis of each occurrence referred to in part 1 is set out below.
Sydney (Kingsford‐Smith) Airport
(a) 12 August 1991. A McDonnell Douglas DC‐10 Series 30ER aircraft (DC‐10) was landing on runway 34 at Sydney (Kingsford‐Smith) Airport. At the same time, an Airbus A320‐211 aircraft (A320), was on a short final approach for landing on runway 25. Runways 34 and 25 intersect, and Simultaneous Runway Operations (SIMOPS) were in progress. Landing instructions to the crew of the DC‐10 included a requirement for the aircraft to be held short of the intersection of runways 34 and 25. A Boeing B747 aircraft was holding on taxiway Victor (EVE), north of runway 25 and west of runway 34, awaiting the landing of the A320 and a subsequent clearance to cross runway 07/25. While observing the DC‐10's landing roll, the captain of the A320 judged that the DC‐10 might not stop before the intersection of the runways. He elected to initiate a go‐around from a low height above the runway. Under heavy braking, the DC‐10 slowed to about 2 knots ground speed, at which time the nose of the aircraft was approximately level with the edge of runway 07/25. During the go‐around executed by the crew of the A320, that aircraft passed above the DC‐10 on its left and the B747 on the right of its flight path.
(b) 19 October 1991. A Cessna 441 aircraft was cleared to land on runway 07 which included a requirement to hold short of runway 16 in accordance with SIMOPS procedures. During the landing, both tyres on the main landing gear of the Cessna were punctured and rapidly deflated. The pilot was unable to stop the aircraft prior to runway 16. Two other aircraft were instructed to go around due to the obstructed runway.
(c) 16 March 1993. A British Aerospace BAE‐125‐1OOOB aircraft was instructed to `Maintain 3000, line up and hold' for runway 16. Shortly after the aerodrome controllers observed the aircraft apparently commencing a take‐off roll. The aircraft was instructed to stop immediately which was accomplished by taxiway B4. An Airbus A320‐211 aircraft cleared to land on runway 07, was able to continue its approach and land.
(d) 19 September 1993. During the passage of a thunderstorm, there were several runway changes. A Boeing B737‐376 aircraft initially taxied for runway 07 then runway 25. On reaching the holding point for runway 25, there was a further change to runway 34. The aircraft was instructed to taxi along runway 25 and hold short of runway 34. The aircraft did not comply with this instruction and crossed runway 34 whilst another Boeing B737‐476 aircraft was landing on that runway. Both aircraft were permitted to continue as there was no perceived danger of collision.
(e) 24 December 1993. A Piper PA‐31‐350 aircraft was cleared to land on runway 07 which included a requirement to hold short of runway 16. During takeoff on runway 16, the pilots of a De Havilland DHC‐8‐102 aircraft monitored the Piper which ultimately stopped inside runway 16.
Wagga Airport
(f) 24 April 1991. An Auster J5 aircraft landed prior to last light without any transmissions due to a radio failure. The aircraft conflicted with a Piper PA‐32R‐300 aircraft which was backtracking and a Mitsubishi MU‐2B‐35 aircraft on its take off run.
Canberra Airport
(g) 12 March 1993. Shortly after a Fokker F28 MK 4000 aircraft was cleared to take‐off on runway 17, the aircraft was instructed to stop immediately due to a military helicopter, an Aerospatiale AS.350B being slow to cross runway 17 during a landing approach and flare. The Fokker abandoned its take‐off run at low speed.
(h) 25 March 1994. A Cessna 172N aircraft was operating left circuits from runway 12. A Boeing B737‐376 aircraft was approaching to land on runway 35. On short final, the Cessna had been cleared to make a touch and go landing which included a requirement to not delay passing the runway intersection. The Boeing B737 had been told to expect a late landing clearance. After
touchdown, the Cessna did not expedite as requested. The Boeing B737 was cleared to land when approaching the threshold. At this time the Cessna had still not passed the runway intersection. Air Traffic Services reported that just prior to the Boeing B737 passing through the runway intersection, the Cessna overflew the intersection at a height of approximately 50‐100 feet.
(i) 18 November 1994. A Beech 58 aircraft landed on runway 35 while a Cessna 152 aircraft was on approach for crossing runway 12. The pilot of the Beech requested clearance to enter runway 30 from runway 35 but was refused, and told to continue through the intersection without delay. The air traffic controller anticipated the Beech would shortly complete the intersection crossing while continuing on runway 35 and therefore cleared the Cessna for a touch and go landing. The Beech was then observed to enter runway 30. It was too late to send the Cessna around and the controller instructed the pilots of both aircraft to stop. Both aircraft came to a halt about 350 metres apart.
Adelaide Airport
(j) 27 April 1995. A Boeing B737‐376 aircraft initiated a go‐around manoeuvre due to the proximity of a Fokker F27 MK 100 aircraft that had commenced its take‐off roll. Subsequent actions by both pilots and Air Traffic Services resulted in a possible infringement of separation standards.
Essendon Airport
(k) 11 July 1995. The duty runway at Essendon was runway 35. A Piper PA‐28‐161 aircraft was on approach to runway 35 and was number one to land. A Canadair CL600‐2B16 aircraft was inbound to Essendon via the Plenty Locator. The Canadair had been offered runway 26 with a 15 knot crosswind and the pilot had accepted that runway. The aerodrome controller said that he had advised the Canadair that he was number two to land following a light aircraft (the Piper) landing on runway 35. He said that he later advised the Canadair to expect a late landing clearance. The aerodrome controller said that he gave a landing clearance to the Canadair when the aircraft was on short final (before it had crossed the runway threshold) after he believed that the Piper had crossed the runways intersection.
As the two aircraft approached the runways intersection, each of the pilots, at the last moment, saw the other's aircraft. Both pilots initiated avoiding action by trying to alter course to the right. The left wing of the Piper collided with the left winglet of the Canadair resulting in substantial damage to those respective areas of the two aircraft. There were no injuries to persons on board and both aircraft taxied clear of the runways without assistance. This accident occurred two
minutes after last light and conditions were reported as dark.
(l) 10 August 1996. The aerodrome controller forgot to advise the pilot of a Cessna 172RG aircraft to stop short of runway 17 during a landing on runway 26. The controller cleared a Piper PA‐31 aircraft for a takeoff on runway 17. The Cessna entered runway 17 as the Piper became airborne on runway 17.
(3) The Task Force has not requested either BASI or the Civil Aviation Safety Authority
(CASA) to further research these occurrences referred to in (1) and (2) above. Information on these occurrences is already publicly available in published form.
(4) On 20 March 1996 I directed Airservices Australia to report on the long term operating plan for Sydney Airport.
This direction included the specific requirement that `the safety of aviation operations is not to be compromised'.
