Kimberley Aboriginal Pastoral Association: Funding
(Question No. 659)
Mr Campbell
asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, upon notice, on 10 September 1996:
(1) What funding has been provided to the Kimberley Aboriginal Pastoral Association (KAPA).
(2) When and on what terms and conditions was money provided.
(3) Is Mr Steve Hawke employed by KAPA; if so, (a) in what capacity and (b) what remuneration has he received.
(4) Has KAPA ever been audited; if so, will the Minister provide a copy of the audit report.
Dr Wooldridge
—The Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission has provided the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs with the following information in response to the honourable member's question:
(1) $583,819 has been funded to KAPA by ATSIC through the Kimberley Land Council (KLC) over a three year period. $815,750 was funded direct to KAPA following its incorporation in 1996.
(2) 1993/94—$290,000 for station assessment reviews.
$14,300 for Kimberley Beef Conference.
1994/95—$176,822 for KAPA administration costs.
1995/96—$102,697 for KAPA administration costs.
$344,000 to establish KAPA office and staffing.
$471,750 for purchase of breeding stock.
Standard ATSIC grant terms and conditions applied to all funding.
(3) Mr Hawke is not employed by KAPA. Mr Hawke is retained by the Kimberley Land Council to administer KAPA needs as Executive Secretary. (b) See (a).
(4) Funds provided for KAPA through the KLC have been audited through KLC audit over the past three financial years. A copy of the Audit Report for the grant made for the 1995/96 financial year has now been received and will be sent to you by the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission.
SkillShare Programs
(Question No. 667)
Mrs Crosio
asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, upon notice, on 11 September 1996:
(1) Will approximately 4.9% of Fairfield's 11,590 unemployed persons have access to SkillShare assistance during the period 1 October 1996 to 30 June 1997.
(2) Is this rate significantly lower than in any other SkillShare region in western Sydney.
(3) Is it a fact that in other regions in western Sydney, SkillShare beneficiaries average 9.1% of unemployed persons in those regions.
(4) Do regions such as St Marys, Burwood, Mt Druitt and Blacktown/Seven Hills have rates greater than 10%.
(5) Does Fairfield have the highest unemployment rate in metropolitan Sydney.
(6) Is Fairfield's SkillShare access rate the lowest in western Sydney; if so, why.
Dr Kemp
—The Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:
(1) Not all unemployed people have access to the SkillShare program. As of 7 October 1996, the eligibility criteria for participation in the SkillShare programme is those who:
have been unemployed for at least 12 months; or
are current in case management and have an agreed Case Management Activity Agreement; or
are under 21 years old.
SkillShare projects, therefore, are only funded to service a proportion of the total number of unemployed clients in their Region.
The number of SkillShare commencements for the period 1 October 1996 to 30 June 1997 approved for funding across the Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs' Sydney Western and Northern Area as primarily based on the relative percentage share of Newstart Allowance (NSA) clients who had been unemployed for at least 12 months in each of the Department's Regions in the Area as at July 1996.
The Fairfield Region had around 22% of the Area's total number of long term unemployed clients in July 1996 and was allocated 22% of the programme commencements.
The resulting allocation of 1,300 commencement approved for SkillShare projects in the Fairfield Region exceeds the 568 (ie 4.9% of 11,590) mentioned in the question.
(2),(3) and (4) No, Fairfield has more commencements than any other Region because as mentioned above, SkillShare funding (and, therefore, the allocated number of participant commencements) for the period 1 October 1996 to 30 June 1996 was primarily based on each Departmental Region's share of NSA recipients. However, some SkillShare projects service clients from outside the Departmental Region in which they are located and in these cases, some minor adjustments had to be made to the allocations. A strict Regional allocation
of funding (and, therefore, commencements) using only proportionate shares of Newstart Allowees, would not provide the necessary flexibility to service clients in those circumstances appropriately.
(5) No.
(6) No.
Second Sydney Airport
(Question No. 670)
Mr Latham
asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, upon notice, on 11 September 1996:
(1) Has the Government increased the planned capacity for Sydney's second airport from 275,000 to 360,000 aircraft movements per annum; if so, why.
(2) Since 1990 what forecasts have the (a) Federal Airports Corporation and (b) his department made for the likely use and capacity level at the second airport site.
(3) Can a 360,000 aircraft movement per annum airport be constructed on the land presently acquired by the Commonwealth at Badgerys Creek.
(4) What representations on the second airport issue has he received from the Member for Macarthur since 2 March 1996.
(5) What role did the ownership of land play in the Government's decision to examine the Holsworthy site.
(6) Did the 1985 Environmental Impact Statement (EIS) study indicate the need for an east‐west runway if the Holsworthy site was proceeded with; if so, does the current Holsworthy proposal include the construction of an east‐west runway.
(7) Will the Government abandon both the Holsworthy and Badgerys Creek sites for a second Sydney airport if at the conclusion of the EIS process neither site is shown to be suitable.
Mr Sharp
—The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1) Yes. The previous planning for a second airport was based on projections contained in the 1985 Environmental Impact Statement (EIS) that significantly underestimated the growth in aircraft movements. The median 1985 figures projected around 12 million passengers for Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport in 1995. Actual 1995 passenger numbers exceeded 18 million. In 1985, the median projections for 1995 aircraft movements were around 216,000, while actual movements in 1995 exceeded 260,000.
Demand for air travel to and from the Sydney region is expected to grow strongly for the foreseeable future, particularly from inbound tourists. The Department of Transport and Regional Develop
ment expects aircraft movements in the Sydney region to approximately double by about the year 2010.
(2)(a) The FAC has developed Sydney Basin forecasts, which have been updated annually, the last public issue being in 1993. Updated forecasts produced by the FAC have not been publicly released in view of the on‐going airport leasing process.
(b) During 1994 the then Department of Transport provided aircraft and passenger movement projections for the Sydney Basin to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure (HORSCOTI) as part of the `Inquiry into the Sydney 2000 Olympics'. In July 1995, the Department provided similar projections to the Senate Select Committee on Aircraft Noise (SSCAN), and to the Sydney Airport Community Consultative Committee (SACCC).
The projections are currently being updated to reflect the latest available statistical information and will be released in the near future.
The implications of these projections for the likely use and capacity of the second airport are being examined as part of the airport planning and environmental assessment processes.
(3) On 6 November 1996, I announced that the EIS would examine five options, three for Badgerys Creek and two for Holsworthy. These are being examined to assess the full potential of each site as a second Sydney airport. One of the options at Badgerys Creek is within the existing site boundaries and I understand that a 360,000 aircraft movement per annum airport could be constructed, with terminal facilities and associated infrastructure to cater for up to 30 million passengers per annum. Two further options at Badgerys Creek and two options at Holsworthy are being assessed to enable the EIS team to demonstrate clearly the trade‐offs between the noise, airspace, natural environment, cost and other impacts.
(4) This question is a matter for the Member for Macarthur.
(5) The Commonwealth ownership of land was one of a number of factors which was considered when the Government decided to include Holsworthy as an alternative in case the environmental impacts of a major airport at Badgerys Creek prove to be unacceptable.
(6) A cross runway was included in the initial designs for each of the ten shortlisted sites in the 1985 Environmental Impact Statement (EIS). A cross runway was not included in the final design for Badgerys Creek on the basis that the degree of usability was sufficient for an overflow airport of limited capacity.
A cross runway has been included in both options that are being assessed at Holsworthy and two of the three options at Badgerys Creek to ensure reliable operations all year round.
(7) The Government will consider issues associated with the future of both the Badgerys Creek and Holsworthy sites following completion of the EIS process.

Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training: Departmental Liaison Officer
(Question No. 762)
Mr Laurie Ferguson
asked the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training, upon notice, on 18 September 1996:
(1) Further to his answer to question 360 (
Hansard
, 28 June 1996, page 3216) and the listing in the September 1996 issue of the Parliament House Communications Directory of a third Departmental Liaison Officer (DLO) attached to his ministerial office, (a) when and (b) why was the officer appointed to his office.
(2) Is the position of Parliamentary Liaison Officer (PLO) related in status and duties to that of a DLO.
(3) How do the positions of PLO and DLO differ.
(4) How long has the PLO position existed and is it unique to his department.
Dr Kemp
—The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1) Further to my answer to question 360 (
Hansard
, 28 June 1996, page 3216) the listing in the September issue of the Parliament House Communications Directory shows that there are still only two DLOs attached to my ministerial office.
(2) No.
(3) The PLO in my office is a ministerial staff member employed under MOPS. The DLOs are departmental officers.
(4) The PLO title has existed in my office since 15 April 1996. The position is held by a ministerial officer, not a departmental one.

Parkes: Freight Airport Proposal
(Question No. 808)
Mr Cobb
asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, upon notice, on 10 October 1996:
(1) Has his attention been drawn to support by over 30 NSW rural local government areas to establish an international freight airport at Parkes.
(2) Is Parkes centrally located to both supply areas and transport routes.
(3) What maintenance service and other infrastructure facilities would be necessary to operate an international air freight facility at Parkes.
(4) What is his Department's estimate of the minimum number of inward and outward air freight movements for the Parkes proposal to be economically viable.
(5) Are there any country to country agreements which would impede the Parkes proposal from being viable; if so, what steps could be taken to overcome those impediments.
(6) What assistance will he provide to assess the viability of the Parkes proposal.
Mr Sharp
—The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows;
(1) I am aware of the support of over 30 NSW rural local government councils for the establishment of an international freight airport at Parkes. However, to date the proposal has not been subject to any rigorous analysis and assessment and the proponents of the project, the Inland Marketing Corporation, have not been able to demonstrate the viability of the concept.
(2) Parkes is located in a major agricultural production area. It is very well connected to other regions of Australia by rail and road. It is located on the Newell highway, the principal north‐south road corridor in inland eastern Australia. Addition
ally, it is on the Sydney‐Perth national rail line and is a key rail junction for eastern Australia.
(3) The maintenance facilities and infrastructure required to operate an international freight airport would depend on a number of factors, including the type of cargo that will be transported through the airport and the aircraft that will use the airport. The cost of the provision and operation of any such infrastructure would have to be able to be recovered from the users of the facility.
The Inland Marketing Corporation, the proponents of an international air freight airport at Parkes, have suggested that the facility would handle some 882 B747 freighter flights into and out of the airport (an average of 2.4 B747 services per day carrying 150,000 tonnes of freight annually) by year 3 of the airport's operations. This is more freight than is currently carried from the combined Australian international gateways other than Sydney and Melbourne and is equal to Melbourne's current performance. The proposed number of flights would be equal to the total number of dedicated freighter services currently operating out of Australia.
(4) The Department has not undertaken a detailed assessment of the viability of the Inland Marketing Corporation proposal for an international air freight airport at Parkes.
The Inland Marketing Corporation has made a number of submissions and given evidence to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Microeconomic Reform Inquiry into Air Freight Exports on its proposal. However, I am advised that other submissions to the Inquiry have questioned the viability of the proposal due to:
the adequacy of existing airports and airline capacity and the unwillingness of airlines and freight forwarders with established infrastructure at other Australian airports to incur additional set up costs at a regional airport;
the inability of a regional airport to service the operating cost of an international facility, let alone the capital costs involved in establishing the facility;
the inability of a regional international airport to deliver lower transport prices and greater capacity for producers than that already offered through the existing gateways;
the inability of a regional international air freight airport to attract the air freight imports necessary to sustain air services; and
the inability to attract sufficient supply of produce to justify the provision of dedicated year round air freight capacity.
These are matters which the Parliamentary Committee is expected to fully assess and analyse.
(5) Parkes is not a designated international airport and is therefore not on the route schedule of any of Australia's bilateral Air Services Agreements. No international airlines have expressed any interest in either operating to Parkes or having Parkes added to any bilateral air service agreement route schedule.
(6) I have asked the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Microeconomic Reform to conduct an inquiry into Australia's air freight exports. The Committee is specifically investigating the need for, and viability of, additional international aviation infrastructure to meet the needs of regional exporters. The Committee has provided an opportunity for the Inland Marketing Corporation (IMC), which has proposed the development of a freight airport at Parkes, and the many other proponents of inland international airports to have their proposals fully considered and the issues openly canvassed through the Committee's processes.
I understand that the committee is aiming to conclude its work and report to Parliament before the end of the year.
Nursing Homes
(Question No. 810)
Mr Pyne
asked the Minister for Family Services, upon notice, on 10 October 1996:
(1) Does the definition of `home' for the purpose of assets testing for the nursing home entry contribution include a retirement village licence; if not, how will persons in retirement villages be assessed.
(2) Will the issue of licensing regulations be addressed in the residential aged care structural reform package.
(3) Will the formula of 40 beds per 1000 over 70 year olds be altered to recognise changes in population demographics, particularly with respect to
increasing life expectancy and consequent increased demand for frail aged care.
Mrs Moylan
—The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1) The entry contribution system, which has been operating in hostels since 1988 and will be extended to nursing homes from 1 July 1997, does not have an assets test. Entry contributions are negotiated between the resident and the provider, subject to a number of protections, including the provision that the resident must be left with a minimum assets level, currently $22,500, after paying the entry contribution.
The honourable member for Sturt may be referring to the Financially Disadvantaged Persons provisions, which provide a higher subsidy for residents unable to pay entry contributions. These provisions currently define as a Financially Disadvantaged Person, a resident who is a full pensioner and has not owned a home in the previous two years. There is no definition of `home' and the current Hostel Manual uses this term and `house' interchangeably. Evidence about a resident's housing status primarily depends on the resident's statements to the hostel, and it is likely that the treatment of a person who had an interest in a retirement village unit would vary between hostels.
The Financially Disadvantaged Persons provisions are currently under review by a working group comprising representatives of peak consumer and industry organisations. It is likely that the definition of home ownership will be clarified to include residents who have a financial interest in their residence which is saleable.
The honourable member may also be thinking of the Department of Social Security's pension assets test, under which a person is defined as a home‐owner for pension purposes if they have paid a contribution of over $88,500 towards a retirement village unit. If they have paid a lesser contribution, this amount is treated as a non‐financial asset.
(2) The Commonwealth will be consulting with State Governments with a view to seeking appropriate changes in state nursing home and hostel licensing regulations in line with the integration of the nursing home and hostel systems under the Residential Aged Care Structural Reform Package. Commonwealth legislation governing nursing homes and hostels will be replaced with new unified legislation covering residential aged care, which is now being drafted.
(3) The residential aged care needs‐based planning formula builds in recognition of changes in population demographics, because it sets a ratio of 100 residential care places per 1,000 people aged seventy and over. Hence, as the population over seventy rises, the number of residential care places will rise proportionately.
With the integration of the nursing home and hostel systems from 1 July 1997, the current separate nursing home and hostel ratios, now 40 and 50 places respectively, will be collapsed into a single residential place ratio of 90 places per 1,000 people over seventy, which with a ratio of 10 Community Aged Care Packages per 1,000, will comprise the needs‐based planning ratio of 100 places per 1,000 people over seventy.
Yamatji Language Centre: House Purchase
(Question No. 840)
Mr Tuckey
asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, on notice, on 17 October 1996:
(1) What was the purchase price of the house at 115 Augustus Street, Geraldton WA, used by the Yamatji Language Centre.
(2) Who funded the purchase.
(3) Were all council by‐laws adhered to in relation to the purchase.
Dr Wooldridge
—The Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) has provided the following information to the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs in response to the honourable member's question:
(1) The purchase price of the premises was $145,000.
(2) The purchase was made with a grant from the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission.
(3) The Yamatji Language Centre Aboriginal Corporation (YLCAC) was unaware of a Council by‐law restricting the conducting of a business in the premises. (The previous owner conducted an accounting business from the premises). The Geraldton City Council originally moved to close the YLCAC operations at the premises. However, following a deputation from YLCAC, and Council's clearer understanding of the nature of YLCAC's operations and realisation that the Council itself utilises YLCAC interpreting and translating services, the Council reconsidered its position, and agreed to permit YLCAC to conduct its business
from the premises, on condition that YLCAC install six parking bays. Local residents objected to the requirement to install parking bays, and the Council is reconsidering this requirement.

Nursing Homes: Directors of Nursing
(Question No. 871)
Mr Mossfield
asked the Minister for Family Services, upon notice, on 29 October 1996:
(1) Is it a fact that the only document nursing home Directors of Nursing receive in departmental briefings is a budget fact sheet entitled `Residential Aged Care Structural Reform'; if so, will the Government provide more detailed material.
(2) Will she urgently advise Directors of Nursing how the reforms will be implemented.
(3) Will the standards to be applied in the new, single integrated aged care facility come into effect 12 months after amalgamation on 1 July 1997; if so, why.
(4) Will funding only be made available to accredited facilities; if so, when will accreditation be determined.
Mrs Moylan
—The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1) and (2) Budget fact sheets were made available from budget night to explain the changes being announced.
Directors of Nursing are one of the key target groups to be informed about the structural reform in aged care through the aged care information strategy.
Components of the information strategy are:
`Aged Care News' which is issued quarterly. The November issue describes the aged care structural reform package announced in the budget; and
a monthly newsletter from the department to inform all stakeholders (including each residential facility) of the progress in implementing the reform strategy.
(3) No. At present, nursing homes and hostels are monitored against two different sets of standards. A group of industry representatives is working with the Department to develop a set of common
standards which will apply to all residential aged care facilities from 1 July 1997.
The same group is also developing a draft set of standards to be used for the accreditation of residential aged care facilities from 1 January 1998. The accreditation standards will address aspects of facility operation not covered by the current arrangements. In recognition that not all facilities will be ready for accreditation immediately, the common outcome standards will continue to be the requirement for unaccredited facilities during a set transition period.
(4) In the long term, only accredited facilities will receive Commonwealth funding to deliver residential aged care services. This reflects our commitment to a quality assurance system that protects the consumer, while shifting the emphasis from regulation to an environment where the industry shares the responsibility for ensuring quality.
There will be a transition period to allow facilities to develop and implement improvement plans consistent with the aims of the accreditation standards. The length of this period will be determined in consultation with all the stakeholders, but regardless of the time allowed, there will be a clear cut‐off date by which facilities must meet the standards required for accreditation.
Hostels and Nursing Homes
(Question No. 872)
Mr Mossfield
asked the Minister for Family Services, upon notice, on 29 October 1996:
Will a private sector tendering scheme be used to appoint an accreditor for each nursing home and hostel; if so, (a) will this process take several years and (b) what funding authorisation and delivery arrangements will be established in the interim.
Mrs Moylan
—The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
No decision has been made on the selection process to appoint accreditors to review aged care
facilities. A working party of stakeholders is currently considering a broad range of options for the accreditation process. The options include:
the use of contracted accreditors;
the use of peers who would undergo training in auditing;
accreditors employed by the independent agency (either full time, part time or on a casual basis); and
a mix of the above arrangements.
The working party will respond to me in December. Depending on the final approach taken, appropriate transition and funding arrangements will be established to ensure a smooth change from present arrangements to the new.
Nursing Homes
(Question No. 873)
Mr Mossfield
asked the Minister for Family Services, upon notice, on 29 October 1996:
(1) Will untrained staff be required to perform nursing care duties under the new nursing home arrangements; if so, why.
(2) When will her department develop (a) instruments for assessing prospective residents and patients and (b) quality assurance programs to ensure standards are met.
(3) What role will State Governments have in new nursing home arrangements and how will the Commonwealth replace the existing inspectorial arrangements.
Mrs Moylan
—The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1) Untrained staff will not be required to perform nursing duties under the new arrangements. The new arrangements will ensure that residential care services meet standards that are acceptable to the community and will encourage facilities to exceed them. In particular, accreditation will require that appropriate care is given by appropriate staff. Hostels now have considerable flexibility to develop their own staffing mix across core and non core duties and with few exceptions use this responsibility suitably. Nursing homes also have the flexibility now to determine the mix of skilled and less skilled core staff. The changes from July 1997, extend to nursing homes the full flexibility now available to hostels by removing the barrier to effective use of staff for both support and personal care tasks.
(2)(a) The single classification scale for residential aged care will be operational from 1 July 1997. The developed instrument should be available from
April 1997, with information and training provided prior to its operational commencement.
(b) The Department already enforces standards of care in nursing homes and hostels. The Government is committed to improving substantially the quality assurance system through shifting the emphasis from regulation to an environment where the industry shares the responsibility for ensuring quality and is encouraged to exceed base level requirements. The new quality system is to be implemented from January 1998.
(3) At the time of the 1996 Budget I wrote to my State counterparts advising them of the Commonwealth's intention to undertake structural reform of residential aged care and indicating that the Commonwealth would be looking to consult on implementation issues in the near future. A number of States have already expressed an interest in becoming involved in discussions on the detailed implementation of the package and I am currently considering a process of consultation on relevant issues.
Hostels and Nursing Homes
(Question No. 874)
Mr Mossfield
asked the Minister for Family Services, upon notice, on 29 October 1996:
Has the sum that residents must pay hostels increased from 85 per cent to 87.5 per cent of their pensions; if so, how will this affect a resident's ability to provide for personal extras.
Mrs Moylan
—The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
Currently the standard resident contribution for hostels is 85 per cent and for nursing homes 87.5 per cent of the combined pension and rent assistance. From 1 July 1997, the base contribution that hostels can charge will be brought into line with that for nursing homes, as part of the broader alignment of the nursing home and hostel programs. It will not be compulsory for hostels to charge residents the higher base contribution and the additional income raised from hostel residents as a result of this change will be kept by providers and not by the Government.
For non‐pensioners in hostels, the base contribution that can be charged will increase to the same level as for nursing home residents under current arrangements, an amount equivalent to 87.5 per cent of the combined pension and rent assistance. However, a different base contribution will apply for pensioners due to some technical changes to the way rent assistance is paid that will take effect at the same time. These changes will mean that the base contribution for pensioners in hostel and nursing homes will be reduced to 85 per cent of the
pension only and rent assistance payments will be transferred into direct subsidies for providers.
The rent assistance changes will not have any significant effect on income for residents or providers. The reduction in the base contribution will enable residents to maintain at least the level of residual income that nursing home residents currently retain. The direct subsidy, together with the base resident contribution, will allow providers to raise the same level of income as nursing homes do from residents under current arrangements, an amount equivalent to 87.5 per cent of the combined pension and rent assistance.
Nursing Homes
(Question No. 875)
Mr Mossfield
asked the Minister for Family Services, upon notice, on 29 October 1996:
(1) Is a portion of nursing home entry fees deducted for the purposes of capital works programs and the balance refunded upon transfer to another nursing home or death; if so what portion of the $26 000 entry contribution will be retained by a nursing home for this purpose.
(2) Will hostels and nursing homes be required to provide a percentage of places to financially disadvantaged persons under amalgamation arrangements.
(3) Will the single classification instrument of elderly, frail aged and nursing homes adversely impact upon the staffing and operational ability of the amalgamated bodies; if not, why not.
Mrs Moylan
—The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1) Yes, nursing homes will retain only a portion of entry contributions and will be required to refund the balance when residents leave. There will be strong incentives for these funds to be used for capital purposes.
Under the current hostel system, providers can retain interest from a contribution plus a retention amount of up to $2,600 a year for a maximum of five years. The retention amounts to apply under the new arrangements will be based on the current hostel system, although the precise detail is still being worked out in consultation with industry and consumer representatives.
(2) Yes, on a regional basis. The precise details about how financially disadvantaged persons will be defined and how the ratios will work is still being determined in consultation with industry and consumer representatives.
(3) No. The Single Classification Instrument will ensure a better match between funding and care need for all residents. It will be implemented as
part of a simplified, single funding and classification system to apply across the whole sector, which will provide greater flexibility for all facilities in the type of residents they care for and in the operational and staffing arrangements they choose to put into place. There is no expectation that every facility will choose to provide the full range of care. Individual facilities may choose to allow ageing in place or to specialise in one type or level of care. Either way, their operations will be better supported by the new system.
Nursing Homes: New Bed Funding
(Question No. 881)
Mr Mossfield
asked the Minister for Family Services, upon notice, on 30 October 1996:
(1) Is her answer to part (1) of question No. 629 (
Hansard
, 17 October 1996, page 5560) the same response which is being given by her department to inquirers such as the Holy Family Nursing Home, Quakers Hill, NSW.
(2) When will the advertisements referred to in her answer to part (3) of question No. 629 appear.
Mrs Moylan
—The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1) No. Providers such as the Sisters of the Holy Family of Nazareth in Marayong who received an approval in principle for nursing home beds in the 1995 approvals round, did not receive and are not eligible for capital funding. They are however, eligible for recurrent funding of the nursing home beds when occupancy occurs.
(2) Advertisements appeared in the press on 9 November 1996.
Comcare v. Ms Gaylene Adamthwaite
(Question No. 884)
Mr Allan Morris
asked the Minister for Industrial Relations, upon notice, on 30 October 1996:
(1) What (a) barristers' fees, (b) solicitors' fees, (c) witness fees, including ravel and other allowances, (d) another associated court or legal fees or costs and (e) internal costs to Comcare were incurred in the Administrative Appeals Tribunal (AAT) hearing (N95/124) listed as Comcare v. Ms Gaylene Adamthwaite.
(2) Which Comcare officer (a) made the decision to withhold from Ms Adamthwaite a medical report from a doctor Comcare directed Ms Adamthwaite to visit, (b) decided not to agree to mediation as part of the AAT process and (c) determined finally to proceed to the AAT, and was this decision reviewed.
(3) How many times has Comcare referred persons to the doctor it used as a witness at the Adamthwaite AAT hearing since October 1995.
(4) What proportion of Comcare claims (a) are settled by acceptance of the claim, (b) are rejected and no further action taken, (c) proceed to mediation and (d) proceed to AAT hearing level.
(5) What proportion of claims which proceed to mediation or an AAT hearing conclude with no liability for Comcare.
Mr Reith
—The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1) To date, costs of $9,284, have been paid. They comprise:
(a) Barrister's fees—No account has been received at this time; (b) Solicitor's fees—$6,803; (c) Witness and travel fees—$359; (d) other associated court or legal fees or costs [comprised of medical examination fees ($845) and other disbursements ($477)]—$1,322; (e) Comcare's internal costs—approximately $800.
(2)(a) The Review Services Manager of Comcare's NSW Office made the decision to initially withhold the medical report, based on legal advice from Comcare's solicitor handling Ms Adamthwaite's appeal. Ms Adamthwaite was subsequently provided with the report.
(b) The Tribunal Member presiding at the pre‐hearing conferences did not invite formal mediation and allowed the matter to proceed to hearing. This was not Comcare's decision to make.
(c) The decision to appeal to the AAT was Ms Adamthwaite's and, as such, not subject to Comcare's review.
(3) Thirty‐three Comcare claimants have been referred to the doctor used as a witness at the Adamthwaite AAT hearing since October 1995. These referrals were not necessarily in the context of AAT proceedings.
(4) These questions have been answered in relation to the 1994‐95 financial year, as this provides more complete information because of lead times in finalising cases before the AAT. Approximately 19,400 new claims lodged with Comcare in the 1994‐95 financial year. Of these:
(a) 92 per cent were accepted;
(b) 8 per cent were rejected, and of these 87 per cent had no AAT‐related action;
(c) formal AAT‐directed mediation is rare and figures are not available. In 1994‐95, less formal mediation, resulting in negotiated settlements, occurred in 32 per cent of Comcare cases appealed to the AAT. This equates to 0.2 per cent of claims received; and
(d) 0.1 per cent of claims proceeded to AAT hearing and have been finalised.
(5) The proportion of claims for initial liability which in 1994‐95 had either a negotiated outcome following an appeal to the AAT, or a finalised AAT hearing and which concluded with no liability for Comcare, is approximately 61 per cent. This calculation excludes those claims for which a decision by the AAT has not yet been made.
Reactions to Drugs
(Question No. 910)
Mr Price
asked the Minister for Health and Family Services, upon notice, on 5 November 1996:
(1) Is he able to say whether there is a requirement to report reactions to drugs; if so, to whom.
(2) How many reactions reported since 1991 have been attributed to out‐of‐date drugs.
(3) What were identified as being the most common causes of drug reactions since 1991.
Dr Wooldridge
—The answer to the honourable member's questions are as follows:
(1) Yes, if the sponsor of a drug product supplied in Australia becomes aware of a serious, unexpected adverse reaction or event which is suspected as being associated with the use of the drug, the sponsor is required to report that in writing to the Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA).
In addition, a voluntary scheme for reporting by health professionals of suspected adverse reactions to drugs has been in operation in Australia since the 1960's.
(2) Regular and detailed clinical analysis of incoming adverse drug reaction reports has only detected evidence of a causal role due to `out‐of‐date' (also known as `expired') drugs in exceptionally rare instances.
(3) The more frequently encountered adverse reactions in specific individuals result from allergy, exaggerated (pharmacological) effects or genetic predisposition.
Pharmaceuticals
(Question No. 911)
Mr Price
asked the Minister for Health and Family Services, upon notice, on 5 November 1996:
(1) Are there legislative prohibitions on the sale of pharmaceuticals for out‐of‐date prescriptions; if so, what are they.
(2) Do manufacturers of pharmaceuticals offer to buy back out‐of‐date pharmaceuticals, if so, (a) is there an industry average and (b) is the full sum
offered by manufacturers passed on to chemists by wholesalers.
(3) Are the activities of pharmaceutical wholesalers regulated; if so, by whom; if not, why not.
Dr Wooldridge
—The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1) Yes. In relation to pharmaceutical benefits made available under the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme, the National Health (Pharmaceutical Benefits) Regulations provide that:
21 (1) An approved pharmacist or an approved medical practitioner must not supply a pharmaceutical benefit to a person on the first presentation of a prescription for the supply of that benefit to the person, unless:
(a) subject to regulations 22, 26 and 26A, the original and the duplicate of the prescription are:
(i) written in accordance with these Regulations; and
(ii) dated within 12 months before the day on which they are presented; and
(iii) given to the pharmacist or practitioner; and
(b) the pharmacist or practitioner writes on the original and duplicate:
(i) the pharmacist's or practitioner's name and approval number under Regulation 8A; and
(ii) a number that identifies the prescription.
A similar Regulation 21(2) applies in respect of prescriptions for pharmaceutical benefits supplied from an approved hospital authority.
(2) The allowance of credit for out‐of‐date pharmaceuticals is a matter for individual manufacturers.
(3) The regulation of wholesalers is covered by State/Territory legislation.

Second Sydney Airport
(Question No. 986)
Mr McClelland
asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Environment, upon notice, on 21 November 1996:
Will the current environmental impact statement procedures being developed for the Badgery's Creek or Holsworthy airport proposals have regard to the navigational routes of planes using Sydney (Kingsford‐Smith) Airport; if so, how.
Mr Warwick Smith
—The Minister for the Environment has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:
Yes. The guidelines for the environmental impact statement (EIS) on Sydney's proposed second major airport require the EIS to describe the proposed operation of the new airport, including the coordination of airspace requirements for aircraft approaching and departing from the airport with reference to other aerodromes in the region and implications for, or conflicts with, their operations. In this context, the EIS is to discuss how a second airport may affect utilisation of Sydney (Kingsford‐Smith) Airport.
RAAF Base Richmond: Commercialisation of Activities
(Question No. 987)
Mr Bevis
asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 2 December 1996:
(1) Has he received advice regarding the commercialisation of activities at RAAF Base Richmond; if so, what is the advice.
(2) Will activities at RAAF Base Richmond be commercialised.
Mr McLachlan
—The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1) Yes. All non‐core support activities at RAAF Richmond will be tested under the Air Force Commercial Support Program to ensure they are undertaken in the most cost‐effective manner.
(2) Whether a particular non‐core support activity is contracted‐out to Australian industry, or retained in the RAAF under a restructured in‐house arrangement, will depend on the relative competitiveness of bids from Australian industry and in‐house options.
Industrial Relations: Victoria
(Question No. 994)
Mr Kelvin Thomson
asked the Minister for Industrial Relations, upon notice, on 2 December 1996:
Does the Government intend taking over the functions and personnel of the Victorian Department of State Development which monitors compliance with industrial agreements and occupational health and safety issues.
Mr Reith
—The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
No. As part of the referral by Victoria of its industrial relations jurisdiction to the Commonwealth, the Commonwealth will be providing services for the industrial relations system in Victoria. These services will include information and advisory services as well as activities directed at achieving compliance with the relevant provisions of the Workplace Relations Act 1996. The Government is discussing with the Victorian Government matters concerning resources. The referral to the Commonwealth does not include occupational health and safety matters.

Mr Price

Hansard
, 21 August 1996, page 3516), has consideration of the issues raised in the report of the Commonwealth Ombudsman for 1994‐95 been finalised in the context of the (a) report of the National Commission of Audit, (b) the Draft Industry Commission Report on Competitive Tendering and Contracting by Public Service
Agencies, (c) Report 37 of the Administrative Review Council dealing with administrative review and funding programs and (d) the Administrative Review Council's report on Administrative Law and Contracting of Services.

Mr Howard

(b) There is no requirement for Humanitarian Program entrants to be sponsored by family members in the manner in which applicants for certain Migration Program visas are sponsored. Persons who seek to assist family members or other people to enter Australia under the Special Humanitarian Program or the Special Assistance Categories of the Humanitarian Program need to lodge a proposal under the Special Humanitarian Program or make an offer of support under the Special Assistance Category.
However, neither of these constitute a sponsorship as defined in the Migration Regulations. Statistics are not kept on the relationship between the proposer and the entrant.
(c) Nil.
(d) Proposers under the Special Humanitarian Program are not obligated to provide settlement assistance to the person proposed. The offer of support under the Special Assistance Category requires the proposer to provide a written undertaking that specifies assistance with regard to:
food, clothing, accommodation and household goods;
personal support;
access to community and public services;
obtaining employment;
language interpretation and securing English language instruction;
community involvement and self‐reliance;
reimbursing the Commonwealth for its costs (if any) in providing accommodation services to the applicant.
Statistics are not kept on the extent to which proposers provide assistance to Special Assistance Category entrants.
Anti-Racism Campaign
(Question No. 1050)
Mr Kerr
asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, upon notice, on 9 December 1996:
(1) Did he announce the Government's anti‐racism campaign on 20 August 1996.
(2) Were community organisations consulted in the development of the campaign; if so, (a) which organisations were consulted and (b) what recommendations did they make.
(3) Has his Department conducted market research to advise it on what programs to deliver and how to deliver them; if so, what were the results of the market research; if not, on what advice or information has the campaign been determined.
(4) If market research was conducted, was it determined through a tendering process; if so, (a), what was the brief for the tender, (b) where and when was the tender announcement made, (c) who was the winning tenderer and (d) what market research will that agency be required to undertake to effectively deliver the campaign.
Mr Ruddock
—The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1) Yes. A media release about the campaign was issued on that date.
(2) Yes. Advice has been sought from individuals and organisations drawn from:
academics and those with experience in anti‐racism programs;
community groups;
ethnic and indigenous organisations;
business, tourism and professional groups; and
the wider community encompassing rural groups, aged organisations, welfare organisations, family associations and religious groups.
All have provided useful insights that need to be taken into account as the Government plans and constructs the campaign.
(3) No. Market research will be undertaken when the Government has finalised the strategic framework for the campaign.
(4) No market research has been undertaken.
Comcar: Subcontractors
(Question No. 1052)
Mr Laurie Ferguson
asked the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 10 December 1996:
(1) Was Mr Larry Swindells previously employed in Comcar management; if so, (a) in which position and (b) for how long was he employed by Comcar.
(2) Is he able to say whether (a) Mr Swindells is the proprietor of Larry Swindells Specialised Transport Services Pty Ltd and (b) that company competes with Comcar in the hire car market.
(3) Does that company subcontract to Comcar; if so, what sums have been paid by Comcar since 31 December 1995.
(4) Is he able to say whether that company was successful in gaining a significant portion of the transportation arrangements for the recent visit of the President of the United States of America.
(5) On what dates did discussions occur between US Government representatives and Comcar.
(6) Is he able to say whether, despite initial indications of success and prior work performance leading to congratulatory comments in the US Senate, Comcar was eventually unsuccessful in gaining the contract due to personality differences between a Comcar executive and US representatives.
(7) What was the estimated value of this contract.
(8) Does Mr Swindells have commercial relationships with the DAS Removals Manager and former Comcar manager, Mr D Fink and Acting NSW State Comcar Supervisor, M. Hanley.
(9) Has Mr Swindells, as proprietor of Larry Swindells Specialised Transport Services Pty Ltd, (a) been permitted use of Comcar equipment, such as laminators and (b) had access to Comcar computers relating to bookings, billing and client printouts, both at Comcar premises and from his home.
(10) Do Comcar employees have password access to obtain this information; if so, (a) how many, (b) who are they and (c) what positions do they hold.
Mr Jull
—The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
The questions the honourable member has asked are related to similar allegations which had previously been made to the Department and are currently under investigation.
As soon as the investigations have been completed I will provide detailed answers to the honourable member's questions.

Department of Industrial Relations: Newcastle Staff
(Question No. 1141)
Mr Allan Morris
asked the Minister for Industrial Relations, on notice, on 12 December 1996:
(1) How many staff positions in the Minister's Department were located within the electoral division of Newcastle as at 6 December 1996.
(2) How many of the positions referred to in part (1) were occupied at 6 December 1996.
(3) How many persons occupying positions referred to in part (1) were employed on a temporary basis at 6 December 1996.
(4) Will the Minister provide a breakdown by position of the staff referred to in part (1).
(5) What was the address of each of the premises owned or leased by the Minister's Department in the electoral division of Newcastle at 6 December 1996.
Mr Reith
—The answer to the honourable member's questions is as follows:
(1) Four.
(2) Two.
(3) One of the positions was filled on a temporary basis by a potentially excess officer from elsewhere in the department.
(4) The breakdown of positions and classification of staff is:
1 x Administrative Service Officer Class 6; 2 x Administrative Service Officer Class 4; and 1 x Administrative Service Officer Class 3.
The positions currently occupied are the Administrative Service Officer Class 6 and the Administrative Service Officer Class 3. The two Administrative Service Officer Class 4 positions will be occupied on a permanent basis from 6 January 1997.
(5) Ground Floor, 237 Wharf Road, Newcastle, NSW. This property is leased.
